title: McDermott v. Kentucky Fried Chicken/Sylvan Food
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Margaret
      McDermott, Appellant,
				v.
				Kentucky Fried Chicken/Sylvan Food, Employer;
      and Security Insurance Co. of Hartford (Covenant Administrators) and Coregis
      Insurance Company (GE Cypercomp), Carriers, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Clyde N. Davis, Jr., Special Circuit
  Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-511
Submitted November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  November 5, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				J. Marvin Mullis, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Harold J. Willson, Jr., of Greenville; Mark Andrews Allison and Weston
  Adams, III, both of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this workerâ€™s compensation case, the Appellate Panel found Margaret McDermott did
  not suffer a compensable mental-mental injury, a mental injury caused or
  aggravated by physical injury, or a physical injury to her left shoulder.Â  The
  circuit court affirmed the decision and order of the Appellate Panel.Â  We
  affirm.[1]
FACTS
Kentucky Fried Chicken (KFC) employed
  McDermott as a general manager.Â  On June 13, 2003, McDermott slipped and
  fell on a wet floor at KFC.Â  She was taken to the emergency room where
  her right arm was placed in a brace.Â  She visited Dr. Joseph Gabriel on
  June 16 and 23, 2003.Â  The doctorâ€™s report indicated she complained of some
  â€œpain in her right arm, hand, and shoulder but is otherwise doing well.â€Â  When
  she returned for a follow up with right wrist pain, he described her condition
  as â€œsome trouble with some right wrist pain as well as occasional pins and
  needles type sensation in her right hand.Â  She denies any new problems at this
  time.â€Â  McDermott was excused from work June 16 through 22, 2003, returning to
  work on June 23, 2003.Â  
September 2003, McDermott learned she
  had been the victim of identity theft when an employee used her social security
  number to attempt activation of a cell phone.Â  McDermott was never
  responsible for any charges resulting from the use of her social security
  number, and the situation was resolved within two months.Â  In addition,
  McDermott asserts in her brief that her social security number was used in an attempt
  to obtain a credit card.Â  
In October 2003, McDermott was promoted to
  manager of a larger KFC.Â  On October 19, 2003, an incident (the Wrench
  Incident) occurred between McDermott and an employee, Lamont Summers.Â  McDermott
  questioned Summers about why there was not a sufficient amount of chicken prepared
  for the lunch crowd.Â  Summers picked up a pair of pliers or a wrench, which he raised
  to shoulder level while speaking to McDermott, and McDermott said to
  him, â€œYouâ€™d better use it.â€Â  McDermott later became upset and started crying.Â  

On October 23, 2003, McDermott was
  admitted to Richland Springs Hospital for treatment of major depression and
  anxiety related to work stress.Â  The admitting physician indicated McDermott
  had a profile consistent with severe anxiety, including features of dependent
  and compulsive personality, and mild depression.Â  On October 31, 2003,
  McDermott was discharged with (1) a diagnosis of major depressive disorder,
  single episode, severe; (2) anxiety disorder; and (3) stress from work and identity
  theft.Â  The discharging physician noted her condition had rapidly improved and
  her mood had stabilized.Â  Following her discharge, McDermott was
  treated with electroconvulsive or â€œshockâ€ therapy.Â  Previously, in
  2001 McDermott was treated with prescription medication for depression and
  anxiety arising out of her exposure to pool chemicals.Â  The exposure was not
  related to employment.
McDermott filed three claims: (1) for the
  slip and fall, alleging it caused physical injuries and a nervous condition;
  (2) for the identity theft, asserting the incident caused a â€œnervous condition
  (aggravation of pre-existing condition)â€; and (3) for the Wrench Incident contending
  it caused a â€œnervous condition (aggravation of pre-existing condition).â€Â  
 
The single commissioner found McDermottâ€™s
  physical injuries to her right arm arising out of her fall compensable and
  denied the remainder of the claims.Â  The single commissioner found
  McDermottâ€™s psychological problems were neither related to nor aggravated by
  events she described.Â  These findings were based on McDermottâ€™s lack of
  credibility due to her inconsistent demeanor
  at the hearing, her demonstration of selective memory, and her inconsistent
  speech patterns.Â  Accordingly, the single commissioner found McDermott failed
  to prove by the greater weight of the evidence that: (1) her work conditions
  were extraordinary or unusual compared to ordinary conditions of managerial
  employment with KFC and (2) her emotional problems were neither caused nor
  aggravated by unusual and extraordinary conditions of employment.Â  

The Appellate
  Panel affirmed and adopted the single commissionerâ€™s factual findings and
  conclusions of law as the decision and order of the Appellate Panel.Â  The
  circuit court affirmed, incorporating the order of the Appellate Panel by
  reference.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW

The South
  Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for
  judicial review of decisions by the Appellate Panel of the South Carolina
  Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130,
  134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  Under the scope of review established in the APA, this court may not
  substitute its judgment for that of the Appellate Panel as to the weight of the
  evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse if the decision is affected by
  an error of law.Â  Stone v. Traylor Bros., Inc., 360 S.C. 271, 274, 600
  S.E.2d 551, 552 (Ct. App. 2004).
The substantial evidence rule governs the standard of review in a
  workersâ€™ compensation decision.Â  Frame
    v. Resort Servs. Inc.,357
  S.C. 520, 527, 593 S.E.2d 491, 494 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The Appellate Panelâ€™s decision must be affirmed if supported by
  substantial evidence in the record.Â  Shuler v. Gregory Elec., 366 S.C. 435, 440, 622 S.E.2d 569, 571 (Ct.
  App. 2005). Â An appellate court can reverse or modify the
  Appellate Panelâ€™s decision only if the appellantâ€™s substantial rights have been
  prejudiced because the decision is affected by an error of law or is â€œclearly
  erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the
  whole record.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2006); Bursey v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 360 S.C. 135, 141, 600 S.E.2d 80, 84
  (Ct. App. 2004).  

	â€œSubstantial evidenceâ€ is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor the
  evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which,
  considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the
  conclusion that the administrative agency reached or must have reached in order
  to justify its action.


Lark, 276 S.C. at 135, 276 S.E.2d at 306.

â€œ[T]he
  possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not
  prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial
  evidence.â€Â  Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C.
  430, 432, 319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984). Â Where the evidence is
  conflicting over a factual issue, the findings of the Appellate Panel are
  conclusive.Â  Hargrove v. Titan
    Textile Co.,360 S.C. 276,
  290, 599 S.E.2d 604, 611 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  In workersâ€™ compensation
  cases, the Appellate Panel is the ultimate finder of fact.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  The final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved for the
  Appellate Panel.Â  Bass v. Kenco Group,366 S.C. 450, 458, 622 S.E.2d 577,
  581 (Ct. App. 2005).
DISCUSSION
I.Â  Mental Injury
McDermott
  contends the circuit court erred in affirming the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding that
  her mental injury did not arise out of her compensable physical injury and the
  stressful incidents at work.Â  McDermott asserts all expert medical opinion submitted
  indicated her mental condition was caused and aggravated by the work
  incidents.Â  We disagree.  
â€œA mental-mental injury is a purely mental injury
  resulting from emotional stimuli.â€ Â Doe v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Disabilities &
    Special Needs, 364 S.C. 411, 418, 613 S.E.2d 785, 788 (Ct. App. 2005). Â In
  order to receive benefits for a mental-mental injury unaccompanied by a
  physical injury, a claimant must demonstrate the stressful employment
  conditions causing the mental injury were extraordinary and unusual in
  comparison to the normal conditions of the employment. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2006).Â  However, where the mental injury is induced by
  physical injury, it is not necessary that it result from unusual or
  extraordinary conditions of employment. Â Bass v. Kenco Group, 366 S.C. 450, 465, 622
  S.E.2d 577, 584 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Thus, mental injuries are compensable if induced either by
  physical injury or by unusual or extraordinary conditions of employment. Getsinger v. Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp., 335 S.C. 77, 80, 515 S.E.2d 104, 105 (Ct. App. 1999).
The right of a claimant to compensation for
  aggravation of a pre-existing condition arises only where the claimant has a
  dormant condition which has produced no disability but becomes disabling because
  of the aggravating injury. Â Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 493, 541
  S.E.2d 526, 528 (2001).Â  Aggravation of pre-existing psychiatric problems is compensable
  if that aggravation is caused by a work-related physical injury. Â Id.
For an injury to be compensable, it must arise out of
  and in the course of employment. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160. Â An injury arises
  out of employment if a causal relationship between the conditions under which
  the work is to be performed and the resulting injury is apparent to the
  rational mind, upon consideration of all the
  circumstances. Â Rodney v. Michelin Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 518, 466
  S.E.2d 357, 358 (1996).Â  The claimant has the burden of proving facts that will
  bring the injury within the workersâ€™ compensation law, and such award must not
  be based on surmise, conjecture, or speculation. Â Clade v. Champion Labs., 330 S.C. 8, 11, 496
  S.E.2d 856, 857 (1998).
While medical testimony is entitled to great respect,
  it should not be held conclusive irrespective of other evidence and the fact
  finder may disregard it if the record includes other competent evidence.Â  Tiller
    v. Natâ€™l Health Care of Sumter, 334
  S.C. 333, 340, 513 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1999).Â  Expert
  medical testimony is designed to aid the Appellate Panel in coming to the
  correct conclusion; therefore, the Appellate Panel determines the weight and
  credit to be given to the expert testimony. Â Id.Â  Once admitted, expert
  testimony is to be considered just like any other testimony. Id.Â 
  Accordingly, in deciding whether substantial evidence supports a finding of
  causation, we consider both the lay and expert evidence.Â  Id. at 341,
  513 S.E.2d at 847.
In Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 161, 519
  S.E.2d 102, 106 (1999), the South Carolina Supreme Court explained that, where uncontroverted medical opinions are
  merely deductions drawn from certain symptoms, the final conclusion in disputes concerning compensability remains with the fact finder.Â  The court further observed that in the absence of actual
  testimony from a physician in the record, it is impossible to determine whether
  his opinion was based strictly upon medical symptoms reported by the claimant,
  or on other medical factors. Â Id. at 161
  n.2, 519 S.E.2d at 106 n.2.Â  The burden is on claimants to prove their
  injuries arise out of employment.Â  Id. Â It was
  within the Appellate Panelâ€™s discretion, as the ultimate fact-finder, to weigh the
  doctorâ€™s opinion.Â  Id. at 161, 519 S.E.2d at 106. Â The court ultimately held, although the record contained
  evidence from which the Appellate Panel could have gone the other way, there was
  evidence which would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the
  Appellate Panel reached. Â Id.Â  The decision of the Appellate Panel was
  affirmed.  
The
  only evidence that the work incidents caused McDermottâ€™s mental condition is
  her testimony and doctorsâ€™ reports.Â  The Appellate Panel found McDermottâ€™s
  testimony was not credible.Â  Some of the doctorsâ€™ reports indicated the work
  incidents caused McDermottâ€™s mental problems. Â However, the doctors did not
  actually testify at McDermottâ€™s hearing and were unavailable for
  cross-examination.Â  As in Sharpe, whether the physicians formed their
  opinions based solely on McDermottâ€™s self-report or on other medical factors
  cannot be ascertained from the record.Â  In fact, the Appellate Panel found
  McDermott â€œfalsely told a physician that someone made â€˜a lotâ€™ of unauthorized
  purchases and charges in her name.â€Â   
Jessica
  Jaques, a witness the Appellate Panel found credible, testified McDermott was
  experiencing marital problems, including accusations of adultery by her husband.Â 
  Another manager at KFC stated McDermott disclosed that she and her husband
  fought.Â  Additionally, a medical report from April 2004 indicates McDermottâ€™s
  children caused her a lot of stress and she â€œfeels ugly.â€ Â An undated report
  from Dr. Robert Schnackenberg indicates McDermott was upset because of a denied
  workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  
A.Â  â€œNervous
  Conditionâ€ Arising from Slip and Fall
The Appellate Panel found McDermott did not develop a
  nervous condition because of the fall at KFC.Â  Immediately following the
  fall, McDermott reported that she was anxious and nervous.Â  However, at
  a follow up visit a week later, she did not mention being anxious or nervous,
  and it was the last time she mentioned pain in her right arm.Â  McDermott
  returned to work on June 19, 2003.Â  She did not seek treatment for anxiety and
  depression until September 2003, and the doctor made no mention of any causal
  relationship to the previous fall in his report.Â  Therefore, substantial
  evidence supports the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision McDermott was not entitled to
  compensation for mental injury induced by her physical injury.
B.Â  â€œNervous
  Conditionâ€ Arising from Identity Theft
A compensable injury under the Workersâ€™ Compensation
  Act includes only an â€œinjury by accident arising out of and in the course of
  employment.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160. Â In workersâ€™ compensation, the word
  â€œaccident,â€ means an unlooked for and untoward event that the person who
  suffered the injury did not expect, design, or intentionally cause.Â  Yates v. Life Ins. Co. of Ga., 291 S.C. 301, 304, 353
  S.E.2d 297, 299 (Ct. App. 1987).
Tamika Scott, the employee who used McDermottâ€™s social security
  number, was a prisoner on work release.Â  McDermottâ€™s social security number was
  used as the managerâ€™s code to void orders.Â  KFCâ€™s policy was that no one
  other than the manager should have access to the code.Â  KFC may have
  used the social security number to discourage the managers from giving the code
  to other employees.Â  Regardless of the policy, McDermott gave her code to Mable
  Bauknight, a team leader, as well as other employees.Â  Although McDermott could
  not recall which employees she gave her code to, she specifically denied giving
  it to any of the work-release employees.Â  Jaques, a KFC employee who the
  Appellate Panel found credible, testified McDermott had given her the code and Tamika
  Scott was one of the employees who used the code.Â  Jaques claimed other
  work-release employees had the code.Â  
McDermott did attribute her nervousness
  and anxiety to the identity theft when she visited the doctor.Â  However, as the
  Appellate Panel noted, she misrepresented the extent of the identity theft.Â  Further, McDermott continued to work following this incident and was
  promoted and assigned to a larger store in October 2003.Â  The Appellate Panel found it was not unexpected or out
  of the ordinary for other employees, including prison-release workers, to unlawfully
  use a social security number they obtained.Â  Therefore, the record contains
  substantial evidence supporting the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision McDermott was
  not entitled to compensation for a mental injury induced by the identity theft.
C.Â  â€œNervous
  Conditionâ€ Arising from Wrench Incident
The Appellate Panel found Summers to be credible and
  his version of the events surrounding the Wrench Incident was accurate.Â  Furthermore,
  the Appellate Panel concluded the incident between McDermott and Summers was nothing
  more than joking between co-workers.Â  Summers testified the exchange
  between McDermott and himself was a joking, playful one.Â  He testified later
  in the day, she told him she was upset because he picked up the wrench.Â  He stated
  he told McDermott, â€œI thought we was all playingâ€ and she responded, â€œI know
  but I got upset.Â  I took it the wrong way,â€ and the two then hugged.Â  A doctorâ€™s
  report from the day following the Wrench Incident does not mention it, although
  the visit was for anxiety.Â  Accordingly, the record contains substantial
  evidence supporting the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision McDermott was not entitled
  to compensation for a mental injury induced by the Wrench Incident.
Substantial
  evidence supports the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision that McDermott failed to meet
  her burden in showing a compensable mental injury arose out of her physical
  injury, the identity theft, and the Wrench Incident.Â  The Appellate Panel found
  (1) McDermott was not credible; (2) other events in her life caused her nervous
  condition, and (3) the work-related incidents were not unusual and
  extraordinary conditions of employment with KFC. Â The circuit court did not err
  in affirming the Appellate Panelâ€™s denial of McDermottâ€™s mental injury claim.
 
II.Â  Physical Injury
McDermott argues the circuit court erred in affirming
  the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding that she did not sustain a compensable physical
  injury to her left shoulder.Â  We disagree.  
The factual finding
  of Appellate Panel that McDermottâ€™s fall at KFC did not cause injury to the
  left shoulder is supported by substantial evidence in the record.Â  McDermott
  first complained of left should pain on April 28, 2004, over ten months after
  her fall at KFC.Â  At that time, she did not relate the shoulder pain to the
  fall.Â  The only evidence linking the fall at KFC to McDermottâ€™s left shoulder
  pain is her testimony, which was found not credible.Â  While testifying, McDermott
  seemed to be confused about which arm she injured. Â She raised her right arm to
  indicate it was the one injured, while stating at the same time that her left
  arm was injured. Â A co-worker who witnessed her fall stated McDermott did not
  complain of any shoulder pain at the time of her injury.Â  McDermott asserted in
  her brief that the doctorâ€™s report from June 16, 2003, reveals McDermott
  â€œinjured her right hand, arm, and left shoulder.â€Â  However, the record to which
  McDermott referred reads that she suffered â€œpain in her right arm, hand and
  shoulder area.â€Â   
CONCLUSION
Substantial
  evidence supports the Appellate Panelâ€™s findings that (1) McDermottâ€™s
  mental condition was neither caused nor aggravated by the work related
  incidents at KFC, and (2) McDermottâ€™s left shoulder pain was not causally
  related to the slip and fall at KFC. Â We find no error in the circuit courtâ€™s
  incorporation of the Appellate Panels findings of fact and conclusions of law.Â 
  Accordingly, the decision and order of the circuit court is  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â We decide
  this case without oral argument, pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent, 
				
				v.
				Joshua Greer, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Spartanburg County
Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-512
Submitted November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed November 7, 2007

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense,
  Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for
  Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka,
  Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Brown, all of Columbia; and Solicitor
  Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER
  CURIAM:Â  Joshua Greer (Greer) appeals
  from his convictions of murder and armed robbery.Â  He contends the trial court
  erred in excluding third-party guilt evidence.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In
  the early morning hours of August 20, 2002, Paul â€œDocâ€ Reagan (Reagan) was
  beaten and robbed in his home.Â  Eleven days later, he died from his injuries,
  never regaining consciousness.Â  After being confronted with the inconsistencies
  in his first statement, Greer confessed to Reaganâ€™s murder.
In his opening
  statement, defense counsel maintained:Â  â€œNow, Iâ€™m sure the State is going to
  disagree with me with what Iâ€™m going to say but I believe there are two people
  who knew what happened in that house on that night and neither one of them are
  in this courtroom.â€Â  The State anticipated that Greer would attempt to cast
  doubt on his own guilt by directing suspicion toward William Frank â€œButchâ€
  Green (Green), a witness at trial.Â  The State moved, in limine, for the
  exclusion of any third-party guilt evidence Greer might proffer.Â   

	The trial judge
  granted the Stateâ€™s motion, stating:
	The
  record will show that counsel for the State and the defendant came into
  chambers and the State has prepared a motion in limine as to third-party
  guilt.Â  That was not studied by the Court but discussed fairly extensively by
  all parties present.Â  The conclusion was that counsel for the defense will be
  prohibited from casting doubt upon the guilt of his client simply by pointing
  to third party guilt by such inferences or presumptions that may arise out of
  the evidence but that only cause a suspicion by conjecture or speculation that
  the commission of the crime was by another person.Â  That will not be
  permitted.Â  That has not been revealed, nothing of that nature has been
  revealed to the State.
	It was
  the Courtâ€™s understanding and counsel I believe has a clear understanding that
  there is nothing to prevent a complete exploration of the facts as they were
  revealed to you and will be revealed during the testimony but your
  cross-examination will not attempt to point to the guilt of another but simply
  point out facts at [sic] they may be.

Defense counsel agreed
  with the courtâ€™s ruling, responding:Â  â€œYes, sir, in order for the jury to get a
  full understanding of the work that was done by the police on this case.â€Â  When
  the judge inquired if the defense wanted to say anything else before the jurors
  came in, counsel answered:Â  â€œNo, sir.â€
During Greenâ€™s cross-examination,
  Greer did not move to admit third-party guilt evidence or elicit testimony that
  implicated Green as the responsible party.Â  In closing, defense counsel reiterated
  Greerâ€™s innocence, but did not cast suspicion on any other individual:

	At the
  beginning of this case I told you that there were two people who knew what
  happened that night and neither one of them are in this courtroom.Â  When I said
  that I didnâ€™t suggest, I wasnâ€™t suggesting that I was going to point the finger
  at someone, merely maintaining Joshua Greerâ€™s innocence, maintaining his
  innocence, that he was not the one that swung that hammer.

The jury found
  Greer guilty of murder and armed robbery, and the trial judge imposed
  consecutive sentences of thirty years for murder and twenty years for armed
  robbery.
DISCUSSION
Greer contends the
  trial court erred by excluding third-party guilt evidence.Â  In response, the
  State maintains Greer never sought to argue evidence of third-party guilt and,
  therefore, failed to preserve this issue for our review.Â  We agree with the
  State and decline to address the merits of Greerâ€™s appeal.
It is well settled
  that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been
  raised to and ruled upon first by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate
  review. Â State v. Freiburger, 366 S.C. 125, 135, 620 S.E.2d 737, 742
  (2005).Â  Trial counsel is responsible for preserving issues for appellate review.
  Â State v. Passmore, 363 S.C. 568, 583, 611 S.E.2d 273, 281 (Ct. App.
  2005) (citing Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 306, 486 S.E.2d 750, 759
  (1997)).Â  Moreover, the objection in the trial court must have been made by the
  party raising the issue on appeal.Â  Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 324, 487 S.E.2d 187, 190 (1997).Â  South Carolina appellate courts do
  not recognize the â€œplain errorâ€ rule, under which a court in certain
  circumstances is allowed to consider and rectify an error not raised below by
  the party.Â  Elam v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 23-24,
  602 S.E.2d 772, 779-780 (2004);  
Error
  preservation requirements enable the trial court to rule properly after it has
  considered all relevant facts, law, and arguments.Â  Elam, 361 S.C. at
  24, 602 S.E.2d at 780; Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406,
  412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000). Â Without an initial resolution by the trial
  court, a reviewing court simply would not be able to evaluate whether the trial
  court committed error.Â  Staubes, 339 S.C. at 412, 529 S.E.2d at 546; Floyd
    v. Floyd, 365 S.C. 56, 73, 615 S.E.2d 465, 474 (Ct. App. 2005).
A
  motion in limine seeks a pretrial declaration obviating the disclosure of
  potentially prejudicial matter to the jury. Â State v. Hill, 331 S.C. 94,
  100-101, 501 S.E.2d 122, 125-126 (1998).Â  This preliminary ruling by the judge
  and the testimony encapsulated within that proceeding is, in essence, a
  temporary decision on admissibility.Â  State v. Floyd, 295 S.C. 518, 521,
  369 S.E.2d 842, 843 (1988).Â   
A
  proffer of testimony excluded in the preliminary ruling is required to preserve
  the issue of whether the exclusion was proper.Â  State v. Simmons, 360
  S.C. 33, 46, 599 S.E.2d 448, 454 (2004).Â  A reviewing court may not consider
  error alleged in the exclusion of testimony unless the record on appeal shows
  fairly what the rejected testimony would have been.Â  Greenville Memorial Auditorium v. Martin, 301 S.C. 242, 244, 391 S.E.2d 546, 547
  (1990).Â  If it is clear from the record that prejudice exists, the issue will
  be preserved on appeal despite the absence of a proffer.Â  State v. Myers,
  301 S.C. 251, 257-259, 391 S.E.2d 551, 555 (1990).Â   
An
  appellant may waive his right to appeal a decision by the trial judge through
  acquiescence.Â  State v. Jackson, 364 S.C. 329, 334-335, 613 S.E.2d 374,
  376-377 (2005).Â  An issue is not preserved if it has been conceded in the trial
  court.Â  State v. Benton, 338 S.C. 151, 156-57, 526 S.E.2d 228, 231
  (2000).Â   
Greer
  asserts for the first time on appeal that the trial court erred by excluding
  third-party guilt evidence. Â Greer did not argue the issue of third-party guilt
  to the trial court, object to the trial courtâ€™s exclusion of third-party guilt
  evidence, or proffer evidence of third-party guilt at trial.Â  In fact, when the
  court explained the parameters of its preliminary decision, defense counsel
  indicated he understood and agreed with the scope of examination the court
  would allow.Â  Moreover, in his closing statement Greer clarified his earlier comment
  on opening, explaining he â€œwasnâ€™t suggesting that [he] was going to point the
  finger at someone,â€ but was â€œmerely maintaining Joshua Greerâ€™s innocence.â€Â  Consequently,
  there is no issue raised by the appellant for our review.  
Prejudice
  from the exclusion of third-party guilt evidence is not apparent from this
  record on appeal.Â  On direct examination Green admitted he was a prime suspect
  in Reaganâ€™s murder because of his history and his record.Â  Green testified he
  was â€œinterviewed quite extensively by the Spartanburg Police Department over a
  very extended period of time.â€Â  Ultimately, the authorities concluded he was
  not involved with the murder.Â  Without a proffer of what more Greer might
  offer, apart from Greenâ€™s testimony, as evidence of third-party guilt, we are
  unable to discern if the trial courtâ€™s ruling was prejudicial error.Â Â   
Accordingly,
  Greerâ€™s issue on appeal is not preserved for our review.
AFFIRMED.

title: Vaughn v. DHEC
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Stephen Vaughn, Appellant,
				v.
				South Carolina
      Department of Health and Environmental Control and Beresford Creek
      Homeownerâ€™s Association, Respondents.
			
		
	


John D. Geathers, Administrative Law Court
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-513
Submitted November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed November 7, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Mary. D. Shahid, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Leslie S. Riley and James D. Myrick, both of Charleston, for
  Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: This
  is an appeal of an Administrative Law Court (ALC) order affirming a decision of
  the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC),
  Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource Management (OCRM), denying a dock permit
  to Appellant, Stephen Vaughn.Â  Vaughn argues the ALC erred in finding his
  property (the Lot) was not waterfront property and in refusing to allow
  modification of the subdivisionâ€™s dock master plan to include a dock corridor
  for the Lot.Â  Vaughn also claims the denial of a dock permit violated his
  constitutional rights to Equal Protection under the laws of South Carolina. Â We
  affirm[1]. Â 
FACTS
Vaughn entered into a contract to purchase
  the Lot on Rivershore Drive in the Beresford Creek Subdivision (the
  Subdivision) on Daniel Island.[2]Â 
  The Lot was not indicated on the dock master plan as having an approved dock
  corridor.Â  Vaughn filed an application with OCRM to obtain a permit to build a
  private dock on the Lot.Â  The proposed dock consisted of a 4 foot by 620 foot
  walkway with handrails leading to a 20 foot by 20 foot fixed pierhead with a
  roof and handrails. Â The proposed dock included an attached 10 foot by 20 foot
  floating dock and a 12 foot by 20 foot six-pile boatlift.Â   
Vaughn
  requested a meeting with OCRM staff through his elected representative, Shirley
  Hinson.Â  OCRM Deputy Commissioner Chris Brooks and Permitting Director Richard
  Chinnis met with Vaughn in October 2004 to discuss the pending dock permit.Â 
 
In the
  beginning of November 2004, OCRM denied Vaughnâ€™s permit application on the
  ground the Lot was not waterfront property as defined by OCRM regulations.Â  First,
  OCRM found the Lotâ€™s â€œprojected property lines d[id] not intersect with the
  creek [within] 1000â€™ as requiredâ€ by OCRM regulations. Â Second, OCRM found the Lot did not â€œpossess a dock corridor on [an OCRM] approvedâ€ dock master plan for the
  Subdivision.Â   
Vaughn
  filed a request for a contested case with the ALC.Â  The Beresford Creek
  Homeownerâ€™s Association (Association) moved to intervene as a party to the
  contested case, and the ALC granted the Associationâ€™s motion.Â  A hearing was
  held in August 2005.Â  The ALC affirmed OCRMâ€™s decision denying a dock permit to
  Vaughn, finding the Lot was not waterfront property as defined by regulations.Â 
 
On November
  4, 2005, Vaughn commenced an appeal of OCRMâ€™s denial of the dock permit to the
  Coastal Zone Management Appellate Panel (the Panel).Â  Vaughn averred the ALC
  erred in finding the Lot was not waterfront property and by refusing to allow
  modification of the dock master plan to include a dock corridor for the Lot. Vaughn also claimed the denial of his permit violated his constitutional rights to
  Equal Protection under the laws of South Carolina. Â During the pendency of the
  appeal, Act 387 (the Act) was signed into law[3] which substantively amended DHECâ€™s administrative and permitting procedures,
  including amendments to the procedure of appeal from the ALC.[4]Â  Pursuant to the Act, Vaughn filed
  and served his notice of appeal with this court on July 3, 2006.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In contested permitting
  cases, the ALC serves as the finder of fact.Â  Brown v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health
    & Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 520, 560 S.E.2d 410, 417 (2002).Â  On
  appeal, this court may not substitute its judgment for that of an agency on
  questions of fact when those facts are supported by substantial evidence.Â  Dorman
    v. Dept. of Health & Envtl. Control, 350 S.C. 159, 565 S.E.2d 119 (Ct.
  App. 2002); See Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 380, 527
  S.E.2d 742, 756 (1999).Â  In
  determining whether the ALCâ€™s decision was supported by substantial evidence,
  this court need only find, looking at the entire record on appeal, evidence
  from which reasonable minds could reach the same conclusion that the
  administrative agency reached.Â  DuRant v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl.
    Control, 361 S.C. 416, 420, 604 S.E.2d 704, 706 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The mere
  possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not
  prevent a finding from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Id. at 420, 604 S.E.2d at 707. 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS  
I.  Waterfront Property
Vaughn contends the ALC erred in finding the Lot was not waterfront property.Â  Vaughn first asserts
  the Lot meets the regulatory requirements of waterfront property, and
  alternatively, he argues OCRM and the ALC improperly used the regulatory
  definition of waterfront property in denying his dock permit.Â  We disagree.
 
The regulatory
  definition of waterfront property, as found in Regulation 30-1(D)(52) of the
  South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006), provides:  

	For
  purposes of these regulations, waterfront property will generally be defined as
  upland sites where a straight-line extension of both, generally shore
  perpendicular, upland property lines reaches a navigable watercourse within
  1000â€™ of the marsh critical line.Â  Waterfront property may also be identified
  via an approved dock master plan where designated corridors differing from
  upland property line extensions are delineated.

In this case, the ALC found
  the Lot did not comport to either of the two definitions of waterfront property
  contained in the regulations.Â   
A.  Straight-Line
  Extension of the Lotâ€™s Property Lines
The
  ALC found the straight-line extensions of both of the Lotâ€™s generally shore perpendicular,
  upland property lines do not reach Beresford Creek or any other navigable
  waterway within 1000 feet of the Lotâ€™s marsh critical line.Â  Vaughn argues the
  testimony of his civil engineer, Greg Jones, demonstrates how an extension of
  the upland property boundaries of the Lot satisfies the 1000 feet requirement
  contained in the definition. However, as noted by the ALC, Jones did not extend
  the upland property lines of the Lot, as required by the regulatory definition,
  to reach his conclusion.[5] Â The ALC explained Jones â€œextended the eastern shore-perpendicular, upland
  property line by creating an angle at the critical line and beginning a new
  line towards Beresford Creek, instead of simply extending the property boundary
  in a straight line.â€Â  For the second extension, Jones â€œextended a segment of
  the [OCRM] critical line towards Beresford Creek, rather than extending the
  other shore perpendicular upland property line of [the] [L]otâ€™s western
  property.â€Â  We find substantial evidence to support the ALCâ€™s determination the
  Lot was not waterfront property according to the first definition of
  waterfront property provided in the regulations.Â  Accordingly, we find no error
  in the ALCâ€™s determination.Â   
Regardless
  of whether the Lotâ€™s straight-line extensions met the required length, Vaughn
  asserts OCRM and the ALC erred in using the regulatory definition of waterfront
  property for the purpose of establishing criteria for the issuance or denial of
  a permit application.Â  Vaughn claims the definition of waterfront property
  provided in Regulation 30-1(D)(52) should have been used only for the purposes
  of providing guidance in the interpretation of other regulations.Â  Vaughn
  suggests that the permit application should have been considered in the context
  of South Carolina Code Regulation 30-12, specifically Regulation
  30-12(A)(1)(e).[6]Â 
  Regulation 30-12 sets forth specific project standards for tidelands and
  coastal waters.Â  Regulation 30-12(A)(1), specified by Vaughn, lists the
  standards for the construction of docks and piers.Â   
We note
  OCRM and the ALC did not err in using Regulation 30-1(D)(52) to determine the
  Lot was not waterfront property.Â  The South Carolina Coastal Zone Management
  Act was passed to protect and enhance the Stateâ€™s coastal resources.Â  S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§Â§ 48-39-10 to 360 (Supp. 2006); S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 30-1 (Supp. 2006).Â  The
  Lot is located in a â€œcritical areaâ€ within the South Carolina coastal zone.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 30-1(D)(14) (Supp. 2006) (defining â€œcritical areasâ€ as
  â€œ(1) coastal waters, (2) tidelands, (3) beach/dune systems and (4) beachesâ€).Â 
  Therefore, one must apply for a dock permit when seeking to construct a dock.Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 30-2 (B) (Supp. 2006) (requiring â€œany person wishing to
  alter a critical area [to] receive a permitâ€).Â  The regulations promulgated
  pursuant to the South Carolina Coastal Zone Management Act cloak OCRM with authority
  to carry out South Carolinaâ€™s coastal zone policies, including the power to
  issue permits for docks and piers.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 30-10(A)(1) (Supp.
  2006); S.C. Code Ann. Â§48-39-130 (Supp. 2006). Â The first general consideration
  OCRM is required to weigh in determining whether to issue a dock permit, or any
  other â€œcritical areaâ€ permit, is â€œ[t]he extent to which the activity requires a
  waterfront location or is economically enhanced by its proximity to water.â€Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 30-11(B)(1) (Supp. 2006).Â  The construction and use of a
  dock are clearly activities that require a waterfront location.Â  See, e.g.,
  S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 30-12(A)(1) (Supp. 2006) (describing a dock as a
  â€œstructure built over and/or floating on water . . . generally used for the
  mooring of boatsâ€).Â  Therefore, as the ALC noted:  

	[W]hile
  Regulation 30-1(D)(52) is a purely definitional section, not a substantive dock
  permitting regulation, the definition of â€˜waterfront propertyâ€™ provided in that
  section is important for determining whether a proposed dock project is located
  in a â€˜waterfront locationâ€™ and thus can satisfy the first general consideration
  for evaluating critical area activities under the Coastal Zone Management Act
  and OCRMâ€™s regulations. 

Accordingly, OCRM
  and the ALC properly considered Regulation 30-1(D)(52) to determine the Lot was not a waterfront property.
 
B.  Identification on
  a Dock Master Plan
The ALC also found
  the Lot was not identified on a dock master plan for the Subdivision, such as to
  satisfy the second definition of waterfront property.Â  The ALC acknowledged Vaughnâ€™s
  efforts to have the dock master plan amended to include a dock corridor for the
  Lot, but concluded the Lot was not identified as waterfront property with a
  dock corridor on the most current version of the dock master plan.Â   
Vaughn again
  asserts OCRM and the ALC erred in using the regulatory definition of waterfront
  property.Â  Vaughn contends nothing in the regulations mandates a denial of a
  dock permit if a lot does not have an established dock corridor on an approved
  dock master plan.Â  Vaughn suggests the regulations only require a dock master plan
  be used as a â€œframeworkâ€ for future permitting decisions.Â  Thus, Vaughn asserts
  it was unlawful regulation and an error of law for OCRM and the ALC to base
  their denial on the fact the Lot was not indicated in the dock master plan.
 
As discussed above, OCRMâ€™s and the ALCâ€™s reliance on the definition of waterfront property and the
  adherence to the requirements contained in the definitions were proper.Â  Further,
  we find substantial evidence to support the ALCâ€™s determination that the Lot was not waterfront property according to the second definition of waterfront property
  provided in the regulations.Â  Accordingly, we find no error in the ALCâ€™s
  determination.
II.  Modification
Vaughn also claims
  the ALC erred in not allowing the dock master plan to be modified.Â  Vaughn
  argues modification of the dock master plan was proper based on new information
  regarding the Lot and the Subdivisionâ€™s restrictive covenants did not prevent a
  modification of the dock master plan, as asserted by the ALC. Â 
The ALC did not
  actually make the ruling which Vaughn raises to this court.Â  The ALC noted in
  its findings of fact that the Lot was subject to the terms and conditions of
  the Subdivisionâ€™s Declaration of Covenants, Conditions and Restrictions, but
  did so to illustrate the Lot was not indicated on the current version of the dock
  master plan.Â  Nowhere within its order does the ALC indicate that the dock
  master plan may not be modified in the future.Â  Accordingly, this issue is not
  preserved for our review, and we decline to address it.Â  In re Michael H., 360 S.C. 540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004) (holding that issues must be
  raised and ruled upon in the trial court to be preserved for appellate review); Ellie, Inc. v. Miccichi, 358 S.C. 78, 103, 594 S.E.2d 485, 498 (Ct. App.
  2004) (finding â€œwithout an initial ruling by the trial court, a reviewing court
  simply would not be able to evaluate whether the trial court committed errorâ€). 
 
III.  Equal Protection
Lastly, Vaughn
  contends his rights to Equal Protection were violated by the ALCâ€™s decision.Â 
  The gravamen of Vaughnâ€™s argument is that he is similarly situated to several
  other lot owners in the Subdivision who have obtained dock permits.Â  We
  disagree.Â   
Vaughn is in a
  different position than the other lot owners in the Subdivision because the Lot was never depicted on the dock master plan as showing a dock corridor.Â  The other lots
  in the neighborhood, which have obtained dock permits, are shown on the dock
  master plan as having a dock corridor.Â  Thus, we find Vaughn is not similarly
  situated to others in the Subdivision, and the ALCâ€™s order does not violate
  Vaughnâ€™s constitutional rights.Â   
CONCLUSION
We find substantial evidence to support the ALCâ€™s
  determination that the Lot was not waterfront property according to the
  definition of waterfront property provided in the regulations and thus, find no
  error in the ALCâ€™s determination.Â  Further, we find reliance on the regulatory
  definition of waterfront property in determining the Lot was not waterfront property
  was proper.Â  Next, we hold Vaughnâ€™s claim the ALC erred in not allowing the dock
  master plan to be modified is not preserved for our review.Â  Lastly, we hold
  Vaughnâ€™s constitutional rights were not violated by the ALCâ€™s decision.Â  Based
  on the foregoing, the final order of the ALC is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON and THOMAS, JJ., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur. 
 

[1] We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] After Vaughn filed this appeal, the Lot was sold to
  SDJ, LLC, an entity in which Vaughn is a principal.Â   
[3] The â€œeffective dateâ€ of the Act is July 1, 2006.Â  
 
[4] Prior to the enactment of the Act, the Panel had
  jurisdiction to review final decisions of the ALC.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610
  (2005) amended by Act 387 Â§5 (codified at S.C. Code Ann. Â§1-23-610 (Supp.
  2006)).Â  Under the Act, the court of appeals now has jurisdiction over appeals
  from final decisions of the ALC.Â  See Act 387 Â§Â§ 5, 15.Â Â  Section 57
  requires the Act to apply â€œto any actions pending on or after the effective
  date.â€Â  However, it also creates an exception to this general rule of
  applicability and mandates the former law continue to apply to â€œappeals of Department
  of Health and Environmental Control, Ocean and Coastal Resource Management and
  Environmental Quality Control permits that are before the Administrative Law
  Court on the effective date of this act and petitions for judicial review that
  are pending before the circuit court.â€Â  See Chem-Nuclear Syss., LLC v. South Carolina Bd. of Health and Envtl. Control, 374 S.C. 201, 206, 648 S.E.2d 601, 604 (2007).Â  Â Â 
[5] The ALC found the testimony of Jones was not
  credible.Â   
[6] Â Regulation 30-12(A)(1)(e) reads: 
 

	All
  applications for docks and piers should accurately illustrate the alignment of
  property boundaries with adjacent owners and show the distance of the proposed
  dock from such extended property boundaries. For the purpose of this section,
  the extension of these boundaries will be an extension of the high ground
  property line.Â  The Department may consider an alternative alignment if site
  specific characteristics warrant or in the case of dock master plans, when
  appropriate.

GOOLSBY,
  A.J.:Â  Lynn Wilson appeals the
  finding by the circuit court that she is not entitled to underinsured motorist
  (UIM) coverage.Â  We affirm.
Contracting DÃ©cors,
  Inc., a business owned by Wilsonâ€™s husband, obtained an automobile insurance
  policy from the respondent Peerless Insurance Company on January 7, 2000.Â  The
  policy covered eighteen motor vehicles, including a 1995 Ford Contour.Â 
  Although the policy listed Contracting DÃ©cors as the owner of the car, the
  parties stipulated at trial that Wilsonâ€™s husband actually owned it.
An
  UIM coverage endorsement contained within the policy states Peerless will pay,
  consistent with South Carolina UIM law, all sums the â€œinsuredâ€ may be legally
  entitled to recover.Â  The endorsement defines the term â€œinsuredâ€ as:

	
		
			1.  
			You.
		
		
			2. 
			If you are an individual, any 
			â€œfamily memberâ€.
		
		
			3. 
			Anyone else â€œoccupyingâ€ a 
			covered â€œautoâ€ or a temporary substitute for a covered â€œautoâ€. . . .
		
	

The policy defines a â€œcovered
  autoâ€ for purposes of UIM as â€œ[o]nly those â€˜autosâ€™ [the named insured]
  own[s].â€Â   
Nine
  months after Contracting DÃ©cors obtained the Peerless policy, Wilson was
  involved in an accident while driving the Ford Contour.Â  Because her damages
  exceeded the liability limits of the at-fault driverâ€™s policy, Wilson sued Peerless to obtain UIM benefits.Â  Wilson maintained she should be qualified as
  a Class II insured because the Peerless policy lists the Ford Contour as a
  â€œcovered auto.â€Â  Peerless, however, disagreed, arguing Contracting DÃ©cors did
  not own the insured vehicle and therefore could not give Wilson the permission
  necessary to make Wilson a Class II insured under the policy.
The
  trial court gave judgment to Peerless, finding the policy unambiguous and finding
  Wilson excluded from UIM coverage by the plain language of the policy.
We
  agree with the trial judge.
In
  order for underinsured motorist coverage to apply to a vehicle listed in the
  policy, the vehicle must first have been owned by the named insured,
  Contracting DÃ©cors.Â  Here, the parties stipulated Wilsonâ€™s husband owned the
  vehicle at issue, not Contracting DÃ©cors.Â  The fact that the policy listed the
  vehicle as an insured vehicle is of no moment since the named insured did not
  own the vehicle.Â  Wilson, then, was not driving a â€œcovered autoâ€ as defined by
  the policy at the time of the accident.[1]
We
  also agree with the trial judge that Wilson cannot be classified as a Class II
  insured under the policy.Â  Again, the owner of the vehicle, Wilsonâ€™s husband,
  was not the named insured under the policy.Â  Contracting DÃ©cor was the named
  insured; thus, the vehicle Wilson was driving at the time of the accident was
  not a vehicle to which the policy applied.Â  Because Wilson was not using a
  vehicle to which the policy applied, she cannot be deemed a Class II insured.[2]
AFFIRMED.
WILLIAMS,
  J. and BEATTY, A.J. concur.

[1]Â  See MGC Management of Charleston, Inc. v.
  Kinghorn Ins. Agency, 336 S.C. 542, 548-49, 520 S.E.2d 820, 823 (Ct. App.
  1999). (â€œThis court must enforce, not write,
  contracts of insurance and we must give policy language its plain, ordinary,
  and popular meaning. . . . [I]f the intention of the parties is
  clear, courts have no authority to torture the meaning of policy language to
  extend or defeat coverage that was never intended by the parties.â€).
[2]Â  See Floyd v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co., 367 S.C. 253, 257, 626 S.E.2d 6, 9 (2005) (â€œClass II insureds are those using the
  insured vehicle with permission of the named insured and a guest in the motor
  vehicle.â€).

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR
  RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2),
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Mario Benson, Respondent
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Petitioner
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-523
Submitted October 1, 2007 â€“ Filed November
  13, 2007
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Assistant Attorney General Lance S. Boozer and Assistant Deputy
  Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, both of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Assistant Appellate Defender Robert Pachak, of Columbia, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Mario Benson filed a petition for post-conviction relief (PCR). Â Granting
  Bensonâ€™s petition, the trial court ordered a new trial.Â  The State petitioned
  this court for certiorari.Â  The parties briefed the issues and after review, we
  reverse.[1]
FACTS
Benson
  pled guilty to two counts of trafficking crack cocaine and one count of
  possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine. Â After a plea hearing, the
  trial judge sentenced Benson to concurrent imprisonment terms of fifteen years
  on each trafficking charge and ten years on the possession charge. Â Benson did
  not appeal.Â   
Benson later filed
  this PCR action alleging, among other claims, that his counsel was ineffective
  in:Â  1) failing to properly investigate a search and seizure issue; and 2)
  failing to advise Benson of his right to challenge the search and seizure at a
  trial.Â   
At the plea
  hearing, Benson admitted telling his counsel one version of the underlying
  facts.Â  The judge questioned Benson about whether counsel explained potential
  defenses.Â  Plea counsel confirmed, stating:Â  â€œ[W]e discussed the exclusion of
  evidence and the possibilities there and discussed perhaps the legal searches
  and seizures.â€Â  Benson agreed, stating: Â â€œI recall we talked about search and
  seizure.â€ Â Benson then admitted he did not have a defense and knew of no reason
  why he should not be found guilty.Â  The judge explained Bensonâ€™s rights to him
  and the solicitor recited the facts.  
The
  recital indicated that following a traffic stop on February 3, 1999, Benson
  consented to a vehicle search resulting in the discovery of crack cocaine.Â  The
  solicitor also stated that on June 9, 2000, the police stopped Benson after
  receiving information from a confidential informant that Benson was
  transporting drugs. Â Benson gave the officers permission to search his vehicle
  and person. Â When nothing was located, Benson allowed the officers to search
  his residence and â€œbasically told [the officers] where the drugs were
  located.â€Â  Benson agreed with the facts as presented and pled guilty.  
At the PCR hearing,
  Benson argued plea counsel failed to investigate. Â Additionally, Benson provided
  a different version of the underlying facts.Â  Under this version, Bensonâ€™s first
  stop occurred as a result of his speeding.  
The officer found Benson had
  an outstanding arrest warrant and placed him in the back of the patrol car.Â  Benson
  then consented to a search of the car. Â The search turned up a film canister containing
  drugs.Â   
As
  to the second search, Benson testified he was stopped as a result of a
  confidential informantâ€™s tip. Â Benson allowed the officers to search his car
  and when they found nothing they searched Bensonâ€™s person and found a key. Â Using
  the key, the officers attempted to open four different apartments.Â  The key fit
  the door to Bensonâ€™s girlfriendâ€™s apartment.Â  Benson stated the officers found
  the drugs in her apartment only after interrogating Benson and threatening to
  arrest his girlfriend and take his child. Â Benson admitted to ownership of the
  drugs.Â   
Benson alleged he
  told his plea counsel this version of the facts and argued counsel was
  ineffective for failing to investigate and failing to move for suppression of
  the drugs and Bensonâ€™s confession.Â  Benson averred his counsel never told him
  of his right to have a suppression hearing and if he had known he would not
  have pled guilty. Â When questioned regarding his admittance of the facts as
  presented at the plea hearing he stated:Â  â€œWell, I didnâ€™t know I was violated â€“
  my Constitutional rights were violated.Â  I was ignorant of the law and I didnâ€™t
  know and I was thinking I was going to do five years of a fifteen year
  sentence.â€Â   
Plea
  counsel testified at the PCR hearing stating the facts as recited at the plea hearing
  were as described to him by Benson and consistent with the incident reports.Â  Also,
  counsel testified that if Benson had wanted to go to trial, counsel would have
  filed a motion to suppress.Â Â Â   
The
  PCR court found trial counsel ineffective for failure to investigate and
  properly advise Benson that a motion to exclude would have been successful
  based on: Â 1) an unlawful detention by the officers after a routine traffic
  stop; and 2) an illegal warrantless search.Â  The court also found the State
  offered no evidence on the legality of the search other than the testimony of
  the plea counsel. Â The court thus granted PCR and ordered a new trial.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The appellate court gives great deference to the post-conviction 
relief courtâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law.Â  Dempsey v. State, 363
  S.C. 365, 368, 610 S.E.2d 812, 814 (2005). Â On review, a PCR judgeâ€™s findings
  will be upheld if there is any evidence of probative value sufficient to
  support them. Â Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 119, 386 S.E.2d 624, 626
  (1989).Â  The Court will not uphold the findings when there is no probative
  evidence to support them.Â  Holland v. State, 322 S.C. 111, 113, 470
  S.E.2d 378, 379 (1996).Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
The State contends
  the PCR court erred in finding there was probative evidence to support Bensonâ€™s
  claims that plea counsel was ineffective and that Benson should receive a new
  trial.Â  We agree.Â   
When
  alleging ineffective assistance of counsel after a guilty plea, an applicant in
  a PCR action must show:Â  1) counselâ€™s representation fell below an objective
  standard of reasonableness; and 2) but for counselâ€™s unprofessional errors,
  there is a reasonable probability the applicant would not have pled guilty but
  would have insisted upon going to trial.Â  Jordan v. State, 297
  S.C. 52, 54, 374 S.E.2d 683, 684 (1988).Â  The burden is on the applicant in a
  post-conviction proceeding to prove the allegations in his application.Â  Butler v. State, 286 S.C. 441, 442, 334 S.E.2d 813, 814 (1985).Â  
 
The
  PCR court essentially found plea counsel ineffective for failure to investigate
  and failure to request a suppression hearing based on the applicantâ€™s testimony
  at the PCR hearing.[2]Â 
  We conclude the focus must be on whether the plea counsel was ineffective based
    on the knowledge he had at the time of the plea.Â  See Harres v.
      Leeke, 282 S.C. 131, 133, 318 S.E.2d 360, 361 (1984) (review of a PCR
  action arising from a guilty plea requires an examination of the records of
  both the plea proceeding and the PCR hearing).
The
  record does not contain probative evidence to support the finding that plea counsel
  was ineffective in failing to investigate and file a motion to suppress based
  on the facts evident at the time of the plea hearing.Â  Benson admitted to the
  Stateâ€™s version of the facts at the plea hearing.Â  These facts were consistent
  with the incident reports and plea counselâ€™s PCR testimony recollecting his
  knowledge at the time of the plea hearing. Â The routine nature of a plea
  hearing is not an invitation to answer queries untruthfully.Â  Wolfe v. State, 326
  S.C. 158, 164-65, 485 S.E.2d 367, 370-71 (1997).Â  Furthermore, counsel
  error is generally cured by an applicantâ€™s acknowledgements at a plea hearing.Â  See id. (finding any possible error by trial counsel cured by
  applicantâ€™s acknowledgements at the plea hearing).Â  Here, because Benson acknowledged at the plea hearing
  that the facts were as recited by the solicitor, there was no need for counsel
  to investigate or move to suppress the evidence.Â  Ergo, we find no ineffective
  representation of counsel.Â Â   
Moreover,
  we find that plea counselâ€™s negotiations on Bensonâ€™s behalf proved advantageous.Â 
  The plea court accepted the negotiated plea of fifteen years imprisonment for
  the trafficking offenses and ten years on the possession with intent to
  distribute offense, all to run concurrently.Â  These offenses carry maximum
  terms that could have resulted in sentences requiring Benson to serve a much
  longer prison term.Â  See Bright
    v. State, 365 S.C. 355, 359-60, 618
  S.E.2d 296, 298 (2005) (considering trial counselâ€™s plea negotiation
  efforts and results in PCR action alleging ineffective assistance of counsel).
Accordingly,
  the order granting PCR and a new trial is
REVERSED.
HEARN,
  C.J., STILWELL, J., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â We note the ultimate issues regarding the legality of the stops,
  searches, and admissibility of the evidence were not proper for consideration
  on post-conviction relief.Â  See Simmons v. State, 264 S.C. 417,
  422-23, 215 S.E.2d 883, 885 (1975) (finding post-conviction relief action not
  proper forum to determine sufficiency of evidence issue).Â

PER CURIAM:Â  In this criminal case, we
  affirm the trial courtâ€™s determination that Manley Thompson (Thompson)
  knowingly and intelligently waived his right to counsel.Â   
FACTS
Lancaster County police officers observed Thompson
  riding a dirt bike and stopped him because the dirt bike was not street legal.Â 
  The officers asked Thompson for his identification.Â  Thompson refused and
  became abusive.Â  The officers informed Thompson he was under arrest for vehicle
  violation and disorderly conduct.Â   
While attempting to handcuff Thompson, Thompson head butted one of
  the officers.Â  The injured officer sustained a black eye and a bloody lip.Â  The
  search incident to the arrest revealed a large quantity of marijuana along with
  scales on Thompsonâ€™s person.Â  The officers also learned the dirt bike was
  stolen.Â   
Thompson was indicted for receiving stolen goods over $1,000 but
  less than $5,000, resisting arrest, and possession with intent to distribute
  marijuana.Â  Thompson entered guilty pleas to all three charges and received
  five years imprisonment, to run concurrently.Â   
On appeal, Thompson argues he did not knowingly and intelligently
  waive his right to counsel.Â  Thompson also contends his guilty plea was not
  freely, intelligently, and voluntarily given.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, this Court reviews errors of law only.Â  State
  v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  An appellate court
  is bound by the trial judgeâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly
  erroneous.Â  Id.  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Thompson initially argues he did not knowingly and intelligently
  waive his right to counsel.Â  It is well established that a criminal defendant
  may waive his constitutional right to counsel and proceed pro se.Â  Dearybury
    v. State, 367 S.C. 34, 39, 625 S.E.2d 212, 215 (2006).Â Â  Even if a â€œdefendantâ€™s
  decision to proceed pro se may be to the defendantâ€™s own detriment, it must be
  honored . . . .â€Â  Id.Â  However, to establish a valid wavier of counsel,
  the accused must be informed of the right to counsel and adequately warned of
  the dangers of self-representation.Â  Prince v. State, 301 S.C. 422,
  423-24, 392 S.E.2d 462, 463 (1990).
The
  following testimony confirms the trial judge advised Thompson of his right to
  counsel and warned him of the dangers of self-representation.  

	The Court: You understand that you have a right to an attorney to
  represent you in regards to these three charges.
	The Defendant: Yes, sir.
	The Court: You understand if you cannot afford an attorney the
  State would be required to appoint an attorney to represent you at no cost to
  you.
	The Defendant: Yes, sir.
	The Court: You understand that an attorney could be of benefit to
  you by knowing things about the case or about you or about the law that could
  benefit you.Â  You understand that.
	The Defendant: Yes, sir.
	The Court: You understand that since youâ€™re not an attorney there
  is a danger in your representing yourself.
	The Defendant: Yes, sir.
	The Court: Knowing those things do you wish to have an attorney or
  proceed without one?
	The Defendant: Wish to proceed without one.
	The Court: I find Mr. Thompson has freely, voluntarily, knowingly,
  and intelligently, understanding his right to counsel, benefits of counsel and
  the danger of self-representation waiving his right to counsel.Â  

The
  foregoing demonstrates the trial judge informed Thompson of his constitutional
  right to counsel and advised Thompson of the dangers of self-representation.
 
Next, Thompson argues his guilty plea was not freely, intelligently, and
  voluntarily given.Â  However, Thompson failed to raise the issue regarding the
  guilty plea at the trial court level.Â  The proper venue in such a case is for
  Thompson to file for post conviction relief.Â  In Interest of Antonio H.,
  324 S.C. 120, 122, 477 S.E.2d 713, 714 (1996) (â€œThe proper avenue in which to
  challenge a guilty plea which is not objected to at the time of its entry is
  through post conviction relief.â€).
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the trial courtâ€™s decision is  
AFFIRMED.[1] 
ANDERSON,
  and WILLIAMS, JJ., A.J. Cureton concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: McSwain v. Little Pee Dee Farms
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Thomas C.
      McSwain, Respondent,
				v.
				Little Pee Dee
      Farms and Legion Insurance Company/South Carolina Property and Casualty
      Insurance Guaranty Association, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Dillon County
Â James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion 
No. 2007-UP-528  
Submitted October 1, 2007 â€“ Filed November
  13, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Frank R. Warder, Jr., of Charleston, for
  Appellants.
				E. Hood Temple, of Florence, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  In this workersâ€™ compensation action, Little Pee Dee Farms (Pee Dee) and Legion Insurance Company/South Carolina
  Property & Casualty Insurance Guaranty Association (collectively Appellants)
  appeal the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the finding of the South Carolina
  Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (Commission) of Thomas McSwainâ€™s (Claimant) applicable
  compensation rate.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Pee
  Dee is a general partnership in which
  Claimant is an equal, one-third partner, with Claimantâ€™s mother and father
  comprising the rest of the partnership.Â  In July 2001, Claimant suffered
  injuries to both of his heels in the course and scope of his employment.Â 
  Thereafter, Claimant had two surgeries on his injured heels, and Appellants
  commenced temporary total disability payments totaling $416.67 per week. 
 
In
  November 2004, Legion Insurance Company filed for bankruptcy and went into
  liquidation.Â  Pursuant to Section 38-31-40 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006),
  a statutorily created association was appointed to assume responsibility for
  Claimantâ€™s file.Â  Upon review of Claimantâ€™s federal and state income tax
  returns, Appellants filed a Form 21 Employerâ€™s Request for Hearing with the Commission,
  requesting an evaluation of Claimantâ€™s compensation rate.Â   
A
  hearing was held before the Single Commissioner to determine if the compensation
  rate should be maintained at its current level or be reduced; the Commissioner
  held the weekly compensation rate was to remain at $416.67.Â  Specifically, the
  Commissioner determined the Claimantâ€™s average weekly wage should not account
  for any losses or debts attributable to Claimantâ€™s partnership interest.Â  Appellants
  filed a timely Form 30 Application for Full Commission Appellate Panel Review, and
  the Appellate Panel affirmed the Single Commissioner, adopting the findings in
  full.Â  Â Â Â Â 
Following a timely appeal and hearing on the matter,
  the circuit court found the decision of the Appellate Panel to be supported by
  substantial evidence and affirmed the decision.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
The Administrative
  Procedures Act applies to appeals from decisions of the Commission.Â  Lark v.
    Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  In an
  appeal from the Appellate Panel, neither this Court nor the circuit court may
  substitute its judgment for that of the Appellate Panel in regards to the
  weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but it may reverse when the
  decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C.
  613, 617, 571 S.E.2d 92, 95 (Ct. App. 2002).
â€œAny review of the [Appellate
  Panelâ€™s] factual findings is governed by the substantial evidence standard.â€Â  Lockridge
    v. Santens of Am., Inc., 344 S.C. 511, 515, 544 S.E.2d 842, 844 (Ct. App.
  2001). â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence that, in viewing the record as a
  whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the same conclusion that the
  [Appellate Panel] reached.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œThe possibility of drawing two
  inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative
  agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence.â€ Â Lee v.
    Harborside CafÃ©, 350 S.C. 74, 78, 564 S.E.2d 354, 356 (Ct. App. 2002)
  (internal quotations and citations omitted). Â Accordingly, we limit review to
  deciding whether the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial
  evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  Corbin, 351 S.C. at
  617, 571 S.E.2d at 95.Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants
  contend the circuit court erred in affirming the Appellate Panel.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
 
Appellants
  have failed to show the findings of the Appellate Panel are unsupported by
  substantial evidence.Â  Claimant presented Dal Felkel, an accountant for
  fifty-four years, who testified he had personally prepared the tax forms of
  both Pee Dee and Claimant.Â  Upon direct examination, Felkel asserted Claimantâ€™s
  salary for the immediate four preceding quarters was $32,500.Â  The average
  weekly wage of an employee for workersâ€™ compensation purposes is defined as
  â€œthe earnings of the injured employee in the employment in which [they were]
  working at the time of the injury . . . [and] must be calculated by taking the
  total wages paid for the last four quarters immediately preceding the quarter
  in which the injury occurred . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-40 (Supp. 2006).Â 
  Using this computation method, Felkel declared Claimantâ€™s bi-weekly wage before
  taxes was $1,250.Â Â Â   
On
  cross-examination, Appellants questioned Felkel about the losses Pee Dee
  sustained during the tax years in question and also as to Claimantâ€™s
  characterizations of the income he received from Pee Dee on his tax forms.Â 
  However, this questioning did not dissuade Felkel of his opinion as to
  Claimantâ€™s compensation in the preceding four quarters, and on re-direct
  examination, Felkel specifically asserted that the $32,500 was received by
  Claimant â€œ[a]s a wage over and above his share of the profits or losses.â€Â  Felkel
  supported his assertions regarding the wage received by Claimant prior to the
  accident, and Appellants failed to present any expert testimony to challenge
  Felkelâ€™s assertions.Â  Appellants instead chose to rely solely upon the submission
  of Claimantâ€™s tax return.Â  Thus, the
  Appellate Panelâ€™s decision not to use Claimantâ€™s net taxable income as the
  basis of his compensation rate is supported by substantial evidence.
In
  support of their argument, Appellants argue this Court must follow Stephen
    v. Avins Construction Co. and determine Claimantâ€™s average weekly wage
  based upon net income. Â 324 S.C. 334, 347, 478 S.E.2d 74, 81 (Ct. App. 1996).Â 
  We disagree.Â   
In Stephen,
  this Court held that a claimantâ€™s compensation rate based on his earnings as a
  self-employed subcontractor should be based on his net taxable income, even
  though the subcontractor was charged workersâ€™ compensation premiums based on
  his gross earnings.Â  Id.Â  This Court, however, was careful to tailor its
  discussion and holding to the specific facts of the case.Â  Id.Â  Claimantâ€™s
  situation is factually distinguishable, and therefore, Stephen provides
  little guidance in determining what the appropriate compensation rate is for Claimant.
  Â Reviewing the evidence presented from both sides,
  the Appellate Panelâ€™s determination of Claimantâ€™s average weekly wage is
  clearly supported by substantial evidence and must, therefore, be
  affirmed.Â Â Â Â Â Â   
CONCLUSION
We
  find the circuit court did not err in affirming the Appellate Panel.Â  Because
  we find substantial evidence in the record to determine the Claimantâ€™s average
  weekly wage was $416.67 after taxes, the circuit courtâ€™s ruling is therefore
AFFIRMED.[1]
STILWELL, SHORT, and
  WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
