title: Adoptive Father and Adoptive Mother v. Child
text:
THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
  PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Adoptive Father
      and Adoptive Mother, Respondents,
				v.
				Child, a minor
      child under the age of fourteen years, Defendant,
				Birth Father
      and Birth Mother,[1] Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Aphrodite K. Konduros, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-529
Submitted November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  November 13, 2007Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				AdamÂ  Fisher, Jr., of Greenville, for
  Appellants.
				Raymond W. Godwin, of Greenville, for Respondents.
				Cheryl Truesdale, of Greenville, Guardian
				ad Litem.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: In
  this action for adoption, Birth Father and Birth Mother (collectively Birth
  Parents) appeal the family courtâ€™s decision that their consents to adoption
  were valid and withdrawing the adoption was improper.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Birth Parents were married and had a son (Child) born January 14,
  2004, in North Carolina.Â  The family lived in a two-bedroom apartment in Salisbury, North Carolina.Â  Birth Mother was diagnosed with obsessive
  compulsive disorder (OCD), and as a result of her illness, she struggled in
  raising Child. Â Two months after Child was born, Birth Mother began
  contemplating adoption.Â  In March 2005, she became more serious about the
  idea.Â  Birth Father agreed to the idea because he felt it was in Childâ€™s
  best interest based on Birth Motherâ€™s condition.Â  
Birth Mother sought a family to adopt Child who: (1) â€œknew Godâ€;
  (2) had no criminal background; and (3) already had a child so Child would have
  a sibling.Â  Birth Parents found Adoptive Father and Adoptive Mother (collectively Adoptive Parents),
  a married couple living in Simpsonville, South Carolina.Â  Adoptive Parents were
  married and had a daughter, born in 2001.Â   
On April 16, 2005, Birth Parents each signed a surrender of
  parental rights or consent to adoption (the Consent).Â  In part, the
  Consent provided, â€œThis consent and the accompanying surrender forfeits all
  rights and obligations which I may have to the adoptee.â€Â  Additionally, a letter dated April 15, 2005 (the Letter), addressed to Birth Parents was
  signed by both Adoptive Parents individually, as well as their attorney,
  stating Adoptive Parents have â€œagreed to at least three visits a year at a
  mutually agreeable location and time and date.Â  They have also agreed to send
  you pictures and letters at least once a month and also to provide you with a
  telephone number in order to maintain regular phone contact.â€Â Â  
Since the signing of the Consent, Child has lived with Adoptive
  Parents.Â  On the evening Birth Parents signed the Consent, they felt
  they had made a horrible mistake and regretted their decision.Â  
On April 18, 2005, Adoptive Parents
  filed a summons and complaint for adoption.Â  Birth Parents filed a
  motion to intervene in the adoption, to which Adoptive Parents consented.Â  Birth
  Parents then filed an answer and counterclaim, which they later amended, asking
  the family court to set aside the Consents and to return Child to their
  custody.Â  The family court held a hearing and issued a temporary order
  finding the withdrawal of Birth Motherâ€™s Consent was not in Childâ€™s best interest
  and the Consent appeared voluntary on its face.Â  Additionally, the court found
  Birth Father did not raise any issue as to his Consent and denied Birth
  Parentsâ€™ motion for visitation.Â  Further, the family court ordered the
  voluntariness of Birth Motherâ€™s Consent be adjudicated at the final hearing.Â  

Following the final hearing, the family
  court found Birth Parents had not proved the Consents were invalid or that they
  were subject to any fraud, coercion, duress, or lack of voluntariness.Â  Further,
  the family court determined it was in Childâ€™s best interest to remain with
  Adoptive Parents.Â  The family court also found because Birth Parents had
  not paid any child support for a period exceeding six months, their parental
  rights were terminated.Â  
Birth Parents filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP,
  motion for reconsideration asserting numerous points of error by the family
  court.Â  The family court denied the motion and issued an amended final
  order correcting what it termed some â€œminor clerical mistakes.â€Â  This appeal
  follows.
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
On
  appeal from a family court order, this Court has authority to correct errors of
  law and find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 473, 415 S.E.2d 812, 814 (1992).Â  When reviewing decisions
  of the
  family court, we note that the family court is in a superior position to judge
  the witnessesâ€™ demeanor and veracity and give its findings broad discretion.Â  
Scott v. Scott, 354
  S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003).Â  This degree of deference is
  especially true in cases involving the welfare and best interests of a minor
  child.Â  Ex
    parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 62, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006). Â When the evidence is conflicting and
  susceptible to different inferences, the family court has the duty of
  determining not only the law of the case, but the facts as well, because it had the benefit of observing the
  witnesses and determining how much credence to give each oneâ€™s testimony.Â  Anders v. Anders, 285 S.C. 512, 514, 331 S.E.2d 340, 341 (1985); see also Woodall
    v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154,
  157 (1996) (holding where
  evidence is disputed, the appellate court may adhere to the family courtâ€™s
  findings).Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Misrepresentations
Birth
  Parents argue the family court erred in failing to find misrepresentations by
  Adoptive Parents nullified the adoption. Â We disagree.
Adoption terminates all rights of a birth parent over
  the adopted child. McLaughlin v. Strickland, 279 S.C. 513, 517, 309
  S.E.2d 787, 790 (Ct. App. 1983).Â  â€œThis
  includes termination of visitation rights.â€Â  Id. Â If an adoption is to
  be based on consent, the birth parent must agree to relinquish all rights to
  the child. Â Id.Â  A qualified consent which attempts to reserve rights in
  the birth parent does not sufficiently constitute consent to adoption required
  by law. Â Â Id.

	Withdrawal of any consent or relinquishment is not
  permitted except by order of the court after notice and opportunity to be heard
  is given to all persons concerned, and except when the court finds that the
  withdrawal is in the best interests of the child and that the consent or
  relinquishment was not given voluntarily or was obtained under duress or
  through coercion.Â  Any person attempting to withdraw consent or relinquishment
  shall file the reasons for withdrawal with the family court. Â The entry of the
  final decree of adoption renders any consent or relinquishment irrevocable.
	

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1720 (Supp. 2006).
South Carolina jurisprudence â€œdisallows the
  revocation of consent voluntarily given particularly where the adoptive parents
  have taken the child into their home in reliance upon the consent.â€ Â Ellison v. Camby, 269 S.C. 48, 51, 236
  S.E.2d 197, 198 (1977); see also Driggers v. Jolley, 219 S.C. 31, 37, 64 S.E.2d
  19, 22 (1951) (recognizing the right to revoke consent is not absolute and
  noting the trend is in favor of enforcing consent when voluntarily given and
  accompanied by reliance on the part of the adoptive parents). Â â€œThe South Carolina statutory adoption scheme leaves the question of withdrawal in the judgeâ€™s
  discretion, assuming the Consent to Adopt is on file.â€Â  Ellison, 269 S.C. at 51, 236 S.E.2d
  at 198.
â€œ[A] final decree of adoption may be vacated or set
  aside because of fraud in the procurement of the judgment.â€ Â Lowe v. Clayton, 264 S.C. 75, 80, 212
  S.E.2d 582, 584 (1975).Â  Parents who sign a consent to adoption waive their right to
  notice or appearance at the proceeding. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1700(A)(9)
  (Supp. 2006). Â Thus, if a parentâ€™s consent is fraudulently obtained, such fraud
  essentially acts to induce the parent not to present a case.Â  Hagy v. Pruitt, 339 S.C. 425, 431-32, 529 S.E.2d 714, 717-18 (2000).Â  Accordingly,
  the allegation that consent was fraudulently obtained sufficiently alleges extrinsic
  fraud.Â  Id.Â  Generally, fraud must be proved by clear and convincing
  evidence. Â Id.

	A party asserting a claim for fraud in the inducement
  to enter into a contract must establish (1) a representation, (2) its falsity,
  (3) its materiality, (4) knowledge of its falsity or reckless disregard of its
  truth or falsity, (5) intent that the representation be acted upon, (6) the
  hearerâ€™s ignorance of its falsity, (7) the hearerâ€™s reliance on its truth, (8)
  the hearerâ€™s right to rely thereon, and (9) the hearerâ€™s consequent and
  proximate injury.

Brown
  v. Stewart, 348 S.C. 33, 41, 557 S.E.2d 676, 680 (Ct. App. 2001) (internal
  quotations and citations omitted).
Birth
  Parents assert Adoptive Parentsâ€™ failure to honor the visitation and telephone
  calls as provided by the Letter were misrepresentations.Â  Birth Mother
  testified she and Birth Father had not received visitation or photographs, and
  she believed they would not receive them.Â  Additionally, Birth Mother
  testified the visitation, photographs, and phone calls were all an integral
  part of the agreement.Â  However, on cross-examination, she admitted Adoptive
  Parents had not yet had the chance to comply with the visitation.Â  

Dr.
  Blake Allen Spence, who is certified to take consent and relinquishments for
  adoptions and to conduct home studies, took the Birth Parentsâ€™ Consents.Â  He
  testified Adoptive Parents and Birth Parents discussed visitation after the
  Consents were signed.Â  Further, he testified Adoptive Parents did not sign the
  Letter until after the Consents were signed.Â   
By Birth Motherâ€™s
  own testimony, Adoptive Parents have not yet had a chance to comply with the
  visitation.Â  The evidence in the record supports the family courtâ€™s finding
  that the Consents were not
  subject to fraud.[2] Accordingly, the family court did not err in failing
  to allow Birth Parents to withdraw their Consents.
Additionally,
  Birth Parents contend errors in Adoptive Parentsâ€™ complaint that were later
  amended at the hearing were also misrepresentations.Â  These errors include the statements
  that Adoptive Parents had an adopted child when in actuality the child was
  their birth child, as well as Child did not own property in the state of Texas,
  when it should have stated South Carolina.Â  At the final hearing, Adoptive
  Parents sought to amend the complaint to correct these errors.Â  Birth Parents
  objected and contended the mistakes in the complaint raised issues of
  credibility.Â  However, the family court ruled Adoptive Parents could amend the
  complaint because the reference to Texas was a scrivenerâ€™s error, and Adoptive
  Parents could testify the child was their biological child.Â   
If
  Birth Parents took issue with the amending of the complaint, they should have
  appealed that ruling, not tried to label these errors as misrepresentations.[3]Â 
  Further, they do not explain how these seemingly minor errors prejudiced them,
  and we can discern no prejudice.Â  Accordingly, we find the family court did not
  err in failing to find the Consents should be revoked because of
  misrepresentations or fraud.
II.Â  Fitness Issues
Birth Parents argue
  the family court erred because issues exist regarding the fitness of Adoptive
  Parents.Â  We disagree.
Birth Parents
  provide a litany of alleged medical conditions by Adoptive Mother.Â  They assert
  Adoptive Mother takes the following medications: Toamax, Migrinal, and Botox
  injections for migraines; Neurontin for restless leg syndrome; Cymbalta for
  depression; Welbutrin for depression and anxiety; Lexapro for adjustment
  disorder; Prevacid for gastrointestinal reflux disease; and Zrytec for an
  allergic condition.Â  Birth Parents further contend Adoptive Mother has a
  history of fibromyalgia, bulimia, back aches, and has chronic situations with
  depression.Â  Additionally, Birth Parents allege Adoptive Mother, a doctor, prescribed
  medications and refills for herself.Â   
Birth
  Parents cite Murray v. Murray, 271 S.C. 62, 244 S.E.2d 538 (1978), and Peeples v. Peeples, 270 S.C. 116, 241 S.E.2d 159 (1978), in support of
  their argument that the fitness issues are sufficient for Adoptive Parents to
  lose custody of Child.Â  Both of these cases involve birth parents losing
  custody of their children to the other birth parent or a grandparent due to
  mental and emotional instability, and thus, greatly differ from the current
  situation.Â  Further, Adoptive Mother is on the medications pursuant to doctorâ€™s
  orders to correct medical problems.Â  Many of these problems would not have any
  bearing on Adoptive Motherâ€™s fitness as a parent.Â  Additionally, Adoptive
  Mother is on the medications to treat her problems for depression and anxiety.Â 
  In regards to the allegations she wrote her own prescriptions, Adoptive Mother
  also testified she only extended prescriptions for which she already had a
  prescription, which did not violate any ethical rules, and she would never
  write a new prescription for herself.Â   
Further,
  Birth Parents argue because Adoptive Father did not testify, there is a
  presumption his testimony would be adverse to his position, citing to McCowan v. Southerland.Â  253 S.C. 9, 168 S.E.2d 573 (1969).Â  In McCowan,
  the South Carolina Supreme Court found when â€œfacts
  were peculiarly within [a defendantâ€™s] knowledgeâ€ and â€œ[h]e did not testify . .
  . his unexplained failure to do so raises an inference that his testimony, if
  it had been submitted, would have been unfavorable to his position.â€Â  Id. at 12, 168 S.E.2d at 574.Â  Here, Father was not the only party that could
  testify he was a fit parent.Â  Adoptive Mother, the guardian ad litem (GAL), Cheryl
  Truesdale, a clinical psychologist, Dr. Joanne Armstrong, and
  another witness, Stacy Garrett, all testified Adoptive
  Father was a fit parent.Â   
Additionally, Birth Parents contend at the time of the
  hearing, Adoptive Parents lived in a two-bedroom apartment with Child sharing a
  room with Adoptive Parentsâ€™ daughter.Â  Although Adoptive Parents did
  temporarily live in a two-bedroom apartment, it was only for a few months while
  construction was being completed on their five bedroom home, in which Child has
  his own bedroom, as well as a playroom and a backyard. Â Accordingly, the family
  court did not err in finding Adoptive Parents to be fit parents.
III.Â  Best Interest of the
  Child
Birth Parents
  maintain it is in the best interest of Child that they raise him.Â  We disagree.
â€œIn adoption cases the child is the proper focus for
  the determination.â€Â  Phillips v. Baker, 284 S.C. 134, 136, 325
  S.E.2d 533, 535 (1985).Â  Section 20-7-1720 authorizes the family court to grant
  a withdrawal of consent to adoption only if â€œthe court finds that the
  withdrawal is in the best interests of the child . . . .â€  
At
  the time Child was placed with Adoptive Parents, his weight was at the twenty-fifth
  percentile on weight charts for his age, making him severely underweight.Â  Further,
  he suffered from a chronic buildup of fluid on his left eardrum, causing
  partial deafness.Â  Child also never wore shoes while he lived with Birth
  Parents and had an abnormality called metatarsus abductus, causing both feet to
  turn inward.Â  Additionally, Child had developmental delays in his speech and
  fine motor skills.Â   
Childâ€™s
  physical condition has shown improvement since he has been living with Adoptive
  Parents.Â  After several months, his weight increased to the seventy-fifth
  percentile.Â  Further, Adoptive Parents have enrolled him in both speech and
  occupational therapy.Â  Additionally, Adoptive Parents had Child examined by an
  ear, nose, and throat specialist, who placed tubes in Childâ€™s ears to alleviate
  fluid causing Child pain and hearing loss.Â  Child has also received medical
  assistance for his metatarsus abductus and can now wear shoes and bear his own
  weight allowing his walking to significantly improve.Â   
Further,
  Adoptive Mother is a pediatrician who currently stays at home with Child.Â  Dr.
  Armstrong testified Child had a strong bond with Adoptive Parents.Â  The GAL
  testified she had concerns with Child being returned to Birth Parents.Â 
  Specifically, when she went to Birth Parentsâ€™ apartment for a planned visit,
  they had very little food in the home.Â  Further, Birth Mother testified she
  intended to home school Child, which concerned the GAL because she found Child
  lacked socialization at the time he was placed with Adoptive Parents and therefore,
  thought home schooling would be detrimental to him.Â  Accordingly, the GAL
  believed it was in Childâ€™s best interest to remain with Adoptive Parents.Â  From a review of the record,
  the evidence supports the family courtâ€™s decision that revoking the Consents
  was not in Childâ€™s best interest, and thus, we find no error in the decision.
 
CONCLUSION
We find the family
  court did not err in finding the Consents should not be revoked and the
  adoption should not be withdrawn because of misrepresentations or fraud.Â 
  Further, we find the Adoptive Parents are fit parents and not withdrawing the
  adoption is in Childâ€™s best interest.Â  Accordingly, the order of the family
  court is
AFFIRMED.[4]
ANDERSON,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] This case is sealed, thus the partiesâ€™ names have
  been changed.  
[2] Further, even if Birth Parents met their burden of proving
  the Consents were given as a result of fraud, they must also prove the
  withdrawal of their Consents was in Childâ€™s best interest.Â  See Â§
  20-7-1720.Â  As discussed in more detail in the third issue, we find the
  withdrawal of Birth Parentsâ€™ consent is not in the best interest of Child.Â  
 
[3] Further, Rule 15, SCRCP,
  provides, â€œA party may amend his pleading once
  as a matter of course at any time before or within 30 days after a responsive
  pleading is served or, if the pleading is one to which no responsive pleading
  is required and the action has not been placed upon the trial roster, he may so
  amend it at any time within 30 days after it is served. Â Otherwise a party may
  amend his pleading only by leave of court or by written consent of the adverse
  party; and leave shall be freely given when justice so requires and does not
  prejudice any other party. A party shall plead in response to an amended
  pleading within the time remaining for response to the original pleading or
  within fifteen days after service of the named amended pleading, whichever
  period may be the longer, unless the court otherwise orders.â€
[4] We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Garrett v. Lister, Flynn, & Kelly, P.A.
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				John J.
      Garrett, Appellant
				v.
				Lister, Flynn,
      & Kelly, P.A., Toney Lister, and Brendan Delaney, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Roger L. Couch, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-530
Submitted November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  November 14, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				John J. Garrett, of Reidville, for Appellant.
				Mason A. Goldsmith, of Greenville, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: In
  this civil case, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s determination that John Garrett
  (Garrett) failed to follow the proper service of process requirements as set
  out in the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  We also conclude the trial
  court properly dismissed the case with prejudice.  
FACTS
On February 28, 2005, Garrett filed a complaint against the law
  firm of Lister, Flynn, & Kelly, P.A. (Law Firm), attorney Toney Lister
  (Lister), and attorney Brenda Delaney (Delaney) In his complaint, Garrett
  alleged numerous causes of action.Â  The acts which Garrett complained of
  occurred on March 15, 2002, nearly three years prior to filing the complaint.Â  
 
On June 10, 2005, Garrett personally attempted to serve Delaney at
  Delaneyâ€™s place of business.Â  However, Delaney was not present at that time.Â 
  On June 20, 2005, Garrett attempted to serve Law Firm by registered mail,
  return receipt requested.Â  The registered mail was not restricted to Law Firmâ€™s
  registered agent, and the registered agent did not sign for the delivery.Â  On
  June 21, 2005, by way of regular mail rather than certified Garrett, attempted
  to serve Lister.Â   
On July 8, 2005, the Respondents filed a Motion to Quash the
  Service of Process.Â  On July 25, 2005, Garrett filed his response to this
  motion.Â  Prior to filing his response, Garrett filed an amended complaint on
  July 11, 2005.Â  The trial court found Garrett had failed to properly serve the
  Respondents.Â  Garrett argued he was unable to effectuate service because he was
  disabled.Â  Garrett asked the trial court to grant him an extension so that he
  could properly serve the Respondents.Â  The trial court denied this request and dismissed
  the case with prejudice because the statute of limitations ran before Garrett
  filed his amended complaint, and Garrett did not perfect service of process on
  the Respondents before the statute of limitation ended.Â   
On appeal, Garrett makes the following nine arguments: (1) the
  trial court erred in finding service to Law Firm was not properly made; (2) the
  trial court erred in failing to conclude Delaney was properly served; (3) the
  trial court should have allowed Garrett an extension of time in which to serve
  the Respondents; (4) the trial court erred by ruling on the statute of
  limitations issue; (5) the trial court erred by dismissing the case with
  prejudice; (6) the trial court erred by failing to put into evidence a document
  Garrett provided; (7) the trial court, by requiring Garrett to stand during
  oral arguments, denied Garrett the opportunity to compete with opposing counsel
  on an equal basis; (8) Garrett was denied the opportunity to check out law
  books from the Spartanburg Library; and (9) the trial judge erred by failing to
  recuse himself.Â  We address each argument in turn.  
LAW/ANALYSIS
A. The trial
  court properly found Garrett did not serve Law Firm.
Garrettâ€™s
  first argument is the trial court improperly concluded that he failed to
  properly serve Law Firm.Â  We disagree.Â   
Garrett
  attempted service upon Law Firm by certified mail.Â  Rule 4(d)(8) of the South
  Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure provides that a partnership may be served â€œby registered or
  certified mail, return receipt requested and delivery restricted to the
    addressee.â€ (emphasis added).Â   
The Certificate of
  Service clearly shows Garrett failed to restrict delivery as required by Rule
  4.Â  Thus, the trial court properly concluded Garrett did not serve Law Firm.
 
B. The trial
  court correctly concluded Garrett improperly served Delaney.
Garrettâ€™s
  second argument is the trial court erred by not concluding he properly served
  Delaney.Â  We disagree.
Rule 4(c) of the South Carolina Rules of
  Civil Procedure states:
Service
  of summons may be made by the sheriff, his deputy, or by any other person not
  less than eighteen (18) years of age, not an attorney in or a party to the
  action.Â  Service of all other process shall be made by the sheriff or his
  deputy or any other duly constituted law enforcement officer or by any person
  designated by the court who is not less than eighteen (18) years of age and not
  an attorney in or a party to the action . . . .
he Certificate of
  Service states that Garrett personally attempted to serve Delaney at Delaneyâ€™s
  place of business.Â  Garrett is a party in the law suit against Delaney, thus he
  cannot effectuate service.Â  Therefore, the trial court properly concluded that
  Delaney was not served.Â   
C. The trial
  court properly ruled that Garrett was not entitled to an extension of time in
  which to serve the Respondents.
Garrettâ€™s
  third argument is the trial court should have granted an extension so that
  Garrett could properly serve the Respondents.Â  We disagree.  
Rule
  3(a) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure provides:  
A civil action is commenced when the summons and complaint are
  filed with clerk of court if: (1) the summons and complaint are served within
  the statute of limitations . . . . or (2) if not served within the statute of
  limitations, actual service must be accomplished no later than one hundred
  twenty days after filing.
In the present case, Garrett filed the complaint on February 28,
  2005. The acts which Garrett complained of occurred on March 15, 2002, nearly three
  years prior to filing the complaint.Â  The statute of limitations for the
  underlying causes of action ran in March 15, 2005.Â  Garrett failed to properly
  serve the Respondents by March 15, 2005, within the statue of limitations.Â  
 
However, Garrett could commence the action if he had served the Respondents
  within 120 days of filing the complaint.Â  Thus, Garrettâ€™s suit would have been
  timely and not barred by the statute of limitations if he had actually served
  the Respondents by June 28, 2005, 120 days after filing the compliant.Â  Rule
  3(a), SCRCP.
As discussed above, Garrett failed to properly serve the Respondents.Â 
  Consequently, the statute of limitations ran on June 28, 2005.Â   
Garrett argues the trial court should have given him an extension
  to serve the Respondents because he was disabled during the time period between
  filing the complaint and the expiration of the one hundred twenty day period.Â 
  In other words, Garrett asks this Court to carve out an exception to the 120
  day time period set out in Rule 3 if an individual is disabled.Â   
When
  interpreting language of a court rule, the same rules of construction employed
  in interpreting statutes apply.Â  State v. Brown, 344 S.C. 302, 307, 543 S.E.2d
  568, 571 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œTherefore, the words of [the
  rule] must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle
  or forced construction to limit or expand the rule.â€Â  Id. (internal
  quotations and citations omitted).Â  The cardinal rule of
  statutory construction is to determine and give effect to the intent of the
  legislature.Â  Charleston County Sch. Dist. v. State Budget & Control Bd.,
  313 S.C. 1, 5, 437 S.E.2d 6, 8 (1993).Â  The best evidence of legislative intent
  is the text of the statute.Â  Wade v. State, 348
  S.C. 255, 259, 559 S.E.2d 843, 844 (2002) (internal quotations
  and citations omitted).Â  If the terms of the statute are clear, the court must
  apply those terms according to their literal meaning.Â  City of
    Columbia v. Am. Civil Liberties Union of S.C., Inc., 323 S.C. 384, 387,
  475 S.E.2d 2d 747, 749 (1996).Â   
Rule 3 does not state an exception to the time period provided therein if an individual is
  disabled.Â  It is not within the purview of this Court to carve such an
  exception.Â  See Wiggins v. Edwards, 314 S.C. 126, 129, 442 S.E.2d
  169, 171 (1994) (â€œThis
  Court is without authority to alter the plain and unambiguous language of the
  statute.â€).  
D. The trial
  court did not err by ruling on the statute of limitations issue.
Garrett
  seems to argue the trial court should not have addressed the statute of
  limitations issue because it was never before the trial court.Â  We disagree.Â 
 
Garrett,
  in response to Respondents Motion to Quash Service stated, â€œAs the 120 days are
  out, any decision to dismiss may conclude any opportunity to recover even if
  the decision is made without prejudice since the Statute of Limitations may
  have run and refiling may not be an option.â€Â  Garrett brought the issue of
  statute of limitations to the trial courtâ€™s attention, and the trial court was
  proper to address it.  
E. The trial
  court did not err by dismissing the case with prejudice.
Garrettâ€™s fifth argument is the trial
  judge erred by dismissing the case with prejudice.Â  We disagree.
As explained above, the statute of limitations in this case ran on
  June 28, 2005.Â  The trial court issued an order on September 29, 2005, three
  months after the statute of limitations expired.Â  The trial court properly
  dismissed the case with prejudice because Garrett was barred from refiling this
  case.Â   
F. The trial
  court did not err by failing to put into evidence a document Garrett provided. 

On
  October 13, 2005, Garrett filed a Motion to Amend.Â  A hearing was held on this
  motion on December 12, 2005.Â  During this hearing, Garrett attempted to
  introduce a letter from Dr. Christopher Caston The trial court declined to
  consider this letter when issuing its order.Â   
Garrett
  does not provide authority as to why the trial courtâ€™s decision is improper.Â 
  Thus, we consider the issue abandoned.Â  Glasscock, Inc. v. U.S. Fid. & Guar. Co., 348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2001) (holding
  statements made without supporting authority are deemed abandoned on appeal and
  are not presented for review).  
G. Garrettâ€™s
  final three arguments are not preserved for review.
In his final three arguments, Garrett contends the trial court, by
  requiring Garrett to stand during oral arguments, denied Garrett the
  opportunity to compete with opposing counsel on an equal basis; Garrett was
  denied the opportunity to check out law books from the Spartanburg Library; and
  the trial judge erred by failing to recuse himself.  
We do
  not address these issues because they were neither raised to nor ruled upon by
  the trial court.Â  Wilder, Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d
  731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first
  time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge
  to be preserved for appellate review.â€).  
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the trial courtâ€™s decision is  
AFFIRMED. [1] 

ANDERSON,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Roderick Bradley, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Allendale County
Â Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-532
Heard November 6, 2007 â€“ Filed November 19, 2007

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, South Carolina Commission, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia; and Solicitor I. McDuffie Stone, III, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Roderick Bradley appeals the trial courtâ€™s denial of a new trial following allegations of juror misconduct.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
A jury convicted Bradley of second-degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor.Â  During voir dire, no potential jurors responded when asked if they were victims of a violent crime.Â  Following the verdict, Juror G[1] claimed two other jurors, Juror F and Juror W, stated they were rape victims during jury deliberations.Â  Further, Juror G alleged one of the jurors used her personal experience to explain why Bradleyâ€™s alleged victim delayed making the sexual misconduct allegation.Â  The trial court denied Bradleyâ€™s motion for a new trial after finding Juror G was not credible and finding Juror W did not intentionally conceal information.Â  This appeal follows.Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.  Bradley argues the trial court erred in denying his motion for a new trial following allegations jurors disclosed they were rape victims during deliberations.Â  We disagree.
A trial courtâ€™s denial of a new trial motion due to allegations a juror gave misleading or incomplete information on voir dire will be affirmed absent a prejudicial abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Guillebeaux, 362 S.C. 270, 274, 607 S.E.2d 99, 101 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
 
When determining if a new trial is warranted, this court must first determine if the jurorâ€™s failure to respond was an intentional concealment.Â  State v. Woods, 345 S.C. 583, 587, 550 S.E.2d 282, 284 (2001).Â  This is a fact intensive determination made on a case-by-case basis.Â  Guillebeaux, 362 S.C. at 274, 607 at 101-02.Â  In Woods, the South Carolina Supreme Court explained:

	[I]ntentional concealment occurs when the question presented to the jury on
	voir dire is reasonably comprehensible to the average juror and the subject of the inquiry is of such significance that the jurorâ€™s failure to respond is unreasonable.Â  Unintentional concealment, on the other hand, occurs where the question posed is ambiguous or incomprehensible to the average juror, or where the subject of the inquiry is insignificant or so far removed in time that the jurorâ€™s failure to respond is reasonable under the circumstances.

345 S.C. at 588, 550 S.E.2d at 284.  
In the case at hand, the trial court conducted a hearing following Juror Gâ€™s accusations.Â  During this subsequent hearing, the trial court asked Juror W, â€œ[h]ave you even been the victim of a crime that you consider to be a violent crime?â€Â  Juror W responded, â€œ[n]o, it wasnâ€™t a violent crime, but I have been raped.â€Â  Further, Juror W denied anyone in the juror room indicated being a rape victim.[2]Â   
The trial court found Juror G lacked credibility due to her demeanor and failure to disclose her relationship with Bradleyâ€™s family during voir dire.Â  Further, the trial court found Juror W to be a credible witness, who did not interject her personal experiences into jury deliberations and did not intentionally conceal information during voir dire. 
 
Similarly, in State v. Sparkman, 358 S.C. 491, 496-97, 596 S.E.2d 375, 377 (2004), the South Carolina Supreme Court found a jurorâ€™s failure to reveal he was a victim of an attack was unintentional because the attack occurred forty years prior to his jury service and the juror was unsure if his attack constituted a â€œserious crime.â€Â  
 
Further, this court is mindful of the sanctity of jury deliberations.Â  â€œ[C]ourts should not intrude into the privacy of the jury room to scrutinize how jurors reached their verdict. . . .  Normally, juror testimony involving internal misconduct is competent only when necessary to ensure due process, i.e. fundamental fairness.â€Â  State v. Hunter, 320 S.C. 85, 88, 463 S.E.2d 314, 316 (1995).Â  The court in Hunter found allegations of racial prejudice to involve principles of fundamental fairness.Â  Id.Â  See also, State v. Franklin, 341 S.C. 555, 560-62, 534 S.E.2d 716, 719-20 (Ct. App. 2000) (holding calling another juror derogatory names and yelling did not rise to the level of affecting the fundamental fairness of the trial).
Given the courtâ€™s limited scope of review, the trial courtâ€™s credibility findings, Juror Wâ€™s testimony, and the interest in protecting the integrity of jury deliberations this court is constrained to affirm the trial courtâ€™s holding the jurors did not intentionally conceal information.Â  As this ruling is dispositive, this court need not address Bradleyâ€™s remaining argument regarding prejudice.Â  Hagood v. Sommerville, 362 S.C. 191, 199, 607 S.E.2d 707, 711 (2005) (appellate court need not reach remaining issues when an issue is dispositive).
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1] This court abbreviates the jurorsâ€™ names, given the sensitivity of the discussed issues.
[2] The trial court determined Juror Fâ€™s testimony was unnecessary because of the ambiguous nature of the voir dire question and because Bradley used all of his preemptory strikes prior to the seating of Juror F.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Ronald C. Harris, Appellant,
				v.
				Kyle Smith d/b/a DYSKY Unlimited Properties and Michael Taylor d/b/a MTP of Columbia, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-533
Submitted November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed November 19, 2007

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Ronald C. Harris, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Harry Clayton DePew and James Emerson Smith, Jr., both of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Ronald C. Harris appeals from the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of his motion to set aside entry of default and appeals the grant of summary judgment against him.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
 
FACTS
Harris filed this action against Kyle Smith, d/b/a Dysky Unlimited Properties (Smith) and Michael Taylor, d/b/a MTP of Columbia (Taylor) alleging fraudulent nondisclosure, civil conspiracy, and unfair trade practices arising from a real estate transaction. Â Smith answered and counterclaimed, entering into evidence a promissory note and mortgage.Â  Harris failed to respond to the counterclaim and nine months after service of the counterclaim, the court entered default on the counterclaim and set a date for a hearing on damages.Â  Counsel for Harris appeared for the damages hearing.Â  At the start of the hearing, Harris moved to set aside entry of default.Â  That same day, Smith filed a motion for summary judgment as to Harrisâ€™ complaint.Â  The court awarded Smith judgment of $12,924.00 on the counterclaim and set a date to hear the motions.Â 
 
Neither Harris nor his attorney appeared at the motions hearing. Â At the hearing, the court deemed Harris admitted Smithâ€™s Request for Admissions as Harris made no response to the discovery requests.Â  The court then granted Smithâ€™s motion for summary judgment and dismissed Harrisâ€™ motion to set aside entry of default for failure to prosecute.Â  The court denied Harrisâ€™ motion to reconsider. Â Harris appeals the order granting summary judgment and dismissing his motion to set aside entry of default.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Harris argues this court should reverse the trial courtâ€™s order because he was prejudiced by his attorneyâ€™s negligence and suspension from the practice of law.Â  We find no reversible error.
â€œIn the attorney-client relationship, clients are generally bound by their attorneysâ€™ acts or omissions during the course of the legal representation that fall within the apparent scope of their attorneysâ€™ authority.â€Â  Koutsogiannis v. BB & T, 365 S.C. 145, 149-150, 616 S.E.2d 425, 428 (2005).Â  To overcome this general rule that an attorneyâ€™s neglect is attributable to the client, the client must establish that the attorney â€œwillfully and unilaterallyâ€ abandoned the client.Â  Stearns Bank Natâ€™l Assâ€™n v. Glenwood Falls, 373 S.C. 331, 342, 644 S.E.2d 793, 798-799 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  The hearing on the motions for summary judgment and to set aside entry of default was held on March 8, 2005.Â  Harrisâ€™ attorney was not suspended from the practice of law until August 3, 2005.Â  There is nothing in the record indicating Harrisâ€™ attorney willfully and unilaterally abandoned Harris.Â  See Cassady v. Meares, 266 S.C. 352, 354, 223 S.E.2d 191, 192 (1976) (unexplained inaction of an attorney is attributable to the client and is insufficient grounds for relief from default).
Accordingly, the order on appeal is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ. concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

      Marie Piccirillo, Respondent,

				Joseph Terrance
      Piccirillo, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lexington County

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-535
Submitted November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  November 20, 2007Â Â Â

				C. Lawrence Simmons, III, of West Columbia, for Appellant.
				J. MichaelÂ  Taylor, of Columbia, and M. Gwyn DuBose-Schmitt, of Lexington, for Respondent.
			
		
	

Per Curiam: Â Joseph
  T. Piccirillo (Husband) appeals from a family court order finding him in contempt
  for willfully Â violating a prior order restrainingÂ  him from having contact
  with his estranged wife, Jennifer Piccirillo (Wife). Â He contends the family
  court erred by: (1) denying his motion
  for a continuance and his request for a recess during the emergency hearing on
  the rule to show cause; (2) granting equitable relief when Wife had unclean
  hands; (3) finding Wife and her witnesses to be more credible than Husband and
  his witnesses; (4) failing to vacate its contempt order on Husbandâ€™s motion for
  reconsideration based on after-discovered evidence; (5) applying the reasonable
  doubt standard; and (6) awarding attorneyâ€™s fees and costs of $1,570 to Wife.
 
We
  affirm pursuant to Rule
  220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities: S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1350 (Supp. 2006) (â€œAn adult who willfully
  violates, neglects, or refuses to obey or perform a lawful order of the court .
  . . Â may be proceeded against for contempt of court. Â An adult found in
  contempt of court may be punished by a fine, a public work sentence, or by
  imprisonment in a local correctional facility, or any combination of them, in
  the discretion of the court, but not to exceed imprisonment in a local
  correctional facility for one year, a fine of fifteen hundred dollars, or
  public work sentence of more than three hundred hours, or any combination of
  them.â€); Eaddy v. Oliver, 345 S.C. 39, 42, 545 S.E.2d 830, 832 (Ct. App.
  2001) (explaining that a finding of contempt should be reversed on appeal only
  when the holding is based on findings without evidentiary support or there has
  been an abuse of discretion); Browning v. Browning,  366 S.C. 255, 263,
  621 S.E.2d 389, 393 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs either when
  the court is controlled by some error of law or where the
  order, based upon findings of fact, lacks evidentiary support.â€); and Poston
    v. Poston, 331 S.C. 106, 114, 502 S.E.2d 86, 90 (1998) (â€œIn a civil
  contempt proceeding, a contemnor may be required to reimburse a complainant for
  the costs he incurred in enforcing the courtâ€™s prior order, including
  reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The award of attorneyâ€™s fees is not a punishment
  but an indemnification to the party who instituted the contempt proceeding.â€).Â  
 
Therefore,
  the family courtâ€™s order is  
AFFIRMED. [1] 
 
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and THOMAS, JJ., concur

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Wayne Razzi, Appellant,
				v.
				Gail A. Moore
      n/k/a Gail A. Abernathy, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Georgetown County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-536
Submitted November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  November 20, 2007Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Toni Lee Tack Pennington, of Pawleys Island, for Appellant.
				Robert J. Moran, of Murrells Inlet, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Â Wayne Razzi (Razzi)
  appeals the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in this contract action.Â 
  The trial court found Razzi failed to establish the existence of a valid,
  enforceable contract between himself and Gail A. Moore, n/k/a Gail A. Abernathy
  (Abernathy), at the time Abernathy accepted a competing offer to purchase her home.Â 
  We affirm.Â  Â Â 
FACTS
Prior to July 28, 2005, Abernathy listed her home in PawleysÂ  Island, South Carolina for sale through Premier Realty, Inc. (Premier) for
  $205,000. Â On July 28, 2005, The Dieter Co. (Dieter), on behalf of Razzi,
  contacted Premier by fax with an offer of $180,000 for Abernathyâ€™s property.Â  Abernathy
  returned with a counteroffer of $198,000 by fax. Â Razzi did not accept
  this counteroffer.Â   
On August 1, 2005, Razzi faxed Abernathy a new offer for $189,900.Â 
  Abernathy did not alter this price, but she did counter the offer with an
  additional stipulation that the home would be sold â€œas is.â€Â  Abernathyâ€™s
  agent at Premier hand-delivered this counteroffer to Razziâ€™s agent at Dieter on
  August 2, 2005.Â   
On August 3, 2005, Abernathy received an offer of $205,000 for her
  home from a third party.Â  Abernathyâ€™s agent informed Razziâ€™s agent of this
  competing offer by August 4, 2005.Â  After learning of the competing offer, Razziâ€™s
  agent verbally indicated to Abernathyâ€™s agent that Razzi accepted the
  counteroffer.Â  Razziâ€™s agent also sent a fax cover sheet to Abernathyâ€™s agent
  stating Razzi had signed the counteroffer, but the signed counteroffer was not
  included as part of that fax.Â  Having no signed counteroffer from Razzi, Abernathy
  accepted the full price offer from the third party on August 4, 2005. Â Abernathy
  did not receive the signed counteroffer from Razzi until August 5, 2005.
The trial court found Razzi failed to establish the existence of a
  valid, enforceable contract between the two parties, and therefore, the trial
  court granted summary judgment in favor of Abernathy.Â  This appeal follows.
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œWhen
  reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this [C]ourt applies the same
  standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP. . . .â€ Â Englert,
    Inc. v. LeafGuard USA, Inc., 365 S.C. 565, 569, 619 S.E.2d 12, 14 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP, provides:
 
[Summary
  judgment] shall be rendered forthwith if the pleadings, depositions, answers to
  interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any,
  show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving
  party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.Â   
â€œIn determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the
  evidence and all factual inferences drawn from it must be viewed in a light
  most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€Â  Donahue v. Multimedia, Inc.,
  362 S.C. 331, 337, 608 S.E.2d 162, 165 (Ct. App. 2005). Â â€œEven if there is no
  dispute as to evidentiary facts, but only as to the conclusions or inferences
  to be drawn from them, summary judgment should be denied.â€Â  Keith v. River
    Consulting, Inc., 365 S.C. 500, 505, 618 S.E.2d 302, 304 (Ct App. 2005).Â 
  â€œSummary judgment is not appropriate when further inquiry into the facts of the
  case is desirable to clarify the application of law.â€Â  Id.Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
Razzi argues
  the trial court erred in granting summary judgment because genuine issues of
  material facts exist.Â  Specifically, Razzi contends facts are in dispute as to
  whether Abernathy effectively notified Razzi of her withdrawal of the
  counteroffer before she accepted another offer.Â  Razzi claims he was never
  informed Abernathy had received another offer.Â  Razzi contends this dispute
  over notice is a factual issue that should be submitted to the jury.Â  We find
  this contention unfounded.  
It is well settled law that â€œnotice to an agent while acting
  within the scope of his authority is notice to the principal.â€Â  Hill v.
    Carolina Power & Light Co., 204 S.C. 83, 99, 28 S.E.2d 545, 550
  (1943).Â  For notice to bind the principal, it â€œmust relate to the business or
  transaction in reference to which the agent is authorized to act for and on
  behalf of his principal, and to matters over which his authority extends.â€ Id.Â  A principal is â€œaffected with constructive
  knowledge of all material facts of which his agent receives notice while acting
  within the scope of his authority.â€Â  Bankers Trust of S.C. v. Bruce, 283
  S.C. 408, 423, 323 S.E.2d 523, 532 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  Furthermore, an agentâ€™s notice binds the principal in
  real estate transactions as well.Â  See Faulkner v. Millar, 319
  S.C. 216, 221, 460 S.E.2d 378, 381 (1995) (â€œBuyerâ€™s notice to Sellersâ€™ realtor
  and attorney is binding upon Sellers.â€).Â   
Steve Tadlock (Tadlock), a real estate agent with Dieter, worked
  with Razzi in the negotiating process for Abernathyâ€™s property.Â  Tadlock stated
  in his affidavit: â€œOn August 4, 2005, [Abernathyâ€™s agent], had called me saying
  that [Abernathy] had accepted a full price offer and that my buyers were out of
  luck.â€Â  Tadlock also demonstrated his knowledge of the competing offer in a fax
  cover sheet, dated August 4, 2005, to Abernathyâ€™s agent.Â  This cover sheet
  included a message acknowledging Abernathyâ€™s agent had informed Tadlock that
  another offer had been received and would be accepted.Â  In the current
  situation, Tadlock was acting as the agent for Razzi for the purchase of Abernathyâ€™s
  property.Â  Therefore, any knowledge Tadlock had of a competing offer was
  imputed to Razzi by way of their agency relationship; it is irrelevant whether
  Razzi had actual knowledge of this competing offer.Â  Tadlockâ€™s knowledge of a
  competing offer was sufficient notice to Razzi that Abernathyâ€™s counteroffer
  had been withdrawn.Â  Â Â 
â€œAs a general rule, a mere offer to buy or sell, not supported by
  sufficient consideration, may be withdrawn by the party making it at any time
  before it is accepted by the other party . . . as long as sufficient notice of
  the withdrawal is communicated to the offeree prior to acceptance.â€Â  77 AM. JUR. 2D Vendor
    and Purchaser Â§ 22 (2007); see Masonic Temple v.
      Ebert, 199 S.C. 5, 12, 18 S.E.2d 584, 587 (1942) (â€œIt is clear, in the
  ordinary case, that an offer may be withdrawn at any time before its
  acceptance, by notice given to that effect to the other party.â€). Â â€œIt is clear
  that the law does not require a notice of withdrawal of an offer to be in any
  particular form.Â  It is not necessary that the words â€˜revokeâ€™ or â€˜withdrawâ€™ be
  used.â€Â  Masonic Temple, 199 S.C. at 16, 18 S.E.2d at 589.Â  Â Â Withdrawal
  of an offer is sufficient if â€œthe person making the offer does some act
  inconsistent with it . . . and that person to whom the offer was made has
  knowledge of such act.â€Â  Id. Â Â 
As of August 4, 2005, Razzi had not accepted Abernathyâ€™s
  counteroffer, leaving Abernathy free to withdraw her counteroffer.Â  Although there
  was never a specific statement withdrawing Abernathyâ€™s counteroffer, we find Abernathyâ€™s
  act of informing Razziâ€™s agent that the full price offer had been received and
  would be accepted constitutes a sufficient withdrawal of her counteroffer.Â 
  This act put Razziâ€™s agent, as well as Razzi, on notice that Abernathyâ€™s
  counteroffer was withdrawn.Â  Razzi failed to provide Abernathy with written
  confirmation of his acceptance of the counteroffer until August 5, 2005, by
  which time Abernathy had withdrawn her counteroffer.Â  With only an oral
  acceptance of the contract, Razzi was in violation of the Statute of Frauds,
  leaving the parties with no valid, enforceable contract.Â  See Bradshaw
    v. Ewing, 297 S.C. 242, 245, 376 S.E.2d 264, 266Â  (1989) (â€œThe Statute of
  Frauds . . . requires, in pertinent part, that a contract for the sale of land
  must be in writing.â€).Â   
Razzi disputes whether the counteroffer was accepted by August 4,
  2005, but we find no factual dispute as to this issue.Â  The Statute of Frauds
  requires a contract for the sale of land to be in writing.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  32-3-10 (1976) (â€œNo action shall be brought . . . [t]o charge any person upon
  any contract or sale of lands . . . [u]nless the agreement upon which such
  action shall be brought or some memorandum or note thereof shall be in writing.
  . . .â€).Â  A formally executed contract is not required for satisfaction of the
  Statute of Frauds, but there must, at a minimum, be some memorandum or note of
  the agreement which sufficiently indicates a contract has been entered between
  the parties.Â  Honorage Nursing Home of Florence, S.C., Inc. v. Florence Convalescent Ctr., Inc., 367 S.C. 108, 114-15, 623 S.E.2d 853, 856 (Ct. App.
  2005).Â   
On August 4, 2005, Razziâ€™s agent verbally indicated to Abernathyâ€™s
  agent that Razzi accepted the counteroffer, but Razzi did not give a written
  confirmation of this acceptance at that time.Â  Razzi argues that the fax cover
  sheet sent on August 4, 2005, satisfies the writing requirement, but we do not
  agree.Â  The fax cover sheet indicated Razzi signed the counteroffer, but Razzi failed
  to actually provide that signed counteroffer.Â  Without a more substantial
  writing, we do not find the fax cover sheet to be a sufficient writing indicating
  an agreement has been entered between the parties, and, therefore, the Statute
  of Frauds has not been satisfied.Â Â Â   
Razzi next argues the facts of this case allow for the application
  of the part performance exception to the writing requirement, thus removing the
  contract from the Statute of Frauds. Â However, we do not find any factual
  dispute which would make this exception applicable.Â  â€œTo remove an oral
  contract to convey real estate from the Statute of Frauds, [the party trying to
  enforce the contract] must show part performance of the oral contract.â€Â  Bradshaw,
  297 S.C. at 245, 376 S.E.2d at 266. Â While payment of the purchase price for
  the property is evidence of performance, â€œ[p]ayment of the purchase price is
  the weakest evidence of part performance and will not suffice on its own to
  remove a contract from the Statute of Frauds.â€Â  Id.Â  A court will only
  grant specific performance of an oral contract for the conveyance of real
  estate when the payment of the purchase price is coupled with possession of or
  improvements to the land by the purchaser.Â  Stackhouse v. Cook, 271 S.C.
  518, 522, 248 S.E.2d 482, 484 (1978).Â  Â Â Â 
While Razzi did pay earnest money for Abernathyâ€™s property, we do
  not find this evidence strong enough to remove the contract from the Statute of
  Frauds.Â  Razzi neither took possession of the land nor made improvements to it,
  and without those acts, the small amount of earnest money Razzi paid will not
  suffice to remove the contract from the Statute of Frauds.Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
For the reasons set forth above, we find no genuine issue of
  material fact exists, and the trial court was correct in finding Abernathy was
  entitled to summary judgment as a matter of law. Â Accordingly,
  the trial courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.[1]
ANDERSON, SHORT,
  and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				South Carolina
      Department of Social Services, Respondent,
				Â  v.
				Laquitta S. and
      Anthony S., Defendants, 
				of whom is
          Laquitta S. is Appellant.
				In the Interest
  of: L. R. S. (DOB: 03/03/04); a minor child under the age of 18.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â Wylie H. Caldwell, Jr., Family Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-537
Submitted November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  November 29, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Ronald R. Norton, of Conway, for Appellant.
				Robert Paul Taylor, of Conway, for Respondent.
				Paige F. Bellamy, of Myrtle Beach, for Childâ€™s Guardian ad Litem.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: The
  South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) brought this termination of
  parental rights (TPR) action against Laquitta S. (Mother) and Anthony S.
  (Father).Â  The family court terminated Motherâ€™s and Fatherâ€™s parental rights to
  L. R. S. (Child).[1] Â Mother appeals the family courtâ€™s termination of her parental rights.Â  We
  affirm.[2] Â Â 
FACTS
Mother gave birth to Child on March 30, 2004.Â  Three days later,
  DSS took Child into emergency protective custody directly from the hospital
  because of its concern Mother would be unable to care for Child at home.Â  DSS
  case manager, Felicia Bellamy, testified at the TPR hearing that Mother, who is
  HIV positive and has an IQ of 60, did not understand that her plans to
  breastfeed could potentially endanger Childâ€™s health.Â Â   
DSS prepared a treatment plan requiring
  Mother and Father to undergo psychological evaluations, attend parenting
  classes, and maintain appropriate housing. Â On
  September 23, 2004, the court ordered DSS to make arrangements to transport
  Child from the foster home to Motherâ€™s home for daily supervised visits, Monday
  through Friday; the visits were to last at least two hours per day. Â DSS
  contracted with the Youth Advocacy Program to transport Child and supervise the
  daily visits.  
For approximately three months, Kathleen Chapman of the Youth
  Advocacy Program transported Child from foster care to Motherâ€™s home for daily
  visits.Â  During these visits, Chapman supervised the interaction between Mother
  and Child and assisted Mother with the care of Child.Â  Chapman testified that
  each visit to Motherâ€™s home lasted approximately six hours.Â   
Following a Merits Hearing on December 9-10, 2004, the court
  relieved DSS of transporting Child to Motherâ€™s home for daily visits; instead,
  the court ordered DSS to exercise its own discretion over future visits.Â  After
  the termination of court-ordered visits, Mother visited Child only twice from
  January 2005 to July 2006.Â  The first visit, on April 2, 2005, took place at a
  fast food restaurant and was supervised by Childâ€™s foster parent.Â  Following
  this visit, the foster parent reported that she did not want to supervise
  future visits due to Motherâ€™s inappropriate comments in Childâ€™s presence.Â 
  Mother did not visit Child again until December 9, 2005.Â   
Â Bellamy testified Mother contacted DSS in February 2006, to
  schedule a visit.Â  Based on DSS notes regarding Motherâ€™s two visits in 2005,
  DSS staff was reluctant to schedule additional visits.Â  However, in response to
  Motherâ€™s continuing attempts to schedule a visit, Bellamy visited Motherâ€™s home
  on April 7, 2006. Â During the visit, Mother said she was living with
  Kevin Harrell and told Ms. Bellamy she planned to â€œsign overâ€ Child to Kevinâ€™s
  mother for adoption once Child was returned to her.[3]Â   
Thereafter,
  DSS filed an action to terminate Motherâ€™s parental rights.Â  The family court
  found termination of Motherâ€™s parental rights was in the best interest of Child
  and was supported by the following statutory grounds: Child lived outside
  Motherâ€™s home for six months, and Mother had provided no meaningful support or
  material contributions to Child during that period, pursuant to S.C. Code Ann.
  Â§ 20-7-1572(4); Child lived outside Motherâ€™s home for six months, and Mother
  had willfully failed to visit Child after December 2005, pursuant to S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(3); Mother failed to remedy the conditions which caused
  removal of Child, pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(2); and Child had been
  in foster care for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months, pursuant to
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(8). Â This appeal followed.  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The grounds for
  the TPR must be proven by clear and convincing evidence. S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc.
    Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 254, 519 S.E.2d 351, 354 (Ct. App. 1999).Â 
  â€œUpon review, the appellate court may make its own finding from the record as
  to whether clear and convincing evidence supports the termination [of parental
  rights].â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 609, 582
  S.E.2d 419, 423 (2003).Â  Despite our broad scope of review, we are not required
  to disregard the findings of the family court because â€œthe family court, who
  saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility
  and assign comparative weight to their testimony.â€ Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Although
  Child left the hospital in DSS care following birth and continuously remained
  in DSS care for twenty-seven months, Mother argues the family court erred in
  terminating her parental rights and brings four issues for our review: (1) DSS
  failed to show by clear and convincing evidence that Mother had failed to
  remedy the conditions that caused removal; (2) Motherâ€™s failure to visit Child
  was not willful because DSS prevented visits between Mother and Child following
  termination of DSS-coordinated visits in December 2004; (3) Motherâ€™s failure to
  support Child for six months was not willful; and (4) no testimony supported a
  finding of severe and repeated abuse or neglect that was unlikely to be
  remedied within twelve months.Â  We find that clear and convincing evidence
  supports at least one ground for termination and that termination is in Childâ€™s
  best interest.  
In South Carolina, procedures for TPR are governed by statute.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§
  20-7-1560 to 1582 (Supp. 2006).Â Â  The purpose of the TPR statute is:

	to
  establish procedures for the reasonable and compassionate termination of
  parental rights where children are abused, neglected, or abandoned in order to
  protect the health and welfare of these children and make them eligible for
  adoption by persons who will provide a suitable home environment and the love
  and care necessary for a happy, healthful, and productive life.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1560
  (Supp. 2006).Â  The TPR statute â€œmust be liberally construed in order to ensure
  prompt judicial procedures for freeing minor children from the custody and
  control of their parents by terminating the parent-child relationship.Â  The
  interests of the child shall prevail if the childâ€™s interest and the parental
  rights conflict.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp. 2006).Â  The family court
  may order TPR upon a finding of one or more of the eleven statutory grounds and
  a finding that termination is in the best interest of the child.Â  See S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2006).Â Â   
In
  this case, the record demonstrates Child had been in foster care since birth,
  and was twenty-seven months old and still residing in foster care when the TPR
  hearing was conducted.Â  A finding that Child had been in foster care for
  fifteen months is sufficient to support TPR where the court also finds TPR is
  in the best interest of Child.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Sims, 359
  S.C. 601, 606, 598 S.E.2d 303, 306 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The fact that DSS proved
  by clear and convincing evidence that Child had been in foster care for the
  past twenty-seven months is not disputed by Mother.
Because
  we affirm the family courtâ€™s finding that Child has resided in foster care for
  fifteen of the past twenty-two months satisfies the statutory ground for TPR,
  we decline to address additional statutory grounds for termination of Motherâ€™s
  parental rights. Â Accordingly, the family court did not err in terminating
  Motherâ€™s parental rights based on its finding that a statutory ground was
  satisfied.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(8).
Mother also does not challenge the family courtâ€™s
  finding that termination of her parental rights is in the best interest of
  Child.Â  We address this issue nonetheless due to the courtâ€™s role in protecting
  minors.Â  See, e.g., Arscott v. Bacon, 351 S.C. 44, 55, 567
  S.E.2d 898, 904 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œ[D]ue to the role of courts in protecting
  minors, this court may raise ex mero motu issues not raised by
  the parties.â€).Â  In a TPR case, the best interest of the child is the paramount
  consideration.Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733,
  735 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œThe interests of the child shall prevail if the childâ€™s
  interest and the parental rights conflict.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp.
  2006).
Motherâ€™s
  guardian ad litem, Glenn Ohanesian, testified: â€œ[t]his woman would do anything
  within her power to care for this child, and she has to the best of her ability
  complied with anything sheâ€™s been asked to do . . . .Â  I think that based on
  what weâ€™ve heard, the testimony is already in the record that with constant
  supervision and . . . the right facility that she could stay with this child .
  . . .â€Â   
Bellamy
  testified that DSS coordinated supervised visits in Motherâ€™s home for three
  months.Â  The visits lasted approximately six hours a day and were designed to
  help Mother learn to care for her child.Â  DSS also explored the possibility of
  placing Mother and Child in a group home or therapeutic foster home that would
  provide services to both of them.Â  However, Bellamy testified that these homes
  indicated they could not take a â€œmentally limited mother and her baby.â€Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
 
DSS
  referred Mother to parenting classes coordinated by Family Outreach.Â  Sherry
  Coutain, Director of Education and an LPN, testified Mother attended eight
  hours of infant care instruction in June 2004.Â  Child did not attend the
  parenting classes; instead, Mother practiced infant care skills with a â€œdemo
  doll.â€Â  Coutain testified that although she believed Mother wanted to be a good
  mother, â€œI would not recommend that the child be left in her care without
  supervision . . . .â€Â  When asked how much supervision Mother would need to
  adequately care for her child, Coutain responded: â€œI would say she would need .
  . . constant supervision.â€  
From
  September 27 to December 9, 2004, Kathleen Chapman of the Youth Advocacy
  Program transported Child from the foster home to Motherâ€™s home and supervised
  their daily visits.Â  She testified that Motherâ€™s home was dirty and without
  soap, dish detergent, or toilet paper.Â  In addition to supervising the
  interactions between Mother and Child, Chapman assisted Mother in making infant
  formula and helped her operate the nebulizer and suctioning syringe required to
  treat Childâ€™s asthma.Â   
Chapman
  testified that people would come and go from Motherâ€™s home throughout the
  supervised visits, sometimes taking food and baby formula.Â  According to
  Chapman, â€œ[Mother] was taken advantage of greatly, greatly.â€Â  Chapman also
  testified Mother did not understand the severity of her HIV condition and told
  her she â€œlet people have sex for money.â€  
Mother
  testified she no longer lived at the home where Child had visited with her in
  2004.Â  Since then, she had lived with her aunt for a while and, for the past
  two days, had been living with her roommate, Cal.Â  When the court asked Mother
  what she would do if she and Cal had a â€œfalling out,â€ she responded: â€œIâ€™ll go
  back to the mission to stay until I find me another place.â€Â   
Following
  the completion of testimony, the court noted: â€œ[t]wo years is a long time for a
  parent not to get in a position to, at the very minimum, have a decent home for
  her to go to . . . .Â  [T]his child has been out of the parentsâ€™ home ever since
  she was removed in March of 2004, and they still donâ€™t have anywhere for her to
  live . . . .â€Â  We agree and find that termination of Motherâ€™s parental rights
  is in Childâ€™s best interest.  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  CONCLUSION
Based on the
  foregoing, the family courtâ€™s order is  
AFFIRMED.
HUFF
  and PIEPER, JJ., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.Â  

[1 Father and Mother were
  living at the same address at the time of Childâ€™s birth; however, Fatherâ€™s
  paternity was not confirmed until he took a paternity test on September 15,
  2004. Â Father no longer lives with Mother
  and was served by publication.Â  He did not attend the TPR hearing; however, his
  interests were represented by counsel, James Young, and guardian ad litem, John
  Thomas.Â  Neither Mr. Young nor Mr. Thomas had been able to locate Father. Â The
  last documented contact between DSS and Father occurred in December 2004.
 
[2] We decide this case without oral argument
  pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3] There is no further mention of Kevin Harrellâ€™s
  mother in the Record.
