THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Giselle Bailey
      Rogers, Respondent,
				v.
				Gregory Rogers, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Aphrodite K. Konduros, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-538
Submitted November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed
  November 29, 2007
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


	
		
			
				DeborahÂ  Murdock, of Greenville, for
  Appellant.
				John Michael Turner, Sr., of Laurens, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  This is an appeal of a divorce decree.Â  Gregory Rogers (Husband) argues the
  family court erred in its findings concerning child support and alimony,
  apportionment of the marital assets and marital debt, grounds for the divorce,
  and attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  We affirm as modified.[1]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Husband and Giselle Bailey Rogers (Wife)
  married on June 29, 1991.Â Â  They have one son, who was born in 1994, and one
  daughter, who was born in 2001.Â  Wife is an elementary schoolteacher.Â  Husband is
  a State Farm insurance agent with various income-producing side ventures,
  including the sale of vehicles and the rental of two tractor-trailer trucks.Â  
 
In
  1998, Wife filed for divorce, alleging Husband had infected her with Chlamydia;
  however, the action was dismissed when the parties reconciled.Â  In 2004, the
  parties separated again, and Wife filed the present action requesting, among
  other relief, a divorce on the ground of adultery, temporary possession of the
  marital home, custody of the partiesâ€™ children, child support and alimony,
  equitable division of the marital property, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  In his answer
  and counterclaim, Husband denied the material allegations of the complaint and
  counterclaimed for custody of the children and possession of the marital home.
On September 20, 2004, the family court
  held a temporary hearing, during which the parties announced an agreement on
  the issues of custody, visitation, discovery, and child support, leaving only
  the issues of temporary possession of the marital home, attorneyâ€™s fees, and
  alimony for the court to decide.Â  Pursuant to the partiesâ€™ agreement, the
  family court granted Wife custody of the children with reasonable visitation to
  Husband, authorized full discovery, and ordered Husband to pay child support of
  $1,000.00 per month directly to Wife.Â  The family court also granted Wife
  temporary possession of the marital home, directed Husband to pay one half of the
  mortgage payment, and held alimony and attorneyâ€™s fees in abeyance with the
  proviso that these issues would be subject to retroactive application.  
Husband
  apparently failed to pay child support as ordered by the court; therefore, on
  February 8, 2005, the family court issued an order requiring all future child
  support to be paid through the clerk of court.Â  On March 29, 2005, a second
  temporary hearing took place, resulting in an order modifying visitation, appointing
  a guardian ad litem, and making certain provisions concerning extracurricular
  activities of the partiesâ€™ son.Â  In addition, pursuant to a motion to compel
  filed by Wife, the family court ordered Husband to produce a statement of his
  retirement fund with State Farm and granted Wife $1,800.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees
  incurred from the motion.
A final
  hearing in the matter took place on March 15, 2006.Â  By order dated June 26,
  2006, the family court granted Wife a divorce on the ground of adultery,
  approved the partiesâ€™ agreement regarding custody and visitation, required
  Husband to pay child support of $1,484.00 per month plus $550.00 per month
  towards the childrenâ€™s school and daycare expenses, set alimony at $2,000.00
  per month retroactive to September 27, 2004, and directed Husband to pay the
  alimony arrearage of $40,000.00 at $500.00 per month.Â  In addition, the family
  court ordered Husband to pay $19,650.00 to Wifeâ€™s attorney, representing the
  balance of her request for attorneyâ€™s fees of $22,950.00 less his prior
  payments of $3,300.00
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn appeals from the family court, an
  appellate court has the authority to find the facts in accordance with its own
  view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C.
  532, 540, 615 S.E.2d 98, 102 (2005) (citing Rutherford v. Rutherford,
  307 S.C. 199, 414 S.E.2d 157 (1992) and Owens v. Owens, 320 S.C. 543,
  466 S.E.2d 373 (Ct. App. 1996)).Â  â€œThis broad scope of review does not,
  however, require the appellate court to disregard the findings of the family
  court.â€Â  Id. (citing Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 279
  S.E.2d 616 (1981)).Â  â€œNeither is the appellate court required to ignore the
  fact that the family court, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better
  position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their
  testimony.â€Â  Id. (citing Cherry Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 280
  S.E.2d 541 (1981)).Â  Moreover, â€œwhen an
  appellate court chooses to find facts in accordance with its own view of the
  evidence, the court must state distinctly its findings of fact and the reason
  for its decision.â€Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278,
  283, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002) (citing Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR).
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â  Husband first alleges
  that, for purposes of calculating child support, the family court improperly
  imputed income to him that was not supported by the evidence.Â  In response,
  Wife argues the family court did not impute income to Husband but simply added
  non-reported and non-taxed income to the amount Husband contended was his
  current income per month.Â  We agree with Wife that the family court committed
  no abuse of discretion in including these amounts to determine Husbandâ€™s income
  potential, but modify the base amount to which these figures were added.
According to
  Husbandâ€™s most recent financial declaration, his current monthly income was
  $10,314.00.Â  At trial, Husband testified he arrived at this figure by averaging
  his taxable income as reflected on his tax returns from 2002 through 2004.Â 
  Inexplicably, however, the family court stated that Husband â€œnow contends that
  his income is $10,368.97 per month . . . .â€Â  We were unable to find any
  corroboration in the record on appeal to support this statement, and Wifeâ€™s counsel
  has not directed our attention to where in the record such evidence appears;
  therefore, we hold any additions to Husbandâ€™s monthly income should have
  supplemented a base figure of $10,314.00, not $10,368.97.
As to the additions
  themselves, however, we hold the family court acted within its discretion in
  including them as income to Husband. Â As noted in the appealed order, these
  amounts included a car benefit of $6,600.00 per year and payment of up to
  $15,000.00 per year of gasoline bills, insurance premiums, water bills, and
  credit card expenses for personal use. Â Husband admitted to receiving these
  benefits.Â  Whether or not he was required to report them as income for income
  tax purposes, they inured to his advantage and were properly considered as
  income for purposes of setting child support.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 114-4720(A)(2) (Supp. 2006) (stating
  that, in determination of child support awards, â€œ[u]nreported case income
  should also be included if it can be identified.â€); id. 114-4720(A)(3)(C) (noting that, although in-kind income is not included in
  gross income for determining child support, â€œthe court should count as income
  expense reimbursements or in-kind payments received by a parent from . . .
  operation of a business if they are significant and reduce personal living
  expenses . . . .â€); Mobley v. Mobley, 309 S.C. 134, 138-39, 420 S.E.2d
  506, 509-10 (Ct. App. 1992) (holding the custodial parent was entitled to a
  redetermination of a child support award because the family court failed to
  include in the noncustodial parentâ€™s income any amount for his employee
  benefits).
Husband
  further takes issue with the inclusion of rental income on one of his
  tractor-trailer trucks in his monthly income, alleging the payments he was
  receiving were simply used to make the loan payments on the vehicles and the
  payments did not come in on a regular basis.Â  We find no abuse of discretion.Â 
  The family court noted (1) the amount reflecting this income actually covered
  the rental of only one of two trucks; and (2) Husband had listed this amount on
  his initial financial declaration, but omitted it from his later financial
  statement.Â  In our view, the family courtâ€™s inclusion of rental income for only
  one tractor-trailer truck was a reasonable compromise offsetting the sporadic
  receipt of the payments and any expenses associated with the trucks.
Applying
  the revised figure for Husbandâ€™s monthly base income, Husbandâ€™s child support
  payments under the South Carolina Child Support Guidelines should be $1,408.00
  per month, rather than $1,484.00 per month as ordered by the family court.Â  We
  therefore modify the appealed order to reflect this finding.  
2.Â  Husband next
  argues the family court erred in requiring him to pay $550.00 per month for the
  younger childâ€™s expenses at a Montessori school.Â  In support of this argument,
  he asserts (1) this payment was not included in the partiesâ€™ agreement; (2) the
  amount was placed into the child support calculation twice and treated as a
  twelve-month expense when it was actually a nine-month expense; (3) it was
  inequitable to require him to pay these expenses because Wife is entitled to
  claim these same expenses as daycare; and (4) he should have been given credit
  for paying expenses associated with the older childâ€™s participation in athletics.Â 
  We find no reversible error.
Although
  the payment of the younger childâ€™s Montessori school expenses was not part of
  the partiesâ€™ agreement, Wife testified she desired Husband to assist with these
  expenses, of which she herself was ordered to pay a proportionate share, plus the
  fee for two to three weeks of summer camp for the younger child.Â  Furthermore, as
  shown on line 10 of the child support worksheet used by the family court,
  Husband was given a credit of $550.00 as an adjustment to his child support
  obligation. Â As to Husbandâ€™s final argument, he has neither directed our
  attention to evidence in the record upon which the family court should have
  based an appropriate adjustment to his child support payments based on his
  contributions toward expenses incurred by the older child nor cited any
  supporting authority for his assertion that he was entitled to such a credit.Â  See First
    Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994) (stating the appellant was deemed to have abandoned an issue for which he
  failed to provide any argument or supporting authority).
3.Â  Husband next
  argues he should not have to pay alimony and child support through the clerk of
  court, arguing he incurs additional costs of $3,984.00 per year in court fees.Â 
  He suggests he should be allowed to set up an automatic draft from his bank
  account to pay alimony and child support directly to Wifeâ€™s bank account.Â  We
  find no abuse of discretion in the family courtâ€™s refusal to let him make his
  own arrangements for these payments.Â  At the initial temporary hearing, the
  family court allowed him to pay child support directly to Wife; however, he
  failed to make payments as ordered, which necessitated an additional hearing to
  require him to make his payments through the court.
4.Â  Husband complains the
  family court overvalued his State Farm account because he did not invest the
  funds in an individual retirement account and because he would not receive
  whatever benefits he was entitled to until he reached age 55 or 60, provided he
  had worked 20 years.Â  On appeal, he contends that, instead of the figure of
  $78,069.00 that appears on Wifeâ€™s asset list as the value of this account, the
  account should have been assigned a present value of $15,000.00.Â  Wife has not
  provided any counterargument on this point in her brief; therefore, we modify
  the appealed order to find that the value of the State Farm residual account
  awarded to Husband is $15,000.00.
5.Â 
  Husband further alleges Wifeâ€™s half-interest in a house that she purchased with
  her father during the marriage should have been included in the marital
  estate.Â  We disagree.Â  The fact that the property was acquired during the
  marriage raises only a presumption that it is marital.Â  See Fuller v.
    Fuller, 370 S.C. 538, 551, 636 S.E.2d 636, 643 (Ct. App. 2006) (â€œBecause of the general presumption
  that property acquired during the marriage is an asset of the marriage, the
  burden to show an asset is nonmarital is
  upon the party claiming the nonmarital status.â€).Â  Here, the family court apparently determined Wife
  carried her burden to show the interest was not marital, and the evidence
  supports this finding.Â  Wife testified her father resided in the house,
  intended to stay there indefinitely, and was responsible for the expenses
  associated with it.Â  She also indicated her name was on the title only because
  she co-signed the loan to purchase the home.
6.Â  Notwithstanding our adjustment of the value of Husbandâ€™s State
  Farm residual account, we affirm the family courtâ€™s division of the remaining
  marital assets and debt.Â   
At the outset, we note the family court
  did not, as required by statute, â€œmake findings of fact from credible evidence
  of the value of property and servicesâ€ before allocating the marital assets and
  debt.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-474(1) (Supp. 2006).Â  Instead, the court
  apparently did not attempt to value the marital assets either individually or
  collectively, but instead divided the marital property in-kind based on how a
  particular item was titled or testimony from the parties regarding who should
  receive it.Â  Accordingly, Wife received the marital home and furnishings, her
  2004 Chevrolet Tahoe, various American Express accounts, and her State retirement
  and 401k accounts. Â Similarly, Husband received his interest in certain
  commercial properties, the residual value of his State Farm account, and all
  other vehicles.Â  As to debts incurred during the marriage, the family court
  required Husband to be responsible for a federal tax lien of $62,854.20 that
  attached to the marital home as a result of his failure to file tax returns and
  pay taxes for 2002, 2003, and 2004.
According to the inventory of marital property submitted
  by Wife, as amended by the revised value of the State Farm residual account, she
  received assets totaling $180,391.03 and Husband received assets totaling $151,876.00;
  therefore, the total value of the divided assets according to Wife was $332,267.03.Â 
  In contrast, Husband submitted an inventory valuing the marital assets Wife
  received at $200,391.44[2] and those he received at $135,876.00[3];
  thus, the combined value of the assets using Husbandâ€™s valuation was $336,267.44.Â 
  Under the evidence presented to the family court, Wifeâ€™s share of the marital
  estate, then, ranges from 54.29 percent to 59.59 percent.Â  Similarly, Husbandâ€™s
  share ranges from 40.41 percent to 45.71 percent.Â  We hold the division is reasonable under the
  circumstances of this case, which include the family courtâ€™s recognition that
  the marital estate was â€œsomewhat difficult to value due to the husbandâ€™s
  evasive answers and obvious attempts not to disclose assets and income.â€ 
 
7.Â  Husband further contends
  that, because the tax lien was incurred before the commencement of the marital
  litigation, the family court should not have made him solely responsible for
  discharging it.Â  Although Husband cites case law supporting his argument that
  the lien was a marital debt and argues at length about the hardship he would
  suffer from having to pay it, he does not contest the family courtâ€™s findings
  that the obligation resulted from his refusal and failure to timely file tax
  returns and pay taxes and that Wife had been filing her tax returns and paying
  her taxes after she became aware Husband was avoiding his tax obligations.[4]Â 
  Under these circumstances, we find no abuse of discretion in the family courtâ€™s
  decision to assign Husband responsibility for the lien.Â  See S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(2) (Supp. 2006) (requiring the family court, in apportioning
  the marital estate, to give appropriate weight to â€œmarital misconduct or fault
  of either or both parties, whether or not used as a basis for a divorce as
  such, if the misconduct affects or has affected the economic circumstances of
  the partiesâ€); Woodside v. Woodside, 290 S.C. 366, 374, 350 S.E.2d 407,
  412 (Ct. App. 1986) (â€œ[T]he conduct factor becomes important in equitable
  distribution when the conduct of one party to the marriage is such that it
  throws upon the other party marital burdens beyond the norms to be expected in
  the marital relationship.â€). Â 
8. Â Husband next argues the
  alimony award was excessive in that it placed Wife in better circumstances than
  she enjoyed during the marriage.Â  In support of this argument, he asserts Wife
  is young, well educated, gainfully employed, and in good health.Â  He also
  points to the fact that, after the divorce, she retained considerable
  nonmarital property and had generous retirement accounts and benefits as a
  state employee.Â  We find no error.
In the appealed
  order, the family court gave full consideration to the statutory factors on
  which to base an alimony award.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(c) (Supp.
  2006).Â  Significantly, the court noted (1) the parties had been married fifteen
  years; (2) Husband earned far more than Wife; (3) Husbandâ€™s misconduct caused
  the breakup of the marriage; (4) during the marriage Wife enjoyed a fine
  lifestyle that included a home in an upscale neighborhood and trips to exotic
  locations; (5) Husband would receive a tax benefit because he could deduct the
  alimony payments; and (6) neither party had any support obligations from a prior
  marriage.Â  Considering these findings, as well as the considerable difficulties
  in ascertaining Husbandâ€™s income, we disagree with Husband that the family
  court abused its discretion in determining the alimony award.Â  See Craig v. Craig, 365 S.C. 285, 292, 617 S.E.2d 359, 362
  (2005) (â€œAn award of alimony rests within the sound discretion of the family
  court and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€).
9.Â  Husband further contends
  the award of retroactive alimony was excessive, especially given that he paid
  one half of the mortgage payments on the marital home while the action was
  pending.Â  We disagree.Â  Wife had requested alimony at the temporary hearing,
  and Husband had notice from the first temporary order that the issue of alimony
  would be decided at the final hearing but was subject to retroactive
  application.Â  In determining retroactive alimony, the family court evidently
  relied on the same factors that it considered in determining periodic alimony.Â 
  As to Husbandâ€™s argument that he should receive a credit toward the retroactive
  alimony award for the payments he made on the mortgage on the marital home, we
  agree with Wife that these payments, which Wife was required to make as well,
  were ordered with the objective of preserving a marital asset rather than to
  provide support and maintenance.
10.Â  Husband next argues the family court erred in granting Wife a
  divorce based on adultery, asserting Wifeâ€™s testimony alone was insufficient
  evidence to support a finding that he had been unfaithful.Â  He further contends
  that any reliance on Wifeâ€™s testimony that he had infected her
  with Chlamydia was improper because the parties reconciled after that
  occurrence.Â   
We
  have some concern as to whether the evidence Wife offered to support her claim
  for a divorce on the ground of adultery was sufficient.Â  See McElveen
    v. McElveen, 332 S.C. 583, 596-97, 506 S.E.2d 1, 7-8 (1998) (affirming the
  family courtâ€™s refusal to find a party had committed adultery, notwithstanding
  numerous telephone calls between the party and her alleged paramour during late
  hours, records of weekend trips taken by the party and her alleged paramour,
  and evidence of attempts to alter or eradicate these records).Â  In any event, we
  note the family court, with Wifeâ€™s consent, granted Husbandâ€™s request to amend
  his pleadings to request a divorce on the ground of a one-year separation.Â  Because
  there was evidence that the parties had been separated at least one year before
  the final hearing, we affirm the grant of a divorce, but modify the decision to
  hold this relief is based on a one-year separation.
11.Â  Finally, Husband
  contends the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife was excessive, especially
  considering that she had allegedly been uncooperative regarding his contact
  with the children and her behavior necessitated a second temporary hearing and
  the appointment of a guardian ad litem.Â  We disagree.Â  In our view, the family court adequately considered the requisite
  factors under Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313,
  315 (1991), in determining the amount to award Wife as attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  In
  particular, we note Husbandâ€™s refusal to reveal his income and assets prolonged
  the resolution of the issues on the case, causing Wife to incur legal expenses
  that would not have been necessary but for Husbandâ€™s failure to cooperate.Â  As
  to Wifeâ€™s alleged interference with visitation, we hold the evidence shows she
  did not intend to prevent Husband from having a meaningful
  relationship with his children, but was concerned that their sonâ€™s
  participation in school and church was declining because of his athletic
  pursuits. Â Finally, we note that Wife was the prevailing party on most of the
  issues in this action.Â  We therefore uphold the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to
  Wife.
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
HEARN, C.J.,
  KITTREDGE and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  In valuing the marital residence, Husband subtracted
  the amount of a tax lien that the family court ordered him to pay; however, the
  figure we have given here does not reflect this debt.
[3]Â  In his inventory, Husband indicated the State Farm
  residual account had a zero value and the total value of Husbandâ€™s assets, as
  submitted by Husband, has been amended in this opinion to reflect that the
  State Farm account has a value of $15,000.00.
[4]Â  It appears from the returns included in the record
  on appeal that Husband had returns professionally prepared for the years in
  question; however, the date of tax preparerâ€™s signature on the returns for 2002
  and 2003 is March 6, 2006, just shortly before the final hearing.Â  There is no
  signature at all on the return for 2004.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Susan B.
      Covington, Alan R. Cochran, and Kathy H. Cochran, Respondents,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Alexander Karter
      and Alexandria Karter, as Trustees of the Karter Living Trust dated 4/17/00;
      Lamar F. Thompson; Vicki A. Thompson; Neil R. Blesi; Janet E. Blesi; Carl D.
      Fago; Susan E. Fago; and Gary Blesi, Defendants,
				Of whom
      Alexander Karter and Alexandria Karter, as Trustees of the Karter Living
      Trust dated 4/17/00; Neil R. Blesi; Janet E. Blesi; and Gary Blesi are the Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Oconee County
Â J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-539
Submitted November 11, 2007 â€“ Filed
  November 29, 2007
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


	
		
			
				Lowell W. Ross, of West Union, for Appellants.
				Eugene C. Covington, Jr., of Greenville, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  This
  is an action filed by Respondents Susan B. Covington, Alan R. Cochran, and
  Kathy H. Cochran, to determine the extent of their rights to use a road
  traversing several tracts of privately owned property.Â  Defendants Alexander and Alexandria Karter, as
  Trustees of the Karter Living Trust dated 4/17/00; and Neil R., Janet E., and Gary
  Blesi (collectively â€œAppellantsâ€), all of whom were among the owners of the
  servient estates, appeal the trial courtâ€™s finding that their properties were
  subject to an easement and the courtâ€™s determination of the scope of the
  easement.Â  We affirm as modified.[1]
FACTS
On January 5, 1899, Wilt T. Meares
  purchased approximately 350 acres of land in Oconee County (the Meares
  Property).Â  On December 8, 1909, Meares deeded the northern portion of
  the land to his daughter, Ella Kestler (the Kestler Tract).Â  Appellantsâ€™
  chain of title originates in the Kestler Tract.
The Kestler Tract was bounded by Oconee Station Road, a public
  road, now known as Biggerstaff Road.Â  Wilt resided on the remaining portion
  of the Meares Property, which was not bounded by any public road, and used a
  road known as Meares Drive, which ran through the Kestler Tract, for ingress
  and egress between his property and Oconee Station Road. 
In 1931,
  the portion of the Meares Property on which Wilt had been living was deeded to another
  of his daughters, Lena Cochran, who began residing in Wiltâ€™s former home (the Cochran
  Tract).Â  In the late 1960s, Duke Power Energy Corporation purchased a
  significant portion of the Cochran Tract, in addition to other property, to
  create Lake Keowee.Â  Because Lenaâ€™s home was located within the property sold
  to Duke Power, she built another home on the Cochran Tract.Â  Lenaâ€™s grandson, Richard Meares, currently lives in the house she built.Â  Another grandson,
  Virgil Meares, lives on and owns another portion of the Cochran Tract.Â  The
  remainder of the Cochran Tract is now owned by Respondents and other Cochran
  relatives. Â 
As
  evidenced by witness testimony and public records, Meares Drive has existed in
  its present location for at least the past seventy-five years.Â  Previously, the
  road had drainage ditches on both sides; however, these have since washed out.Â 
  In the early 1980s, the Karters installed railroad ties and planted shrubbery
  on their property in the ditch lines, thus narrowing the width of the road;
  however, other parts of Meares Drive were at least twenty feet wide.Â  It
  appears undisputed that, but for Meares Drive, the Cochran tract, on which a
  church once stood, would be landlocked.  
On April 25, 2005, Respondents filed this
  action against Appellants and others asserting
  they were entitled to a twenty-foot-wide express easement, easement implied by
  prior use, easement by prescription, and easement by necessity.Â  The other
  defendants besides Appellants agreed to deed Respondents a twenty-foot-wide
  easement with rights of improvement over their respective lots.  
At trial, Appellants conceded the
  existence of an easement.Â  The trial court found Respondents had an
  easement based on the following grounds: Â (1) by grant or reservation; (2)
  implied by necessity; (3) implied by pre-existing use; and (4) by prescription.
The trial court found the width of the easement to be twenty
  feet.Â  In support of this finding, the court noted the following: Â (1) the road
  is twenty feet wide for over seventy-five percent of its length; (2)
  Appellantsâ€™ lots are not contiguous; therefore, the width of the road would
  change numerous times if the road were not of uniform width; (3) a twenty-foot-wide
  road would be sufficient to accommodate two-way traffic; (4) the width of Meares
  Drive has been at least twenty feet since the 1960s, with the only evidence of
  any narrowing being landscape timbers placed by the Karters in the ditch; and (5)
  there was testimony that at one point the road was wide enough to accommodate
  the transportation of a twenty-four-foot-wide mobile home. 
The trial court further found it was
  reasonable and necessary to the proper enjoyment of the easement that the surface
  of the road conform to that of other roads in the community.Â  In support
  of this finding, the trial court stated that â€œ[a]ll of the exhibits introduced
  indicated that paved roads are prevalent in this residential portion of the
  community.â€Â  The court also found it could â€œtake judicial notice that
  the reasonable standard for a vehicular road in the 21st Century is pavement
  rather than dirt.â€Â  As to any contention that paving the road would
  affect Appellantsâ€™ use of their properties, the trial court found the easement would
  still be used consistent with the purpose and character of the easement and
  granted Respondents â€œreasonable and necessary improvement rights in the
  easement which shall include paving and grading.â€[2]Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The determination of whether an easement exists is a
  question of fact in a law case subject to an â€œany evidenceâ€ standard of
  review.Â  Slear v. Hanna, 329 S.C. 407, 410, 496 S.E.2d 633, 635 (1998).Â  The determination of the scope
  of the easement, however, is a question in equity.Â  Hardy v. Aiken, 369
  S.C. 160, 165, 631 S.E.2d 539, 541 (2006).Â   
In an equity action,
  an appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its views
  of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Grosshuesch v. Cramer, 367 S.C.
  1, 4, 623 S.E.2d 833, 834 (2005).Â  Thus, this Court may reverse a factual
  finding by the trial court when the appellant satisfies us the finding is
  against the greater weight of the evidence.Â  Campbell v. Carr,
  361 S.C. 258, 263, 603 S.E.2d 625, 627 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Pursuant to Rule
  220(b), SCACR, â€œwhen an appellate court chooses to find facts in accordance
  with its own view of the evidence, the court must state distinctly its findings
  of fact and the reason for its decision.â€Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351
  S.C. 278, 283, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002).
Moreover, the broad
  scope of review in an equity case does not require an appellate court to
  disregard the findings of the trial court.Â  Id.; Robinson v. Tyson,
  319 S.C. 360, 362-63, 461 S.E.2d 397, 399 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  Furthermore, an
  appellant is not relieved of the burden of convincing the appellate court that
  that the trial courtâ€™s findings were in error.Â  Pinckney v. Warren, 344
  S.C. 382, 387-88, 544 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.Â 
  Appellants first argue the trial court erred in finding Respondents are
  entitled to either a prescriptive easement or an easement by necessity.Â  We find
  no reversible error.[3]
In
  their brief, Appellants conceded the existence of an easement by prescription
  or necessity in the argument section of their brief.[4]Â 
  Moreover, they did not appeal the trial courtâ€™s finding that Respondents have
  an express easement or an implied easement by prior use.[5]Â  â€œA ruling not challenged on appeal is the law of the
  case, regardless of the correctness of the ruling.â€Â  S.C. Coastal
    Conservation League v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 363 S.C.
  67, 76, 610 S.E.2d 482, 487 (2005).Â  Accordingly, the finding that
  Respondents had an easement by necessity over Appellantsâ€™ land, and
  alternatively an easement by grant, an easement implied by prior use, or an
  easement by prescription is the law of the case.Â   
In
  any event, we hold the evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s finding that
  Respondents established their right to an easement by necessity over
  Appellantsâ€™ land.Â  Both the dominant and servient estates were acquired as a
  single tract by Wilt Meares, who subsequently deeded the Kestler tract to his
  daughter, and there appears to be no dispute that Meares Drive was the
  only way to access the property from the public street at the time of this
  conveyance and, for that matter, remains so today.Â  See Kennedy v.
    Bedenbaugh, 352 S.C. 56, 60, 572 S.E.2d 452, 454 (2002) (stating the legal
  requirements of an easement by necessity are unity of title, severance of
  title, and necessity).Â   
2.Â  Appellants
  next assert the trial court erred in finding Respondents could â€œwidenâ€ the
  easement to twenty feet.Â  We find no error.
Contrary to Appellantsâ€™ contention in their brief, the
  trial court did not permit Respondents to expand the width of Meares Road; rather, the court found the width of the easement to be twenty feet.Â  The
  record has evidence to support this finding.  
Virgil Meares testified that when he was preparing to move a mobile home onto his
  property, he measured Meares Drive Â and determined the road was at least
  twenty feet wide from ditch to ditch.Â  In addition, Virgil testified that his
  father, who had also lived on the Cochran Tract, had routinely cleared the
  ditches that ran alongside Meares Drive to prevent water from draining over the
  road.Â  Virgil further estimated the road was â€œfrom ditch to ditch . . .
  probably 22 feet.â€Â  He also stated that, since his fatherâ€™s death, the ditches
  had been washed over with rain and as a result are filled in.Â   
Virgil
  also testified that the location where Meares Drive traverses his property and
  his brothersâ€™ and sistersâ€™ property, the road is twenty feet wide.Â  He believed
  that portion of the road was around one thousand feet in length.Â  He also
  noted that his information was based on a survey of his motherâ€™s property that
  he requested when he administered her estate.  
Based
  on this evidence, we uphold the trial courtâ€™s finding that the width of the
  easement is twenty feet.Â  See Moore v. Reynolds, 285 S.C.
  574, 578, 330 S.E.2d 542, 545 (Ct. App. 1985) (â€œ[W]here a deed grants a
  right of way but does not fix its width, a determination of the width of the
  easement becomes a matter of construction of the instrument with strong
  consideration being given to what is reasonable, convenient and necessary to
  accomplish the purpose for which the right-of-way was created.â€); Marlow v. Marlow, 284 S.C. 155, 161, 325 S.E.2d 703, 707
  (Ct. App. 1984) (holding a twenty-foot-wide road was sufficient to accommodate
  two-way automobile traffic and enable the owner of the dominant estate to
  access her land); 12 S.C. Jur. Easements Â§ 22 (1992) (â€œThere do not appear to be any South Carolina cases concerning the
  width of an easement by necessity, but presumably a court would look to what is
  reasonable and necessary.â€).[6] 
 
3.Â  Finally,
  Appellants argue the trial court erred in allowing Respondents to pave and
  grade Meares Drive.Â  Although we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision to allow
  Respondents to grade the road, we agree with Appellantsâ€™ challenge to the
  courtâ€™s permission to pave it.
â€œ[T]he holder of an easement
  . . . is entitled to use the servient estate in a manner that is reasonably
  necessary for the convenient enjoyment of the servitude.Â  The manner,
  frequency, and intensity of the use may change over time to take advantage of
  developments in technology and to accommodate normal development of the
  dominant estate or enterprise benefited by the servitude.â€Â  Restatement
    (Third) of Property Â§ 4.10 (2000).Â   
The
  trial court found Meares Road was initially a dirt road that descendants of
  Wilt Meares had maintained by grading and application of gravel.Â  Noting
  Respondents desired to improve the road for â€œcurrent day travelâ€ by paving it,
  the trial court found the request was â€œreasonable and necessary to the proper
  enjoyment of the easement that the surface of the road conform[ ] to other road
  standards in the community.â€Â  The trial court supported its decision by taking
  â€œjudicial noticeâ€ that paved roads, rather than dirt roads, are the present day
  norm.
We
  find this reasoning flawed for several reasons.Â  First, although the trial
  court may be correct that paved roads are more common than dirt roads, the road
  at issue here presently has a gravel surface.Â  More important, however, is the
  absence of any evidence that a graded gravel road has not provided Respondents
  â€œconvenient enjoymentâ€ of their right-of-way over Meares Drive.Â  Furthermore,
  the record is devoid of evidence suggesting the dominant estates have developed
  commercially or otherwise to the extent that vehicular traffic over a gravel
  surface has become unfeasible.Â  Indeed, as the trial court noted, Respondents
  own only 4.6 acres out of the 350-acre estate that Wilt Meares acquired in
  1899.
We therefore modify the trial courtâ€™s ruling regarding
  improvement of the easement to hold that, although Respondents may continue to
  grade Meares Drive at their own expense, they may not pave the road.
4.Â  Finally,
  Appellants assert Respondents, as remote grantees, should not be allowed to
  expand the use of an easement of limited use to that of unlimited use.Â  We
  decline to address this argument.Â  The
  trial court did not rule on this issue, and Appellants did not move under Rule
  59(e), SCRCP, to address this omission; therefore, this issue is not preserved
  for our review.Â  See In
  re Michael H., 360 S.C. 540, 546, 602 S.E.2d 729, 732 (2004) (â€œAn issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal.Â  In order
  to preserve an issue for appeal, it must be raised to and ruled upon by the
  trial court.â€); Lucas v. Rawl Family
    Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505,
  510-11, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004) (â€œIt is well settled
  that, but for a very few exceptional circumstances, an appellate court cannot
  address an issue unless it was raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€).
AFFIRMED AS
  MODIFIED.
HEARN, C.J.,
  KITTREDGE and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  The trial court acknowledged that â€œthe Karters could
  complain that their landscape timbers could be dislodged by the improvement of
  the road,â€ and, as a solution to this problem, ordered Respondents to take
  responsibility for replacing the trees and any other planted vegetation after
  paving the road.
[3]Â  Respondents assert numerous preservation
  concerns with Appellantsâ€™ brief.Â  Many of those concerns revolve around
  Respondentsâ€™ contention Appellantsâ€™ arguments are not listed in their statement of issues on appeal.Â  See State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 694 (2003) (â€œNo point will be considered which is not set forth in the
  statement of issues on appeal.â€) (citing Rule 208(b)(1)(B), SCACR).Â  In our view, Appellantsâ€™ arguments
  were all sufficiently contained in the issues on appeal.Â  Nevertheless, although
  Appellants listed the issue of the existence of an easement in their statement
  of issues on appeal, they failed to address it in the argument section of their
  brief; therefore, we decline to address it.Â  See Fields v.
    Melrose Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 312 S.C. 102, 106,
  439 S.E.2d 283, 284 (Ct. App. 1993) (â€œAn issue raised on
  appeal but not argued in the brief is deemed abandoned and will not be
  considered by the appellate court.â€).Â   
[4]Â  Specifically, Appellants made the following
  statement in their brief: Â â€œIt is admitted that the dirt road leading from
  Biggerstaff Road to the Meares home . . . existed either as a prescriptive
  easement or as an easement by necessity to the Meares property.â€  
[5] Â We are aware of the apparent inconsistency within
  the appealed order concerning the findings by the trial court that Respondents
  had both a prescriptive easement and an easement by grant or reservation.Â  See 12 S.C. Jur. Easements Â§ 10 (1992) (â€œA prescriptive easement is
  analogous to adverse possession.Â  A prescriptive easement arises not from an
  express grant or reservation or by implication, but is established by conduct
  of the owner of the dominant tenement contrary to the fee simple interest of
  the owner of the servient tenement.â€).Â  We reconcile this
  apparent contradiction by noting the order concludes that Respondents â€œare
  hereby granted an appurtenant easement by necessity or alternatively an
  easement by grant or reservation, implied by pre-existing use, or by
  prescription, in the road over [Appellantsâ€™] property known as Meares Drive.â€ (emphasis added).
 
[6]Â  Appellants also question the trial courtâ€™s statement
  that â€œThere is testimony that the road at one point was wide enough to
  accommodate the transportation of a 24 foot wide trailer by Virgil Meares,â€ noting
  the trailer came in two fourteen-foot sections.Â  Even if, as Appellants seem to
  contend, the evidence is suspect, we hold there is sufficient evidence
  otherwise to support the finding that the width of the easement is twenty feet.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				Paul H.
      Thompson, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Union County
Â Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-540
Submitted November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate
  Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary of the South Carolina Commission on Indigent
  Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
  Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, of Columbia; and
  Solicitor Kevin S. Brackett, of York; for Respondent.
			
		
	

__________
PER
  CURIAM:Â  Appellant, Paul Thompson, was indicted for and
  convicted of intimidation of court officials, witnesses, or jurors in violation
  of South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 16-9-340.[1]Â 
  He appeals, asserting the trial court erred in admitting inadmissible hearsay
  evidence from one witness to bolster the testimony of another witness, which
  was the basis of the prosecution.Â  We affirm.[2]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
This
  case arose from a telephone conversation between Thompson and Chief Sam White,
  the Chief of Public Safety for the City of Union.Â  Chief White testified that
  around three-thirty in the afternoon on Tuesday, March 15, 2005, he returned to
  his office and found a voice mail message had been left for him by Thompson
  telling the Chief who he was and leaving a phone number.Â  Chief White had known
  Thompson about twenty-five years and recognized his voice on the message.Â  
 
Chief
  White called the number and spoke with Thompson, who asked if the Chief was
  aware of Thompsonâ€™s daughterâ€™s situation.Â  The Chief told Thompson he knew
  Thompsonâ€™s daughter had been in court that day, but he was unaware of the
  sentence she received.Â  Thompson relayed he was upset because his daughter was
  just a drug user, not a seller, but that the people who were selling drugs
  never were caught.Â  Chief White talked with Thompson some about his daughterâ€™s
  case, after which Thompson made the statement that he had been in the military
  for thirty-eight years, and told the Chief that he was trained as a sniper.Â 
  Thompson discussed that the police did not catch the pushers, but only the
  users of drugs, and that he knew where they were and he was going to take care
  of them.Â  Thompson brought up his military training and asked the Chief if he
  knew what it meant that people referred to him as â€œone-shot.â€Â  Chief White told
  Thompson he could not take the law into his hands and shoot someone.Â 
  Thereafter, the focus of Thompsonâ€™s conversation changed from the drug
  dealers.Â  Thompson told Chief White that if they were having court the next
  day, â€œit would be best if [Chief White] didnâ€™t go.â€Â  The Chief asked Thompson
  what he was talking about and Thompson replied that â€œwhat happened in Atlanta
  will look like a picnic,â€ and he was â€œtelling [Chief White] as a friend,â€ that
  if they were having court the next day it would be best if the Chief did not
  attend.Â  Chief White explained that several court personnel had been killed in
  an Atlanta courtroom that previous Friday.Â  Toward the end of the conversation,
  Thompson told the Chief, â€œIâ€™m telling you as a friend, donâ€™t go to court
  tomorrow if they have it,â€ and he then hung up the phone.Â   
Chief
  White testified Thompson sounded as if he had been drinking, and seemed
  irritated and upset.Â  Knowing that Thompson was a gun dealer, Chief White
  feared for the safety of people at the courthouse.Â  After dropping off some
  money at City Hall, the Chief went to the Sheriffâ€™s Office and told Sheriff
  Howard Wells about the conversation he had with Thompson.Â   
Sheriff
  Wells testified that he is responsible for, among other things, security of the
  Union County Courthouse.Â  General Sessions Court was being held there the week
  of March 14, 2005, with Judge Westbrook presiding.Â  On Tuesday of that week,
  the court was taking guilty pleas and, after a break for lunch, bond hearings
  and more guilty pleas were scheduled.Â  Shortly after 4:00 p.m., as court was
  proceeding with these matters, Chief White came to Sheriff Wellsâ€™ office.Â  The
  Sheriff testified, â€œAround four, four ten on the afternoon of Tuesday, March
  the 15th, Sam White the Public Safety Chief came to my office and
  told me that he had had a disturbing telephone call --.â€Â  Defense counsel then
  stated, â€œObjection, your Honor, as to hearsay.â€Â  The trial court overruled the
  objection, stating simply, â€œIâ€™m going to allow it.Â  Thank you very much.Â 
  Please proceed.â€Â  Sheriff Wells then testified that Chief White came to his
  office around 4:10 p.m. and informed him he had received a call from Thompson,
  which Chief White returned.Â  Sheriff Wells stated, â€œThe substance of that
  telephone conversation gave him some concern and he was relating to me what had
  been said.â€Â  The solicitor then asked whether the â€œsubject of the conversation
  was . . . reflected in the Chiefâ€™s testimonyâ€ that he had just heard.Â  The
  Sheriff responded, â€œThatâ€™s correct.â€Â   
The
  Sheriff then went on to testify to the steps he took to ensure the security for
  the Courthouse Complex as a result of Chief Whiteâ€™s report.Â  Specifically,
  Sheriff Wells informed Judge Westbrook of the threat directed toward the
  court.Â  His office obtained a warrant against Thompson, and put a plan in
  action to neutralize the threat.Â  If Thompson could be located and taken into custody
  in time, court would proceed the next day.Â  If, however, they were unable to
  timely take Thompson into custody, he would notify Judge Westbrook and the
  courthouse would be shut down the following day.Â   
Thompson
  was subsequently located, taken into custody, and booked into the jail around
  6:20 that evening.Â  However, the Sheriff testified they were still on
  heightened alert that next day, and because of Thompsonâ€™s actions, the court
  effectively shut down the afternoon of the phone call, with no other matters
  being handled by the court that day.Â  Further, because Judge Westbrook was the
  sentencing judge in the case of Thompsonâ€™s daughter, they provided security for
  the judge, and he and his law clerk did not leave Union County until Judge
  Westbrook was notified that Thompson was in custody.Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
On
  appeal, Thompson contends the trial court erred in permitting inadmissible
  hearsay testimony by Sheriff Wells to bolster Chief Whiteâ€™s testimony about
  Thompsonâ€™s statements, these statements being the basis of Thompsonâ€™s
  prosecution.Â  Thompson argues the testimony by Sheriff Wells, that Chief White
  relayed the same information to him that Chief White testified to at trial,
  constituted an out-of-court statement offered to prove the truth of the matter
  asserted which is prohibited by Rule 801, SCRE.Â  Thompson further maintains
  these statements constituted a prior consistent statement which did not qualify
  as non-hearsay pursuant to Rule 801(d)(1)(B), SCRE.Â  Thompson asserts the
  admission of the improper bolstering testimony was prejudicial because it
  allowed the jury to hear two witnesses against him.
We
  first note that Thompson never raised below the specific arguments he makes on
  appeal.Â  He never argued to the trial court that Sheriff Wellsâ€™ testimony
  bolstered Chief Whiteâ€™s testimony, nor did he assert that the testimony of
  Sheriff Wells constituted a prior consistent statement that was inadmissible
  under the rules.Â  Thus, these arguments are not preserved for review.Â  See State v. Johnson, 363 S.C. 53, 58-59, 609 S.E.2d 520, 523 (2005) (To
  preserve an issue for appellate review there must be a contemporaneous
  objection that is ruled upon by the trial court and the objection should be
  addressed to the trial court in a sufficiently specific manner that brings
  attention to the exact error.Â  If a party fails to properly object, he is
  procedurally barred from raising the issue on appeal.); State v. Dunbar,
  356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 694 (2003) (A party need not use the exact
  name of a legal doctrine in order to preserve it, but it must be clear that the
  argument has been presented on that ground.).
Turning
  to the specific objection Thompson did make, which was the simple statement of
  â€œhearsay,â€ it is notable that the objection was made prior to Sheriff Wellsâ€™
  testimony regarding the content of Chief Whiteâ€™s statement.Â  The Sheriff
  testified Chief White reported to him â€œHe had a disturbing telephone call,â€ at
  which point defense counsel objected and the court overruled the objection.Â 
  When the Sheriff continued his answer, he explained that the telephone
  conversation was with Thompson, the substance of the conversation gave Chief
  White some concern and that the Chief related to the Sheriff what had been
  said.Â  Sheriff Wells did not, at that point, testify as to what exactly Chief
  White relayed to him.Â  It is this testimony, along with the Sheriffâ€™s response
  to the question asked of whether the subject of Thompsonâ€™s conversation with
  the Chief was reflected in Chief Whiteâ€™s testimony, that Thompson apparently
  complains of on appeal.Â  However, Thompson made no objection to these questions
  or responses at trial.
At
  any rate, assuming that Thompsonâ€™s single â€œhearsayâ€ objection was sufficient to
  constitute an objection to the line of questioning regarding what Chief White
  relayed to Sheriff Wells, we find no error.Â  First, Sheriff Wells did not
  testify, as Thompson maintains, that â€œChief White relayed to him the same
  information to which he had testified at trial.â€Â  Sheriff Wells merely stated
  the Chief â€œrelat[ed] to [him] what had been saidâ€ and that the subject of the conversation was reflected in Chief Whiteâ€™s testimony.Â  Rule 801(c), SCRE, provides, â€œâ€˜Hearsayâ€™ is
  a statement, other than one made by the declarant while testifying at the trial
  or hearing, offered in evidence to prove the truth of the matter asserted.â€ A
  statement is defined as â€œ(1) an oral or written assertion or (2) nonverbal
  conduct of a person, if it is intended by the person as an assertion.â€Â  Rule
  801(a), SCRE.Â  There was no oral or written assertion or nonverbal conduct
  testified to by the Sheriff and therefore the testimony complained of does not
  qualify as a statement under the rule.Â   
Further, even if the complained of testimony did amount to a
  statement, it was not a statement used to prove the truth of the matter
  asserted.Â  See State v. Weaver, 361 S.C. 73, 86-87, 602
  S.E.2d 786, 792-93 (Ct. App. 2004), affâ€™d as modified, 374 S.C. 313, 649
  S.E.2d 479 (2007) (finding no error in the admission of evidence because testimony did not constitute hearsay where officer never repeated
  statements made to him by individuals at the crime scene, but testified only to
  the conclusions he made based on what his investigation had revealed and testimony
  was offered to explain part of his investigation); State v. Thompson,
  352 S.C. 552, 558, 559, 575 S.E.2d 77, 81 (Ct. App. 2003) (finding testimony
  concerning a statement from a bystander to the police was not hearsay because
  it was not offered to prove the truth of the matter asserted but rather to
  explain and outline the investigation and the officerâ€™s reason for going to the
  defendantâ€™s home); State v. Kirby, 325 S.C. 390, 396, 481 S.E.2d 150,
  153 (Ct. App. 1996) (concluding testimony by police officer about dispatcherâ€™s
  call informing of drugs and firearms in a car was not hearsay where offered to
  explain the reason for the initiation of police surveillance of the vehicle in
  question); State v. Brown, 317 S.C. 55, 63, 451 S.E.2d 888, 894 (1994)
  (holding an out of court statement is not hearsay if it is offered for the
  limited purpose of explaining why a government investigation was undertaken).Â 
  Here, the testimony was offered to explain the reason behind the actions
  Sheriff Wells was required to take.Â  Accordingly, we conclude this testimony
  was not hearsay and was properly admitted to explain the necessity of the
  actions Sheriff Wells took to secure the safety of Judge Westbrook and the
  courthouse.
Finally, even if the Sheriffâ€™s testimony constituted inadmissible
  hearsay, the admission was harmless.Â  Chief White testified as to the
  conversation he had with Thompson and that he reported this conversation to
  Sheriff Wells.Â  Thus, the Sheriffâ€™s testimony that Chief White related what had
  been said in his conversation with Thompson and that the subject of Chief
  Whiteâ€™s conversation with Sheriff Wells was reflected in the Chiefâ€™s testimony
  is merely cumulative to Chief Whiteâ€™s testimony.Â  See State v.
    Haselden, 353 S.C. 190, 197, 577 S.E.2d 445, 448-49 (2003) (any error in
  admission of evidence cumulative to other unobjected-to evidence is harmless); State
    v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985) (improper
  admission of hearsay evidence is reversible error only when the admission
  causes prejudice).
For the foregoing reasons, Thompsonâ€™s
  conviction is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and PIEPER, JJ., and GOOLSBY, AJ., concur.

[1]This code section provides in pertinent part:
(A) It is unlawful for a
  person by threat or force to:

	(1)
  intimidate or impede a judge, magistrate, juror, witness, or potential juror or
  witness, arbiter, commissioner, or member of any commission of this State or
  any other official of any court, in the discharge of his duty as such;Â  or
	(2) destroy,
  impede, or attempt to obstruct or impede the administration of justice in any
  court.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  16-9-340 (2003).
[2]We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

title: MCC Outdoor v. SCDOT
text:
THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE AND SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				MCC Outdoor,
      LLC, d/b/a Fairway Outdoor Advertising, Appellant,
				v.
				South Carolina
      Department of Transportation, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Administrative Law Court
Â Ralph K. Anderson, III, Administrative
  Law Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â Â  2007-UP-541
Heard October 11, 2007 â€“ Filed November
  30, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				William James Johnson and Craig D. Justus, both of Asheville, for
  Appellant.
				Barbara Munig Wessinger, S.C. Dept. of Transportation Legal
  Division, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Appellant
  appeals the administrative law courtâ€™s (ALC) order granting summary judgment in
  favor of SCDOT and denying Appellantâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
By lease agreement dated November 22, 2002, Appellant leased real
  estate located adjacent to U.S. Highway 176 (the road) for the purpose of
  constructing a billboard.Â  In December of 2002, Appellant applied to
  SCDOT for an outdoor advertising permit to allow it to erect the billboard.Â  On
  February 12, 2003, SCDOT approved the permit for the billboard.Â  Appellant completed
  construction of the billboard in July of 2003.Â   
In December of 2003, TNT Trucking, the qualifying business for the
  billboard, went out of business.Â  By letter dated February 4, 2004, SCDOT
  notified Appellant that the permit for the billboard was revoked due to the
  qualifying businessâ€™s termination within one year of the issuance of the
  permit.Â  Subsequent to receiving notice of SCDOTâ€™s intent to revoke the permit,
  Appellant met with Joyce Gardener, a representative of SCDOT, to discuss the
  possibility of selecting another qualifying business.Â  Appellant was ultimately
  unable to find an alternate qualifying business, and the billboard was taken
  down on or around April 16, 2004.
On June 4, 2004, Appellant applied to SCDOT for a new outdoor
  advertising permit to allow it to erect a new billboard on the property.Â  By
  letter dated July 2, 2004, SCDOT informed Appellant that the review process for
  the permit request would require additional time beyond the standard thirty
  days for investigation.Â  On or around August 31, 2004, SCDOT blocked direct
  access to the property by placing concrete barriers along the road.Â  This was
  done as part of a planned transformation of the section of the road that
  borders the property into a controlled access highway.[1]  
By letter dated September 16, 2004, SCDOT notified Appellant that
  its permit request was denied because the proposed billboard site was located
  within five hundred feet of an interchange on a controlled access federal-aid
  highway.Â  Appellant requested a contested case hearing before the ALC.Â  On
  March 1, 2006, the ALC held a hearing on the matter.Â  By order dated July 20,
  2006, the ALC granted SCDOTâ€™s motion for summary judgment and denied
  Appellantâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  Appellant appeals this ruling.
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal, this
  court may not substitute its judgment for that of an agency on questions of
  fact when those facts are supported by substantial evidence.Â  Al-Shabazz v.
    State, 338 S.C. 354, 380, 527 S.E.2d 742, 756 (1999).Â  â€œIn determining whether the [ALCâ€™s]
  decision was supported by substantial evidence, this court need only find,
  looking at the entire record on appeal, evidence from which reasonable minds
  could reach the same conclusion that the administrative agency reached.â€Â  DuRant
    v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 361 S.C. 416, 420, 604 S.E.2d
  704, 706 (Ct. App. 2004)(citation omitted).Â  â€œThe mere possibility of drawing
  two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent a finding from
  being supported by substantial evidence.â€Â  Id. at 420, 604 S.E.2d at
  707.  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellant raises
  multiple challenges to the ALCâ€™s order.Â  Appellant first argues that SCDOT
  never acquired its right of direct access to the property from the road, and,
  therefore, SCDOT has failed to establish the road as a controlled access
  highway.Â  The majority of
  Appellantâ€™s remaining arguments center on the status of the road at the time of
  filing its application.Â  Specifically, Appellant
  argues that the road was not a controlled access highway at the time of the
  filing of its request for the permit,
  and, accordingly, it is vested with a right to the permit.Â  Appellant also argues that it filed its permit request in good faith, and therefore, the
  ALCâ€™s reliance on Sherman v. Reaves, 273 S.C. 542, 257 S.E.2d 735 (1979)
  constitutes error.Â  Appellant also argues
  that pursuant to the holdings
  in Pure Oil Division v. The City of Columbia, 254 S.C. 28, 34-35, 173
  S.E.2d 140, 143 (1970) and Scott v. Greenville County, 716 F.2d 1409,
  1418 (1983), its motion for summary judgment should have been granted.
Additionally, Appellant argues that SCDOT is estopped from
  claiming the road was established as a controlled access highway and that the issuance of an outdoor advertising permit is a ministerial act.Â  We find all
  of Appellantâ€™s arguments to be without merit.
I) APPELLANTâ€™S
  RIGHT OF DIRECT ACCESS
Appellant
  argues SCDOT never acquired its right of direct access to the property from the
  road, and, therefore, SCDOT has failed to establish the road as a controlled
  access highway.Â  The terms of Appellantâ€™s lease specifically address the access
  conferred to the Appellant.Â  Pursuant to the lease, Appellant received a right
  to â€œsufficient access to allow [Appellant] to service and maintainâ€ the
  billboard.Â  The ALC found Appellant had sufficient access to the property by way
  of the service roads.Â  Appellant never possessed a right of direct access to or
  from the road for SCDOT to acquire.Â  Therefore, we find this issue to be
  without merit.Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â 
II) THE ROADâ€™S STATUS AT THE
  TIME OF FILING
Appellant argues its application for an outdoor advertising permit
  was properly filed with SCDOT before the road became a controlled access
  highway, and, accordingly, it is vested with a right to the permit.Â  We disagree.[2]
Appellant
  cites the cases of Pure
    Oil Division v. The City of Columbia, 254 S.C. 28, 34-35, 173 S.E.2d 140, 143 (1970) and Scott v.
      Greenville County, 716 F.2d 1409, 1418 (1983) for the proposition that it
  was vested with a right to the permit at the time of filing its application.Â  We
  find Appellantâ€™s reliance on these cases to be misplaced.
Unlike the present case, both cases cited by Appellant deal with permits
  for land uses that were expressly allowed by the applicable zoning ordinances. Â Furthermore,
  the aggrieved parties in both of the cases cited by Appellant detrimentally
  changed their positions in reliance on the zoning ordinances. Â Appellant has
  not changed its position in reliance on the permit at issue here.Â  Appellant
  leased the property for the purpose of constructing a billboard.Â  Appellant was
  issued an outdoor advertising permit and completed construction of the
  billboard.Â  However, Appellant failed to comply with the requirements in order
  to keep the permit effective and, accordingly, was ordered to remove the
  billboard.Â  Appellantâ€™s detrimental change in position was caused by its
  failure to satisfy the requirements of keeping the original permit in effect.Â  Therefore,
  we find the cases cited by Appellant to be inapplicable to the case before us. 
 
We find the present case to be closer to Sherman v. Reaves,
  273 S.C. 542, 257 S.E.2d 735 (1979).Â  In Sherman, the Supreme Court
  refused to apply the holding of Pure Oil Division to facts similar to
  those currently before us.Â  The distinction between the cases was Sherman had â€œpresented little, if any, proof of expenditures or incurrence of obligations
  in good faith reliance upon their proposed use.â€ Id. at 545, 257 S.E.2d
  at 737.Â  Appellant contends the ALC committed error by citing this case in
  support of its order given that Appellantâ€™s application was filed in good
  faith.Â  We are not persuaded by this argument.Â  Where there is no expenditure
  or incurrence of obligation, there is also no expenditure or incurrence of obligation
  made in good faith.Â  While the Supreme Court did address the issue of Shermanâ€™s lack of good faith in his filing, the outcome of the case turned on the lack of
  detrimental reliance.Â  Â Â Â Â Â 
In the present case, Appellant applied to SCDOT for an outdoor
  advertising permit around June 4, 2004.Â  By letter dated July 2, 2004, SCDOT
  informed Appellant that the review process for the permit request would require
  additional time beyond the standard 30 days for investigation.[3]Â  While it is unclear exactly when the road became a controlled
  access highway, it is clear SCDOT acquired the property ownersâ€™ rights of direct access to and from the
  road on June 16, 2003.Â  It is also clear access to and from the section of the road adjacent to the proposed
  site of the billboard was controlled by August 31, 2004, due to SCDOT blocking direct access to the
  property by placing concrete barriers along the road.Â  Accordingly, access to the
  section of the road adjacent to the proposed site became controlled before
  SCDOT completed its investigation.Â Â Â Â Â   
Section 57-25-140(E) of the South Carolina Code (the five hundred
  feet rule) provides: â€œNo sign may be located on the interstate system or
  controlled access federal-aid primary route adjacent to or within 500 feet of
  an interchangeâ€¦.â€ South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 57-25-140(E) (Supp. 2006).
  Likewise, Regulation 63-346(B)(1)(b) provides: â€œno sign in a rural,
  unincorporated area may be erected within 500 feet of an interchange or rest
  area.â€Â  25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 63-346(B)(1)(b) (Supp. 2006).Â  It is undisputed that the proposed site for the billboard is
  located within 500 feet of an interchange. Â Accordingly, there is substantial
  evidence in the record to support the ALCâ€™s finding that Appellantâ€™s permit
  application failed to satisfy the requirements of section 57-25-140(E) and
  Regulation 63-346(B)(1)(b).
III) ESTOPPEL
Appellant argues SCDOT is estopped from arguing the road
  was established as a controlled access highway due to Joyce Gardener stating
  the section of the road adjacent to the property was not controlled access.Â 
  Appellant, in its brief, states it â€œraised this issue for the sole purpose of
  barring SCDOT from taking a position that controlled access was established for
  U.S. 176 in front of the property prior to [Appellantâ€™s] 2004 Permit Request
  Application.â€Â  Given our holding as to the time at which access to the road
  became controlled, this issue is irrelevant.Â  Moreover, while a government
  agency is not immune from the application of the doctrine of equitable
  estoppel, it cannot be estopped based on the
  unauthorized or erroneous statements of its officers or agents. Â South Carolina Coastal Council v. Vogel, 292 S.C.
  449, 452-3, 357 S.E.2d 187, 189 (Ct. App. 1987).Â   
IV) MINISTERIAL ACT
Appellant contends the issuance of an outdoor advertising permit
  is a ministerial act, and, therefore, SCDOT lacks discretion in granting such
  permits.Â  This contention is based on the language of South Carolina Code Ann.
  Â§ 57-25-150(B) (Supp. 2006) which states permits for signs coming within the
  exception in item (8) of subsection (A) of Â§ 57-25-140 â€œshallâ€ be issued.Â 
  However, section 57-25-140(E) (the five hundred feet rule) expressly applies to
  signs permitted under item (8) of subsection (A) of Â§ 57-25-140. Â 
The
  words of a statute â€œmust be given their plain and ordinary
  meaning without resort to subtle or forced construction to limit or expandâ€ the
  statuteâ€™s operation. Â Hitatchi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C.
  174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992). Â However, â€œ[t]he cardinal rule of statutory
  construction is to ascertain and effectuate the legislative intent whenever
  possible.â€ Â Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commn., 332 S.C. 54,
  62, 504 S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998). Â â€œAll rules of statutory construction are
  subservient to the one that the legislative intent must prevail if it can be
  reasonably discovered in the language used, and that language must be construed
  in the light of the intended purpose of the statute.â€ Â Kiriakides v. United
    Artists Commcâ€™ns, Inc., 312 S.C. 271, 275, 440 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1994).Â  Applying the â€œshallâ€ in Â§ 57-25-150(B)
  literally without factoring in the express limitation included in Â§ 57-25-140
  would result in the issuance of a permit for the erection of a sign that cannot
  legally be erected.Â  Clearly, this cannot be the outcome intended by the
  Legislature.Â  Accordingly, we find this argument to be without merit.
CONCLUSION
For the
  reasons stated above, the order of the ALC is
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, SHORT, and WILLIAMS JJ., concur.

[1] This transformation was part of a three mile
  improvement project for I-585.Â  The project started in 1999 with funding
  allocations.Â  SCDOT started acquiring right-of-way for the project in 2001 and
  acquired the rights of direct access to the subject property in 2003.Â  Physical
  construction on the project began in June of 2004, but there was no physical
  indication of the project in the proximity of the subject property until the
  end of August of 2004 when SCDOT used concrete barriers to block direct access
  to the property.  
[2] We have summarized, combined, and addressed Appellantâ€™s arguments dealing with the
  status of the road at the time of filing its application into this issue.
[3] Regulation 63-349(L) provides:

	Upon
  receipt of the permit application, the District Sign Coordinator will inspect
  the sign site in order to ascertain if the location legally qualifies.Â  The
  Department reserves the right to consider any application for a sign permit for
  up to 30 days from the date the application is submitted.Â  Any application not
  approved within that time may be deemed by the applicant to have been rejected
  unless the Department notifies the applicant in writing on the reasons it
  requires further time to investigate the application.

25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 63-349(L)(Supp. 2006).

text:
THIS OPINION HAS
