THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				John R.
      Marceron and Jeanne M. Marceron, Respondents,
				v.
				J. Reese Helms
      and Brenda Helms, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Master-In-Equity
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-542
Heard June 6, 2007 â€“ Filed November 30,
  2007Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Carl Scott Masel, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellants.
				Mason Summers and Charles E. Carpenter, Jr., both of Columbia, for
  Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Â Reese
  and Brenda Helms appeal the master-in-equityâ€™s denial of their motion for
  non-suit claiming John and Jeanne Marceron failed to prove that the Helms breached
  the contract between the parties or that they suffered any damages as a result.Â 
  We affirm.
FACTS
The Helmses were the owners of a home located on a lot they leased inside of Ocean
  Lakes Family Campground (Ocean Lakes).[1]Â 
  The Helmses decided to subdivide their lease site (MH9) into three separate lease
  sites (MH9-A, MH9-B, and MH9-C).[2]Â 
  The Helmses hired a surveyor to survey their lease site to ensure that each new
  site would meet Ocean Lakesâ€™ minimum size requirement.Â   
In the summer of 2003, the Marcerons and the Helmses began
  discussing the possibility of the Marcerons purchasing the lease rights to
  MH9.Â  As a result of these discussions, on June 7, 2004, the Marcerons entered
  into a contract with the Helmses to purchase MH9-C for $90,000.00.Â  The
  contract required the Helmses to provide a survey of MH9-C and gave the
  Marcerons a right of first refusal for MH9-A and MH9-B.Â  The contract provided
  that the closing would occur on June 8, 2007, and that MH9 would be subdivided
  to create MH9-C on or before October 1, 2004.Â  Also on June 7, 2004, John
  Marceron and Reese Helms met with Wayne Peeler, a builder the Helms had
  contacted about constructing a home on the site, at the lease site to ensure
  the proposed home would fit on the site.Â  At this meeting, Reese Helms gave John
  Marceron a survey of MH9 with the proposed subdivided lots marked on it. It is
  undisputed that this survey did not accurately depict the size of MH9-C or its
  existing boundaries as set by Ocean Lakes.Â  The
  inaccuracy in the survey was due to an earlier shifting of the boundary lines
  by Ocean Lakes to resolve a dispute with an adjoining neighbor.Â  The moving of
  the boundary lines resulted in an overall increase in the square footage of
  MH9-C and decrease in the lake frontage of MH9 as a whole.Â  Following the meeting, the Marcerons
  purchased the lease rights to MH9-C from the Helmses for the agreed upon price.
By letter dated June 15, 2004, Reese Helms informed the Marcerons he
  had received an offer of $180,000.00 for the lease rights to the remaining
  portions of MH9 and gave them until June 27, 2004 to exercise their right of
  first refusal by matching the offer.Â  By letter dated June 23, 2004, the
  Marcerons informed the Helmses they would purchase the lease rights to all of
  MH9 for the price of $260,000.00 and the earlier payment of $90,000.00 should
  be treated as a prepayment towards this transaction.Â  The letter also expressly
  stated: â€œThis [agreement] does not change any agreement per our original
  contract on June 7, 2004.â€Â  On July 2, 2003, the Marcerons paid the Helms the
  agreed upon amount and received a written lease from Ocean Lakes for MH9.Â 
 
The Marcerons claim they were not aware of the previous change in
  the boundary line until after their purchase of the lease rights.Â  After
  unsuccessfully attempting to resolve the boundary line issue with the Helms and
  Ocean Lakes, the Marcerons initiated this current action on October 18, 2004.Â 
  The Marcerons alleged the following causes of action: breach of contract;
  negligent misrepresentation; fraud; and breach with fraudulent intent.Â  The
  Marcerons sought damages in the amount of the difference between the values of
  the site as represented in the survey and the site as actually conveyed,
  punitive damages, and reasonable attorney fees and costs for the action.Â  By
  consent, the case was referred to the Horry County Master in Equity, J. Stanton
  Cross, Jr.Â  The matter was heard at trial on March 30, 2006.Â  At the conclusion
  of the Marceronsâ€™ case, the Helms moved for a directed verdict on all issues.Â 
  The Master informed the Helms that they were really seeking an involuntary
  nonsuit, treated their motion as such, and denied their motion.Â  By final order
  filed June 9, 2006, the Master found in favor of the Marcerons for breach of
  contract and awarded damages in the amount of $26,000.00 which represented the
  difference in the value of the lot as contracted and the value of the lot as
  conveyed.Â  The Helms now appeal the Masterâ€™s denial of their motion for
  involuntary nonsuit claiming the Marcerons failed to prove the Helms breached
  the contract between the parties or that they suffered any damages as a result.Â Â 
 
STANDARD OF
  REVIEW
We
  note initially that while the Helmsâ€™ motion at the close of the evidence was
  couched as a â€œdirected verdictâ€ motion, governed by Rule 50, SCRCP, this was a
  non-jury action. Â Rule 50, SCRCP, as noted by the master, is only applicable to
  jury trials. Â The proper motion for the Helmsâ€™ to have made was a motion for
  involuntary non-suit under Rule 41(b), SCRCP. Â â€œAfter the plaintiff in an
  action tried by the court without a jury has completed the presentation of his
  evidence, the defendant, . . . may move for a dismissal on the ground that upon
  the facts and the law the plaintiff has shown no right to relief.â€ Rule 41(b),
  SCRCP.Â  Rule 41(b), SCRCP, â€œallows the judge as fact finder to weigh the
  evidence, determine the facts and render a judgment
  against the plaintiff at the close of his case if justified.â€ Â Johnson
    v. J.P. Stevens & Co., 308 S.C. 116, 118, 417 S.E.2d 527, 529 (1992). 
 
In
  reviewing the rulings of a trial judge on motions for involuntary nonsuit, this
  Court must review the evidence and all inferences in the light most favorable
  to the nonmoving party. Â Rewis v. Grand Strand Gen. Hosp., 290 S.C. 40, 41-2, 348 S.E.2d 173, 174 (1986). If more than one
  reasonable inference can be drawn from the evidence, the motion for nonsuit
  must be denied. Â Id.Â  â€œIn deciding a motion for nonsuit, the trial court
  must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most
  favorable to the plaintiff.â€ Â Bullard v. Ehrhardt, 283 S.C. 557, 558, 324
  S.E.2d 61, 61 (1984). â€œIf there is no relevant competent evidence reasonably
  tending to establish the material elements of the plaintiffâ€™s case a motion for
  nonsuit must be granted.â€ Â Id.
â€œA
  breach of contract seeking money damages is an action at law.â€Â  South Carolina Fed. Sav. Bank v. Thornton-Crosby Dev. Co., 310 S.C. 232, 235,
  423 S.E.2d 114, 116 (1992).Â  On appeal of an action at law tried without a
  jury, â€œthe findings of fact of the trial court will not be disturbed unless
  found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the trial courtâ€™s
  findings. The rule is
  the same with or without a reference.â€ Â Townes
    Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775
  (1976). The trial courtâ€™s findings are equivalent to a juryâ€™s findings in a law
  action. Â Chapman v. Allstate Ins. Co., 263 S.C. 565, 567, 211 S.E.2d
  876, 877 (1975). Â This courtâ€™s role is to determine whether any evidence
  reasonably supports the factual findings of the trial court. Â Townes
    Assocs., Ltd., 266 S.C. at 86, 221 S.E.2d at 776. Â Additionally, the
  appellate court can correct errors of law. Okatie River, L.L.C. v. Southeastern Site Prep, L.L.C., 353 S.C. 327, 334, 577 S.E.2d 468,
  472 (Ct. App. 2003).  
While
  the facts of this particular case are unique, the standard of review applies
  and operates here like in any other case.Â  Accordingly, if there was any
  evidence or reasonable inference to reasonably support the Maceronsâ€™ case, we
  must affirm the Masterâ€™s denial of the Helmsesâ€™ motion for involuntary
  nonsuit.Â  Likewise, if there is any evidence in the record which reasonably supports
  the Masterâ€™s final determination, we must affirm.
LAW/ANALYSIS
In
  an action for breach of contract, the plaintiff must prove the existence of a
  contract, its breach, and damages caused by the breach.Â  See Baughman
    v. Southern Ry. Co. 127 S.C. 493, 121 S.E. 356, 356 (1924).

	The contract for MH9-C provided:
	
		Conveyance Shall Be Made subject to all easements as well as covenants of record (providing
  they do not make title unmarketable) and all governmental [statutes],
  ordinances, rules and regulations: A survey map of leased lot 9C, section MH
  shall be provided by the seller prior to the closing date.
	

(Bolded in the
  original).Â  The Helmses claim this requirement does not apply because it was
  included in the contract for the lease rights to MH9-C and not in the agreement
  for MH9 in its entirety.Â  However, included in the letter in which the
  Marcerons exercised their right of first refusal to the remainder of MH9 is a
  provision that states: â€œThis does not change any agreement per our original
  contract. . . .â€Â  Furthermore, it is clear that the parties, while contracting
  for MH9-C, had considered a transfer of MH9 in its entirety.Â  The contract for
  MH9-C included the right of first refusal for the remainder of MH9 and the
  survey provided as part of the transaction for MH9-C was a survey of MH9 in its
  entirety. Accordingly, there is evidence in the record to support the Masterâ€™s
  finding that the Helmses were required to provide a survey as part of the
  contract for MH9.
Implicit in the requirement to provide a survey is the requirement
  that the survey which is provided be an accurate survey.Â  â€œCommon sense and good faith are the
  leading touchstones of construction of the provisions of a contract; where one
  construction makes the provisions unusual or extraordinary and another
  construction which is equally consistent with the language employed, would make
  it reasonable, fair and just, the latter construction must prevail.â€Â  C.A.N. Enters., Inc. v. South Carolina Health &
    Human Servs. Fin. Comâ€™n  296
  S.C. 373, 377, 373 S.E.2d 584, 586 (1988) (citing Farr v. Duke Power Co., 265 S.C. 356, 360, 218 S.E.2d 431, 434 (1975)).Â  It is undisputed that the survey
  provided by the Helmses was inaccurate.Â   
During
  the trial, Reese Helms testified that at the meeting, he informed John Maceron
  of the inaccuracy of the survey due to an earlier shifting of the boundary
  lines by Ocean Lakes to resolve a dispute with an adjoining neighbor.Â  Brenda
  Helms testified that she discussed the shift in the boundary line with John
  Marceron on the day of the meeting.Â  Wayne Peeler testified that Reese Helms
  informed John Marceron at the meeting that the boundary line had been moved.Â 
  He also testified that the measurements the three men used to lay out the home
  site reflected the change in the boundary line.Â  However, John Marceron
  testified that he was unaware of the inaccuracy of the survey or the change in
  the boundary line.Â   
Despite
  the conflicting testimony, the Master found the Marcerons were unaware of the
  inaccuracies in the survey. Â Although John Marceronâ€™s testimony conflicts with other evidence in the record, our
  standard of review dictates that we affirm if any evidence exists in the record
  to reasonably support the findings of the Master and does not allow us to weigh
  the evidence. Accordingly, we find evidence to support the Masterâ€™s finding
  that Marcerons were unaware of the inaccuracies in the survey.Â  See Sherman v. W & B Enters., Inc. 357 S.C. 243, 250, 592 S.E.2d 307,
  310 (Ct. App. 2003).  
The Helmsesâ€™
  argue that because the dimensions and boundaries of lots in Ocean Lakes are subject to change conferring lease rights to sites of set dimensions is
  impossible.Â  We are not persuaded by this argument.Â  By the terms of the
  contract, the Helmses agreed to provide a survey of the lot to be conveyed. The
  inaccuracies in the survey were material to the contract because the survey
  provided the only means by which the Marcerons could determine the land of
  which they were purchasing the lease rights.Â  The moved boundary line served as
  the boundary between the MH9 and the adjoining lease site.Â  Accordingly, the
  physical change to the boundary line which was not reflected in the survey
  equally affected lot MH9 in its entirety and the proposed lot MH9-C.Â  Â 
The
  Helms claim that because the value of the lease site now exceeds the amount the
  Marcerons paid, the Marcerons cannot show any resulting damages.Â  This argument
  is unpersuasive.Â  â€œIn a breach of contract action, damages serve to place the
  nonbreaching party in the position he would have enjoyed had the contract been
  performed.â€Â  South Carolina Federal Sav. Bank v. Thornton-Crosby
    Development Co., Inc.  303 S.C. 74, 77, 399 S.E.2d 8,10 - 11 (Ct.
  App.1990).Â  The Marceron sought damages based on the correct measure: the
  difference in the value of the lot as contracted for and the value of the lot
  as conveyed.  
â€œIn South Carolina, a property owner is competent to offer testimony as to the value of his property.â€ Abercrombie v. Abercrombie, 372 S.C. 643, 647,
  643 S.E.2d 697, 699 (Ct. App. 2007) (citing Cooper v. Cooper, 289
  S.C. 377, 379, 346 S.E.2d 326, 327 (Ct. App. 1986)).Â  The rule that a property
  owner is competent to present an opinion as to the propertyâ€™s value is well
  recognized. Lewis v. South Carolina State Highway Dept., 278 S.C. 170,
  173, 293 S.E.2d 434, 436 (1982).  
John
  Marceron testified that the value of the lease site was based heavily on the
  amount of lake frontage the lot had.Â  He testified that the lot as represented
  in the survey had a total of 153 feet of lake frontage, but the lot as conveyed
  only had 138 feet of lake frontage.Â  He testified that the difference between
  the two measurements equaled ten percent of the total lake frontage as
  represented in the survey.Â  He also testified that the increase in the total
  amount of square footage did not increase the value of the lease site.Â  He
  stated the additional land was valueless to him because it was made up of a
  roadway and an unsightly berm. Â He also testified that the total purchase price
  for MH9 was $260,000.00 and explained that he was seeking ten percent of the
  total purchase in damages as result of the reduction in lake frontage.Â  Accordingly,
  there is evidence in the record support the Masterâ€™s findings as to damages.Â  Â Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
For the
  reasons stated above, the order of the Master is
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, SHORT, and WILLIAMS JJ., concur.


[1] The lots located inside Ocean Lakes are referred to
  as lease sites because they are owned by Ocean Lakes and are leased to
  individuals who construct or position homes upon them.Â  Ocean Lakes, at all times, retains the right to adjust and move the boundary lines of any and all
  lease sites.Â  Accordingly, the lease sites do not have permanently set boundary
  lines.Â Â Â Â Â Â   
[2] Ocean Lakes allows individuals to subdivide their
  lease sites as long as each proposed site will have at least 3,000 square feet
  based on the existing boundaries as set by Ocean Lakes.Â

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Diane Shannon, Respondent,
				v.
				James McGee,
      Robert C. Hood, Sr., as Personal Representative of the Estate of Betty Hood
      and Robert C. Hood, Sr., d/b/a Hoodâ€™s Used Cars, Defendants, of whom Robert
      C. Hood, Sr., d/b/a Hoodâ€™s Used Cars is the Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Marion County
Gerald M. Angelo, Special Referee 
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-543
Submitted October 10, 2007 â€“ Filed
  November 30, 2007
REVERSED 



	
		
			
				Johnny Gardner, of Conway, for Appellant.
				George Jebaily and Â Rangeley Chewning, both of Florence, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: In
  this civil case, we reverse the Special Refereeâ€™s denial of a motion to set
  aside an entry of default.  
FACTS
This case arises from an automobile accident that occurred in
  Marion County South Carolina.Â  A GMC vehicle failed to yield the right-of-way,
  striking a Dodge van.Â  The GMC vehicle was driven by James McGee (McGee).Â  Diane
  Shannon (Shannon) was a passenger in the Dodge van.Â   
As a result of the accident, Shannon suffered multiple injuries.Â 
  Specifically, Shannon underwent surgery to correct her right hand, right forearm,
  and left knee.Â  Unfortunately, Shannonâ€™s left knee developed an infection,
  which required a second surgery.Â  The surgical sites became infected, which
  ultimately led to a partial amputation of Shannonâ€™s left leg.Â   
A summons and complaint were filed on June 6, 2005, and Robert
  Hood, doing business as Hoodâ€™s Used Cars, was personally served two days
  later.Â  Hood failed to respond.Â  Consequently, Shannon filed a Motion for Entry
  of Default.Â  On July 13, 2005, an entry of default was entered, and the matter was
  referred to the Special Referee to ascertain damages.Â   
A hearing before the Special Referee was held on August 12, 2005.Â 
  Prior to this hearing, Hood was personally served with notice of the hearing
  and the order of entry of default on July 26, 2005.Â  Hood retained counsel on
  August 11, 2005, one day prior to the hearing before the Special Referee.Â  Hood
  made a motion to set aside the entry of default.Â   
The Special Referee found that at the time of the accident, the
  GMC vehicle was titled in Betty Hoodâ€™s name.Â  The Special Referee: (1) found McGee
  to be an employee of Hoodâ€™s Used Cars at the time of the accident; (2) held Robert
  Hood (Hood), doing business as Hoodâ€™s Used Cars, was negligent in entrusting a
  company vehicle to McGee; (3) concluded Shannon incurred and will incur
  substantial medical costs; and (4) refused to set aside the entry of default.Â 
  Ultimately, the Special Referee entered a judgment against Hood in the amount
  of $1,475,000.Â   
On appeal, Hood argues the Special Referee committed reversible
  error by not setting aside the entry of default.Â  Shannon maintains the grant
  or denial of a motion to set aside the entry of default is an interlocutory
  appeal, which is not immediately appealable.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A court may set aside an entry of default if good cause is shown.Â 
  Rule 55(c), SCRCP.Â  Whether good cause is established is left to the sound
  discretion of the trial court.Â  Williams v. Vanvolkenburg, 312 S.C. 373,
  375, 440 S.E.2d 408, 409 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  We will not disturb a discretionary
  ruling on appeal unless the ruling is without any evidentiary support or
  controlled by an error of law.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Before we address whether the Special
  Referee committed reversible error by not setting aside the entry of default,
  we confront the issue of whether this appeal is properly before us.Â   
A. This appeal
  is properly before us. Â 
Shannon initially argues this Court lacks jurisdiction to
  decide this case because this appeal constitutes an interlocutory appeal.Â  We
  disagree.
Generally,
  an appeal to this Court will be allowed only if there has been a final judgment.Â  Hagood v. Sommerville, 362 S.C. 191, 194, 607 S.E.2d 707, 708 (2005).Â  For
  the purposes of determining whether an order is appealable, â€œfinal judgmentâ€
  refers to the disposition of all the issues in the case.Â  Doe v. Howe,
  362 S.C. 212, 216, 607 S.E.2d 354, 356 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The present case
  constitutes a â€œfinal judgmentâ€ by the Special Referee.  
The
  Special Referee denied Hoodâ€™s motion to set aside the entry of default and
  entered a default judgment of $1,475,000.Â  This terminates the litigation because all Shannon must do to recover the judgment amount is collect.Â  See Ateyeh v. United
    of Omaha Life Ins. Co., 293 S.C. 436, 437, 361 S.E.2d 340, 340 (Ct. App.
  1987) (An order setting aside an entry of default is not appealable absent a
  final judgment.); Thynes v. Lloyd, 294 S.C. 152, 153, 363 S.E.2d 122,
  122 (Ct. App. 1987) (An order refusing to set aside an entry of default is not
  appealable until after final judgment.). However, even if we assume the Special
  Refereeâ€™s order is not a final judgment, this appeal is properly before us.
The
  following four situations permit a party to appeal absent a final judgment: 
 

	(1)
  intermediate judgments, orders or decrees involving the merits, (2) orders
  affecting substantial rights when such orders in effect determine the action
  and prevent a judgment from which an appeal may be taken or when the orders
  discontinue the action, (3) a final order in special proceedings, and (4)
  interlocutory orders [relating to injunctions].

Â Walker v. Springs
  Indus., Inc., 298 S.C. 249, 251, 379 S.E.2d 729, 730 (Ct. App. 1989).
An
  order affects a substantial right if the order determines and discontinues the
  action.Â  Brown v. County of Berkeley, 366 S.C. 354, 361, 622 S.E.2d 533,
  537 (2005).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Special Refereeâ€™s order in the current case determines
  and discontinues the action.Â  The order determines the action because Hood is
  held liable for the injuries suffered by Shannon.Â  The order terminates the
  action because all Shannon must do to recover the judgment amount is collect.Â  Thus,
  this appeal is properly before us.Â   
B. The Special
  Referee committed reversible error in not setting aside the entry of default.
As noted above, the decision of whether to
  grant relief from an entry of default is a matter solely within the sound
  discretion of the trial court.Â  Bage, LLC v. Se. Roofing Co. of Spartanburg,
    Inc., 373 S.C. 457, 471, 646 S.E.2d 153, 160 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  An abuse of
  discretion arises if the lower courtâ€™s decision is controlled by an error of
  law or is without evidentiary support.Â  Id. at 464-65, 646 S.E.2d at
  157.Â  Consequently, the question before us is not whether we believe good cause
  existed to set aside the entry of default, but whether the Special Refereeâ€™s
  determination is supported by evidence and not controlled by an error of law.Â  Id. 
 
â€œFor good cause shown the court may set aside an entry of default .
  . . .â€ Â Rule 55(c), SCRCP.Â  Thus, the standard for granting relief from an
  entry of default is good cause.Â  Bage, LLC, 373 S.C. at 470, 646 S.E.2d at
  160.Â  In this case, the Special Referee applied the good cause standard in
  denying the motion to set aside the entry of default.Â  The Special Referee
  applied the correct legal standard; therefore, the Special Refereeâ€™s decision
  is not controlled by an error of law.Â  Now, we must consider whether the
  Special Refereeâ€™s decision is supported by the evidence.
In determining whether to set aside an entry of default, the
  factors the Special Referee â€œshould consider are: (1) the timing of the motion
  for relief; (2) whether the defendant has a meritorious defense; and (3) the
  degree of prejudice to the plaintiff if relief is granted.â€Â  Id. at 472,
  646 S.E.2d at 161.Â  The Special Referee did not make specific findings with
  respect to each of these three enumerated factors, but he did apply the factors
  in denying the motion to set aside the entry of default.Â  The Special Referee
  is not required to make specific findings in regard to these factors if
  sufficient evidence supports the finding of the lack of good cause.Â  Id.Â  
 
The first factor is the timing of the motion for relief.Â  In this
  case, Shannon filed the summons and complaint on June 6, 2005. Shannon personally served the summons and complaint on Hood on June 8, 2005.Â  Hood made the
  motion to set aside the entry of default on August 11, 2005.Â  Only two months
  elapsed between the time Hood was served with the summons and complaint and
  when he moved for relief.Â Â  Â Â Â Â 
The second factor is whether the defendant has a meritorious defense.Â Â 
  A meritorious defense does not have to be a perfect defense nor does have to be
  guaranteed to prevail at a trial. Graham v. Town of Loris, 272 S.C. 442,
  543, 248 S.E.2d 594, 599 (1978).Â Â  â€œIt need be only one which is worthy of a
  hearing or judicial inquiry because it raises a question of law deserving of
  some investigation and discussion or a real controversy as to essential facts
  arising from conflicting or doubtful evidence.â€ Id.Â  This case arose due
  to an automobile accident.Â  Hood maintains that at the time of the accident,
  McGee was not acting as Hoodâ€™s employee.Â  The issue is worthy of investigation
  and thus the second factor weighs in favor of Hood.
The final factor is the degree of prejudice to the plaintiff if the
  entry of default is set aside.Â  We fail to see any prejudice that would result
  if entry of default is set aside.Â  It does not appear that evidence essential
  to the adjudication of this case on the merits will be affected by a reversal.Â 
  Thus, this factor weighs in favor of Hood.Â   
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the Special Refereeâ€™s decision is  
REVERSED.  [1] 

STILWELL,
  SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral arguments pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
